description:
Free BBQ and chat with Council & Kāpiti Mountain Bike Club, Council staff and Kapiti MTB club have been around Waikanae Park hill, checking out some of the do-it-yourself bike tracks that have been popping up. We’ve been walking the hills (and jumping into a few of the holes!) to get a real sense of the terrain, the steep drops, and the jump locations, and yes, photos never quite do the scale justice!
While some of the current tracks and features are unsafe and need to be removed, we get it, this isn’t about shutting down fun. It’s about ensuring the space can work better for everyone, now and in the future, through best practices.
That’s why this Sunday, we’re inviting local young riders and their whānau to come down for a Free BBQ and kōrero.
Meet the crew, share your thoughts, and be part of the conversation about what mountain biking in the park could look like moving forward, using the NZ MTB guidelines to inform good track-building practices.
Where: Waikanae Park, end of the rugby fields
When: Sunday, 5 October at 12pm
label: Hobbies & Interests

description:
(Re)generation next: The Poet Laureate steps down, Aotearoa New Zealand Poet Laureate Chris Tse marks the end of his term in this exciting evening with fellow poets Ken Arkind, Cadence Chung, Gregory O’Brien, Chris Price, and Ruby Solly.
Reflections on the future
Join Chris at the National Library to mark the end of his time in the role with his reflections on the future of Aotearoa New Zealand poetry and readings from special guests.
"I left the doors to the past and the future unlocked ... "
Chris Tse’s three-year term as Aotearoa New Zealand Poet Laureate ends on Phantom Billstickers National Poetry Day, when the next Poet Laureate will be announced: https://www.nzbookawards.nz/nat.../2016-national-poetry-day/
About the speakers
Chris Tse (he/him) was born and raised in Lower Hutt, New Zealand. He studied film and English literature at Victoria University of Wellington, where he also completed an MA in Creative Writing at the International Institute of Modern Letters. In 2022, he was named the 13th New Zealand Poet Laureate. His poetry, short fiction, and non-fiction have been recorded for radio and widely published in numerous journals, magazines and anthologies. He has published several collections of poetry and his latest book Super Model Minority (2022) was longlisted for the Ockham New Zealand Book Awards 2023.
Ken Arkind is an American poet, author, performer, and educator originating from Steamboat Springs in Colorado. He holds the 2006 title of the American National Poetry Slam Champion and the 2010 title of Nuyorican Poets Cafe Grand Slam Champion. Ken now resides in Auckland and is a recent graduate from the Manukau Institute of Technology’s Creative Arts Programme.
Cadence Chung (she/they) is a poet, student, and musician from Wellington, currently studying at the New Zealand School of Music. Her poems started being published in her junior years of high school, and her debut chapbook anomalia was published by We Are Babies Press in April 2022. Her writing takes inspiration from antique stores, Tumblr text posts, and dead poets.
Gregory O’Brien is a poet, painter, author, curator, and editor. His most recent poetry publication is a collection of poems and paintings, House and contents (2022). Other recent publications include a book-length meditation on the Pacific, Always song in the water (2019) and the Ockham award winning book Don Binney: Flight Path (2023).

description:
Voices from the Moana: Amplifying Pacific stories of healing and resilience, Talanoa Tai Learning is a new collection of learning experiences. They're designed to help you build your cultural responsiveness and improve your ability to engage meaningfully with Pacific communities. Talanoa is a Paciﬁc style of deep dialogue, with a focus on how we connect to each other and strengthen relationships, while still being able to share honest and eﬀective insights. Tai refers to ocean waters, which represent your opportunity to rise through the ebb and ﬂow of this learning journey. If you want to strengthen your capability in this space, to create transformational change, and to enhance your relationships with people from diﬀerent communities - this workshop is your chance to grow.
What will I gain from Voices from the Moana?
In Voices from the Moana, you will explore and share rich narratives of healing and resilience from different Pacific nations and perspectives. The Pacific ocean is a diverse place and we have our own unique stories of healing through traditional practices, beliefs and methods. This Talanoa Tai learning experience invites reflection on your own understanding of different healing modalities from the Pacific and the impact it has on your worldview. It will equip you to advocate for social justice through Pacific voices. You'll gain practical tolls and insights that you can apply directly to your work.
This is a 3 hour in-person learning experience.
Who is this workshop for?
These learning experiences are for both Paciﬁc professionals and those from other communities. You don’t need to have prior knowledge or experience in this area - we’ll meet you where you are and provide a welcoming, supportive environment for you to learn.
Cultural responsiveness is for everyone. Whether you’re in social work, education, government, community sectors or beyond, these learning experiences have been designed to help everyone build their skills. If you think this professional development might be right for you, it is!
Cost
When work is busy and budgets are tight, cultural responsiveness can often take a backseat. But this is an aﬀordable investment that will help you address the challenges that so many of us share, like how to build engagement and trust, and avoid relationship missteps. It’s not a buzzword; it’s a vital skill if you want to better meet the needs of the people you serve. Price: $170 (inc GST) per person, including morning tea.
 Facilitator
Our team’s extensive research and experience feed into these sessions, with a focus on interactive activities and practical, real-life examples. Our team has decades of experience across a range of ﬁelds, in particular social development, education, and research. We have worked with organisations and businesses across the Paciﬁc, and our engagement with diﬀerent Paciﬁc languages, cultures, and communities means we oﬀer robust, informed perspectives. Fa’aeafale’upolu (Polu) Samuelu is the facilitator of this Talanoa Tai Learning experience.
label: Community & Culture

description:
Amélie the Musical, ‘Amélie the Musical’ is set to enchant Wellington for its Australasian premiere. The show will play at The Hannah theatre in November. The Grammy and Olivier Award-nominated adaptation follows shy Amélie Poulain, who carries out small acts of kindness for those around her. 
Wellington’s Rachel McSweeney, who played Sophie in the 2025 production of ‘Mamma Mia!’, stars as Amélie. Gemma Hoskins is Amélie’s mother, and William Duignan plays the pop icon Elton John. A cast of thirteen takes on many roles, from greengrocers to goldfish. Produced by WITCH Music Theatre, the show captures the whimsy of the film that made Amélie a global favourite. It features a Grammy-nominated score by Daniel Messé and Nathan Tyson, as well as a witty book by Craig Lucas. Directors Maya Handa Naff and Nick Lerew, with music director Hayden Taylor, bring Amélie’s quirky world to life. The Guardian has described the musical as “a magical and emotional triumph”.
label: Arts & Theatre

description:
Bob McNeill and Emily Roughton, Bob McNeill and Emily Roughton
Bob McNeill & Emily Roughton are two of New Zealand's best-known folk musicians. They bring their deep musical connection to festivals across New Zealand, playing their favourite songs and tunes collected over years of playing together at festivals, stages and late into the night at kitchen tables.
Based in Wellington, Bob is one of NZ's best known folk songwriters. His songs have been covered by artists in NZ, Australia, the UK and USA. New Zealand Musician magazine compared his songwriting to Bruce Springsteen and Mark Knopfler; the Dominion Post likened him to Jackson Brown, James Taylor, Luka Bloom and Dougie Ma­cLean. A guitarist, he is known for both his open-tuned acoustic fingerstyle style and electric guitar playing. He has toured widely in NZ, Australia, Canada, Ireland, the UK and USA. His latest album, released in June 2024, is Lost Stars, an extended release on CD and download featuring new recordings and rarities, with Emily on violin and piano.
From Whangarei, Emily is a virtuoso violinist inspired by the Scottish tradition and the modern trad movement. Classically trained, she is infinitely adaptable with her gorgeous stylings and fiery tune playing and the perfect foil for Bob's lyrical songs.
Don't miss a chance to see these two consummate musicians share their footstomping collection of banging tunes, favourite songs and stolen moments from the last 20 years.
Tickets $25 from Eventfinda or book by text to 02102361951
label: Music & Concerts

description:
Anti-Pageant 2025, Anti-Pageant: The Next Drag Monster 2025
Presented by Allikins Productions | Created by The Den of Thurst

It’s time to summon all ghouls, ghosts, goblins, zombaes — and of course, our beloved theys — for the return of the Anti-Pageant this Halloween.

Prepare for a night of twisted glamour and unholy talent as we crown Aotearoa’s next Drag Monster for 2025. This is drag at its filthiest, fiercest, and most fabulously freaky.

Featuring a lineup of handpicked, up-and-coming alternative drag artists from across the motu, expect haunting looks, high drama, and performances that will leave you screaming (in the best way). Come unleash your inner demon, revel in the weird, and celebrate the beauty of being unapologetically other. We invite you to bring your best Halloween costumes and creations to join in the celebration.

Join us in the eerie depths of Ivy Bar and Cabaret this Halloween and witness the ascension of our next Drag Monster. It’s a night you won’t forget — and one you may never recover from.

Show Details

Doors open at 7:30pm.
Show runs from 8:00 pm to 11:30pm, with three short intermissions between sets.

Ticketing

General Admission (Standing): Unallocated standing room.

Sold out - Seated Tickets: Limited availability. If you're attending with a group and want to sit together, contact us ahead of time. Otherwise, please arrive early to secure your preferred spot.

Accessibility
The venue is located downstairs via a set of stairs with a handrail. If you require an alternative access option (is available), please get in touch with Allikins before the event.
Unfortunately, all of our seated options, including those reserved for guests with accessibility needs, are currently sold out. Please feel free to get in touch with us, and we’ll be happy to notify you if additional seating becomes available.

Safety & Content

Trigger warnings will be announced before each performance. We have a strict zero tolerance policy for abusive or discriminatory behavior.

No realistic look weapons (props) will be allowed into the venue.

Contact

Join us at Fringe Bar for ALTAR, a spellbinding drag ritual honouring the turn of the seasons. As day and night stand in perfect balance, witness an evening of witchcraft, blasphemy, mythology, and queer magic brought to life by a fierce coven of drag kings, queens, monsters, and cryptids.

This equinox, we invoke the primal, the divine, and the forbidden. Expect offerings to old gods, sacrificial glamour, and performances steeped in folklore, resistance and radical ritual. ALTAR is a celebration of queer power, transgressive beauty, and the defiance of a world that seeks to burn us at the stake.

Come ready to worship. Come ready to sin.
Bring your rage, your devotion, your offerings, and lay them down at the ALTAR!

description:
B.M.I : Bad Mōmona Individual (Playreading), Created by Īhaka Martyn. Play read by Kaisa Fa'atui

Tired of having no room for self love? Maybe burning 50kgs in 50 minutes will change that.

Join our inspiring fitness guru as he shows the audience how to shed your ego and excess fat. By utilising the power of manifestation, you too can change your pathetic little impulses. In fact, when was the last time you went to the gym? Maybe you should just skip this show and hit the treadmill instead, yeah?

Filled with self-helpless tips, banging tunes and kōrero hōhonu, this playreading will dissect the fraught relationships we have with our tinana, and where those nasty thoughts are really coming from.

Audience care: Contains body image themes and reference to “Fatphobia.”
label: Arts & Theatre

description:
Airhorn Calms Down, Hi [said in a whisper], how are you, are you ready for Airhorn?
PLEASE READ. SHOW WARNING!
This is truly going to be a different Airhorn. Last month was intense, and we love intensity, but felt the need to bring it down. The focus for this month is calm. Chill. Relaxation. This is truly going to be the most gentle Airhorn you have seen.
There will be no flashing lights or threat of epilepsy. There will not be loud noises or gross out humour. There will not be airhorns! This is not a bit. We are sincerely concerned that folks are going to come to think this is a goof and expect the usual madcap, abrasive chaos of our comedy show.
There will be no abrasion. There will be no chaos. We are wanting to do the most experimental show we can do, which in our case is a low-key, cozy, warm-hearted hour of quiet reflection and gentle comedy.This is going to be a soft show for everyone who needs a minute to just breathe. You will laugh, but not enough to hurt your side or upset your neighbor. It will be a laugh held in the liminal space between a deep breath and a long sigh.
For folks in which this amount of calm is too stressful, we will also have a Stimulation Booth (provided by Wattie's) available at any time to provide the classic Airhorn jolt they need.
label: Arts & Theatre

description:
1/2 Price Winter Wednesdays at Te Nukuao Wellington Zoo!, Wrap up warm and enjoy a mid-winter treat with Winter Wednesdays at Te Nukuao Wellington Zoo! Visit the Zoo any Wednesday in August and get 1/2 price standard adult and child entry. You can purchase a ticket at the Zoo or pre-book online for any Wednesday in August and go in the draw to win a Tiger Close Encounter for two!
Come to our winter animal talks to learn how animals adapt over the colder months, and how we help to keep them warm. Many of the animals at the Zoo love the winter season, including Snow Leopard, the Red Pandas, and the Kororā - Little Blue Penguins. You are even more likely to spot these amazing animals during this time, so rug up and explore Te Nukuao Wellington Zoo this winter.
Head to our website for more details!
https://wellingtonzoo.com/winter-wednesdays

description:
Book Launch | It's What He Would've Wanted by Nick Ascroft, Join us at Unity Books Wellington on 3 September to celebrate a new book from Nick Ascroft! The book will be launched by Always Becominging.
Wednesday 3 September, 6pm
Unity Books Wellington
All welcome!
What would he have wanted? As little fuss as possible. But, reading between the lines: a little help. All the latest gossip and complaints. An arse that is not wrong. Opulence. One leap from the rope ladder. The final word.
It’s What He Would’ve Wanted is the sixth book of poetry from the author of the acclaimed The Stupefying. In this hilarious and affecting new work, Nick Ascroft writes of lost friends, new frailties, new braveries, and being stuck in an organ pipe during a recital and not wanting to bother anyone about it. Yes, there are poems of cycling into dead-end utility holes but also poems of trembling resolve and arriving at work as aged as the night sky after completing the morning school drop-off. This is the best collection yet by one of the most exciting and mercurial poets writing in Aotearoa today.
About the author:
Nick Ascroft is the author of five previous poetry collections with Te Herenga Waka University Press, most recently The Stupefying (2022) and Moral Sloth (2019). Living in Thorndon, he is a public servant and the president of Scrabble Wellington.
Cover design by Todd Atticus.
label: Arts & Theatre

description:
Book Launch | All Her Lives by Ingrid Horrocks, Book Launch | All Her Lives by Ingrid Horrocks
Join us to celebrate a new work from Ingrid Horrocks, and her first book of fiction!

🌿 Thursday 9 October, 6pm
🌿 Unity Books Wellington
🌿 Free event – all welcome!

All Her Lives follows women across generations as they resist, nurture and transform. These are lives shaped by love and politics, motherhood and memory, constraint and defiance.

From girls raised in the garden of Plunket founder Truby King, to a queer university student at a mid-2000s Berlin rave, to a mother facing the cost of her son’s climate rebellion, the women of All Her Lives are complex, resilient and deeply human. Shadowing their stories is the early feminist writer Mary Wollstonecraft, whose journey of grief and revolution will become a vessel for what endures – and for finding hope.

Vast and intimate, All Her Lives explores the layered selfhood of women – all that they inherit, sacrifice, imagine and carry forward – and the power found in unravelling and reweaving those selves on their own terms.

'A wonderful collection that swims in and out of women's lives across time, exploring the struggle for freedom and love. I'll be thinking about it for a long time - a book of quiet force.' —Emily Perkins, author of Lioness

Ingrid Horrocks’s books include the memoir Where We Swim (2021), a literary history, Women Wanderers and the Writing of Mobility (2017), and two collections of poetry. Her writing has appeared in Lithub, The Ninth Letter, The Sydney Review of Books, The Spinoff, Landfall, and the Guardian. In 2024 she was the Kaituhi Tarāwhare CNZ Writer in Residence at the International Institute of Modern Letters, and in 2025 she was awarded the Michael King Writers Centre Australian Residency at Varuna. Ingrid lives in Te Whanganui-a-Tara, Wellington, with her partner and twin daughters.

Cover: Sarah Wilkins
label: Arts & Theatre

description:
Book Launch: Hoods Landing by Laura Vincent, Book Launch: Hoods Landing by Laura Vincent
Join Āporo Press at Unity Books for the mystical book launch of ‘Hoods Landing’ by Laura Vincent.

About this Event

Join Āporo Press at Unity Books Wellington on Halloween, 31 October, to celebrate the debut novel by Laura Vincent.

🎃 Friday 31 October, 6pm
🎃 Unity Books Wellington
🎃 All welcome!

Rita considered the dead. Shut her eyes. Rolled their names around her brain. Stacked each person in order like folded laundry, warm and crisp from the sun. She wondered how her name would sound amongst them.

In the rural reaches of Auckland, the women of the eclectic Gordon family gather for Christmas. They may push each other’s buttons, but know precisely when to offer tea (or a tipple). Rita, the 50-year-old baby of the family, is planning to tell them she has cancer. Drifting between past and present, she considers the lives of women in their community and reckons with what it all means for her future and her family.

Featuring elderly lesbians, twins who aren’t twins, and several dogs named Roger, Hoods Landing is about shoddy pasts, ambiguous futures and the imperfect bonds that tie family together.

About the author:

Laura Vincent (Ngāti Māhanga, Ngāpuhi) is an author whose work spans fiction, poetry and food writing. She has written the food blog hungryandfrozen.com since 2007, and her debut cookbook was published by Penguin Random House in 2013. Laura’s poetry has appeared in anthologies published by Āporo Press, Auckland University Press and Muswell Press, and she completed her Master of Creative Writing at Auckland University of Technology in 2022. Born in Waiuku, Laura currently lives in Tāmaki Makaurau. Hoods Landing is her first novel.
label: Arts & Theatre

description:
NZIFF: Twinless, A grieving brother finds an unlikely connection at a support group for siblings who have lost a twin, but his burgeoning bromance threatens to turn into something darker in this uncomfortably sharp-witted comedy.

When his brother is suddenly killed in a car accident, estranged sibling Roman (Dylan O’Brien) suffers the unique pain of being permanently severed from his twin. Inseparable in childhood, the brothers drifted apart as adults, brother Rocky (also O’Brien) living out and proud in Portland while Roman lived a (decidedly hetero) tradie life in hometown Idaho. It seems he’ll never have the chance to work through his complicated feelings towards his twin until stumbling upon a bereavement group for just such a purpose.

There he meets Dennis (James Sweeney). Neurotic, sarcastic, gay, he’s the opposite that attracts as the pair bond over trauma and a deep need for attachment. They quickly become each other’s emotional support twin-surrogate, on call for late night grocery trips, afterwork bitch sessions, and road trip singalongs. But odd couple bliss can’t last, as Dennis has more than friendship in mind, Roman grapples with explosive anger issues, and dark secrets inevitably come to light.

Sweeny’s sophomore effort as writer, director, and co-star walks an entertaining balance between discomfort and hilarity. With finely calibrated performances from both leads, Twinless is witty, warped, and surprisingly warm hearted. — Adrian Hatwell
label: Film & Media

Join Āporo Press at Unity Books Wellington on Halloween, 31 October, to celebrate the debut novel by Laura Vincent.

🎃 Friday 31 October, 6pm
🎃 Unity Books Wellington
🎃 All welcome!

Rita considered the dead. Shut her eyes. Rolled their names around her brain. Stacked each person in order like folded laundry, warm and crisp from the sun. She wondered how her name would sound amongst them.

In the rural reaches of Auckland, the women of the eclectic Gordon family gather for Christmas. They may push each other’s buttons, but know precisely when to offer tea (or a tipple). Rita, the 50-year-old baby of the family, is planning to tell them she has cancer. Drifting between past and present, she considers the lives of women in their community and reckons with what it all means for her future and her family.

Featuring elderly lesbians, twins who aren’t twins, and several dogs named Roger, Hoods Landing is about shoddy pasts, ambiguous futures and the imperfect bonds that tie family together.

About the author:

Laura Vincent (Ngāti Māhanga, Ngāpuhi) is an author whose work spans fiction, poetry and food writing. She has written the food blog hungryandfrozen.com since 2007, and her debut cookbook was published by Penguin Random House in 2013. Laura’s poetry has appeared in anthologies published by Āporo Press, Auckland University Press and Muswell Press, and she completed her Master of Creative Writing at Auckland University of Technology in 2022. Born in Waiuku, Laura currently lives in Tāmaki Makaurau. Hoods Landing is her first novel.

Volunteer Info Evening- 2/57 Willis Street, Are you ready to make waves in conservation?
Join Mountains to Sea Wellington on our journey to restore and protect our marine and freshwater environments.
This information evening will give anyone interested in volunteering with us an opportunity to hear all about our volunteer programme and meet the MTSW crew.
There are lots of ways you can help us at MTSW! Are you into photography? Do you make a mean cuppa? Love to snorkel? Love to talk about marine critters? Nau mai, haere mai! We’d love your help! In return, we promise you a summer of adventure and fun times.
You're welcome to join us anytime from 5pm, there will be a short presentation at 5.15pm, followed by drinks and kai. There will be Mountains to Sea Wellington Staff onsite, as well as some of our current volunteers who'll be able to give you the inside word on what it's like to volunteer with us!

description:
Cringeworthy: The 90's, Cringeworthy – 90s!
A high-octane explosion of ‘90s nostalgia!
Written and devised by Andrea Sanders
Produced by Beatgirl Productions
Starring Andrea Sanders, Devon Neiman, Jared Pallesen and Emma Katene
Following the success of Cringeworthy ’60s, ’70s and ’80s, this show pays homage to NZ music and culture in the last decade of the 20th century. Expect a ‘rad’ mix of local and international hits delivered with snappy dance moves, scintillating vocals and a generous dollop of cheesy comedy.
The 90s was a decade bursting with diverse musical genres, from boy bands and girl groups to MMMBop and hip hop, the swing revival (Mambo No. 5), country (Achy Breaky Heart), The Macarena and re-releases of iconic hits such as To Sir With Love, Silly Love Songs, Unchained Melody and Get Down on It (can you dig it??).
On the local scene, legends such as Crowded House, Dave Dobbyn, The Exponents, Margaret Urlich, Supergroove, True Bliss, Ardijah, South Side of Bombay and The Chills gave us heavenly pop hits that have become Kiwi classics.
In some ‘fly’ outfits, Cringeworthy – the ’90s packages the hits of the decade (including Can’t Touch This, Weather With You, Love Shack and How Bizarre) with some unforgettable fashion trends including flannel shirts, baggy jeans, tracksuits and chokers. These energetic styles are woven together with a witty narrative reflecting the lifestyle, news events and culture of the time – smelling like Teen Spirit!
What’s the time Mr Wolf? Time to grab your ticket to ride this retro rollercoaster! Nostalgia invites you to relive a decade that still resonates today. Get ready to party like its 1999!
label: Arts & Theatre

description:
Roll For Romance (AGE 25- 39), Roll For Romance (AGE 25- 39)

Single? We have got you!



Highlights:

This unique event adds a playful twist to speed dating, allowing singles to connect through fun and games.
Enjoy simple board games like Giant Jenga, perfect for breaking the ice – even if you’re new to games!
Skip the awkward small talk and see how people interact in a relaxed, group setting. Match with someone and get connected for a second date.


You’ll start the night in mixed-gender groups and rotate around to see people of the opposite gender.



Feeling a bit shy? You’ll stay with your same-gendered group through the night, so bring a friend along for the ride!



Drinks are provided, and we have nibbles to keep you fueled. Because, let’s face it, gaming is thirsty work!





After the games wrap up, feel free to hang out with your new acquaintances till 9.15 and play other games.

A match form will be sent out the following day, and we’ll connect you with your matches in the coming days.

Perfect for singles looking to mix fun with the chance to meet someone special.





Recommended age 25-39.

Book now!



Not your vibe? Check out our other upcoming events on our website!
By purchasing a ticket you agree to our Privacy Policy & Terms & Conditions.



** If your gender is showing as sold out, join the waitlist! You’ll get a notification if there are cancellations or additional tickets released!

description:
Techno Taster, Techno Taster
This year for the first of our annual pre-parties we’ve gone around the country to gather a lineup of creators working at the intersections of techno, delving into influences from bass, breaks, psychedelia, club music and beyond, all underpinned by elements of dance music's most enduring genre.

We believe each one of these acts is currently pushing the needle forward for underground club culture in Aotearoa, and are thrilled to host them all together at Valhalla to push their vision across the almighty Third Eye Hi-Fi soundsystem.


ELI HØFF — Abyssal Soundworks / PHTM

Producer and DJ, Eli is undoubtedly at the forefront of Aotearoa’s underground dance scene.
Those who have kept their ears tuned to the innovative underground have no doubt stumbled upon the tribalistic, psychedelic, and focused sounds emanating from the mind of Auckland-based producer Eli Høff. With a string of releases on Berlin-based PHTM, Tāmaki Makaurau-based Gypnotica, and an impressive catalog of self-releases, he consistently showcases his singular and original interpretation of dance music.

Instagram.com/e.li
elihoff.bandcamp.com
abyssalsoundworks.bandcamp.com


HUNTER — Hang the Saints / Haven

Raised in Kaikōura, Aotearoa, Hunter's dark and atmospheric sound often contrasts the beautiful environment she grew up in. Her direct approach to techno draws influence from heavy percussion, bold rhythm and industrial soundscapes. After spending two years finding inspiration in clubs overseas, she has returned to Ōtautahi with a refined style that’s ready to make people dance. As the co-founder of “Hang The Saints” and resident of “Haven”, Hunter is all about creating safe, inclusive spaces for people to connect through the music she loves.

https://www.instagram.com/sspoonsnake/
https://soundcloud.com/hunter-mccrory-334790608
https://on.soundcloud.com/bC3qeA6pUxBoMo7P9


LUDUS & RIZZO — Tonic Collective

Tonic Collective is the recent endeavour of Ludus and Rizzo, inspired by the people, places and spaces of their experience touring China with BIRDPARTY and Vera Ellen. Both acts are individually known for their versatile and innovative sound, bringing a wide range of influences and inspirations to the dancefloor. In the short time since establishing the collective, they’ve already hosted Kaishandao and Bone Chapel, established a space, and debuted a monthly radio show on Mouthfull that explores sound from across the genre spectrum, both in the club and out.

https://www.instagram.com/ludus.etc/
https://www.instagram.com/alicerizzoofficial
https://www.instagram.com/tonic.collective/
https://soundcloud.com/l-s-rizzo/416life-support-cl1n1c-chengdu
https://soundcloud.com/racquetclub-info/mix-series-016-ludus


SHLI — Echo Train Records / Warehouse Rave / Holding Hands

Shli is the alias of Ōtautahi-via-Pōneke DJ and Producer Tim Ward. Steadily releasing works over recent years through local labels like Echo Train and the Big Fresh Collective, he is carving out a sound of his own.

Stitching together infectious rhythms layered over low-end pressure, Shli’s sets draw influence from across the hardcore continuum and beyond. Creating dancefloor moments from trippy rhythmic states to unleashing sheer bass weight.

https://www.instagram.com/____shli/
https://echotrainer.bandcamp.com/album/ech009-bracing-set-pace-u-dont
https://soundcloud.com/1shli

Field Trip Presents - Pitch Ya Pal, Field Trip Presents - Pitch Ya Pal
Hosted by the fabulous Kita Mean, winner of RuPaul’s Drag Race Down Under, this hilarious event sees ten friends give 4-minute presentations on why you should date their bestie.

HOW IT WORKS
If you want to Pitch Ya Pal: Submit a short, creative pitch deck. If selected, you’ll present it live on stage to a crowd of (mostly) singles.

Come Watch the Magic: Whether you’re pitching or just along for the ride, expect a night full of laughs and potential right swipes in real life.

See Someone You Fancy? Scan the QR on your table and submit an online dating form. Here’s the twist, it goes to their bestie to decide if you’d be a good match.

After the Pitches: It might only be 8:30, but we’re still calling it an after party. The DJ takes over, the lights shift, and now’s your moment to move, mingle, and see what happens next.

FOR ALL THE DETAILS VISIT

Friday Laughs with Lesa Macleod-Whiting and El Jaguar, Saturday Laughs at the Royal Hotel brings top comedy talent to the heart of Featherston

This month's show features -
El Jaguar
Canadian comedy act El Jaguar is coming to wrestle his way into hilarity. From Canada, to New Zealand, and throughout Australia, El Jaguar is making a name for himself on the comedy scene using only his fast wits and tight lycra.
From the dusty streets of central America, rising triumphant as the luchador everyone wanted to be in the World Wrestling Federation circa 1990, then into obscurity: El Jaguar is making a comeback… and it’s going to be hilarious.

And MC Lesa Macleod-Whiting - 2025 Billy T Award nominee
Lesa is a Wellington-based writer, improviser and comedian. She has been a regular on the Wellington improv scene since 2016 and began doing stand-up in July 2020, going on to nab the Runner Up spot at the Wellington Raw Comedy Quest. She has a penchant for characters, accents and fast-paced silliness.
Winner – Best Newcomer – 2020 Wellington Comedy Awards Nominated – Best Newcomer (Lower North Island) – 2020 NZ Comedy Guild Awards

He has had sold out season’s at The New International Comedy Festival and has won awards for Best Show and in 2010 he won the supreme Festival Award The Fred for outstanding artistic achievement.
Before sweeping the New Zealand International Comedy Festival his show ”Wilson Dixon’s American Dream” played to rave reviews at the Edinburgh Fringe and Melbourne International Comedy Festival. description:
George Fenn is: Sexy Ghost Boy (Pōneke), Begin with a circle. Work your way up, slowly. Bravely. The Macarena happens to completion. Scream.

This is how you summon Sexy Ghost Boy, the award winning and hilariously f***able spirit, haunting Pōneke this October.

The show dissects the unspoken rituals and micro neurosis we have around Sex and the presentation of ourselves as sexual agents. Using Clown and Burlesque this wordless performance inspires the audience to heroically rebel against insecurity. Described by witnesses as a hot mess mash up of Mr Bean and Marina Abramović, this show has split the sides of audiences across New Zealand.

-Organised Chaos Award / Auckland Fringe 2024
-Bizarre and Charming Award / Hasting Fringe 2024
-Nominated for Outstanding Performer / Dunedin Fringe 2025

Tickets $30 waged / $20 unwaged.

The show is strictly R18. It contains sexual themes and nudity up to underwear.

Creative team:
George Fenn (he/she/they) is a genre bending comedy theatre maker based in New Zealand who specializes in audience interaction. Their passion is inspired in opposition to the coercive trends of Comedic Interaction, and prioritises negotiating audience’s boundaries and building experiences where power is exchanged and humor is shared.

Anne Cunliffe (she/her) is an emerging producer and comedy nerd who is using the skills learned during her decade long public servant career to excel in Arts Management.

description:
GOMIL (Grumpy Old Man In Lycra), GOMIL (Grumpy Old Man In Lycra)
The Lycra is back: GOMIL – the hilarious new sequel to MAMIL hits the road across New Zealand!

One of New Zealand’s biggest theatrical success stories is back in the saddle! Following the phenomenal popularity of MAMIL (Middle Aged Man in Lycra), which played to over 70,000 people across the country, comes its laugh-out-loud sequel: GOMIL – Grumpy Old Man in Lycra. And this time, it’s going national.

From the comedic genius of writer and director Gregory Cooper (MAMIL, That Bloody Woman) and starring Kiwi acting royalty Mark Hadlow ONZM (King Kong, The Hobbit, SNAG), GOMIL is primed to bring a fresh wave of laughter, Lycra, and life’s mid-life absurdities to 14 cities throughout New Zealand in a major national tour kicking off this September.

After a critically acclaimed, sold-out debut season in Ōtautahi Christchurch, GOMIL is shifting gears and going full speed ahead across Aotearoa. Audiences who laughed (and winced) along with the unforgettable antics in MAMIL will now follow the journey of our favourite cyclist as he faces a new life stage: grumpier, greyer, and still clad in way too much Lycra.

Hadlow, one of the country’s most beloved performers, reprises his role with impeccable comic timing and emotional depth, bringing to life a story that’s not only hilarious, but also touching, timely, and unashamedly relatable.

Whether you’re a weekend warrior, a reluctant spouse, or just someone who enjoys watching others sweat the small (and stretchy) stuff, GOMIL is a must-see. This show digs deep into the world of ageing men, fragile egos, friendship, family, and the undeniable need to keep moving—no matter how creaky your knees may be.

Get ready to laugh, reflect, and maybe even wince in recognition as GOMIL pedals its way across the country this spring. It’s more than a show—it’s a celebration of growing older (and slightly wider) with humour, heart, and a healthy dose of spandex.

Don’t miss the next chapter in this iconic Kiwi comedy saga. GOMIL is coming to a theatre near you—lycra, laughter and all.
label: Arts & Theatre

description:
George Fenn is: Sexy Ghost Boy, Sexy Ghost Boy is a wordless interactive comedy that came from the challenge to make work exploring consent without using words. Thematically this show is a celebration of the micro-neurosis and little rituals we have around sex and appearing sexy. It is an uplifting and exciting show, which is satirical in its burlesque and invigorating through its clown. It is very, very funny.
The performer’s approach to interaction and participation is gentle, with a focus on ensuring the audience is enthusiastic consenting to each action. George Fenn is an interactive theatre comedian with decade of experience. This is not an experimental show. This is a weird show. A very good, weird show.

Official and unofficial praise Sexy Ghost Boy:
Organised Chaos Award at Auckland Fringe / 2024
Bizarre and Charming Award / Hasting Fringe Festival 2024
Nominated for Outstanding Performer / Dunedin Fringe 2025
“A theatrical alchemist, Fenn has the rare talent to create something utterly ridiculous yet very clever…he worms his way into our brains making it crazy, yet safe. There’s an element of consent in the interaction that is miles away from the experience of sitting in the front row of some stand-ups.” - Rosheen Fitzgerald, Theatreview
"but we both feel so… I don’t even know how to describe it. I feel like I’m floating while simultaneously feeling grounded, I’m ecstatic while also very chill. Maybe it’s the full moon, or maybe I’m just a little bit possessed by the Sexy Ghost Boy." - Laura Ferguson, Art Murmurs
"... Like Mr. Bean, but Sexy." - Audience member
"What the **** that was incredible." - Audience member
The show is strictly R18. It contains sexual themes and nudity up to underwear.
label: Arts & Theatre

description:
Gloria, Witness a show in honour of the renowned choreographer and dancer, Douglas Wright. The New Zealand Dance Company and Co3 Contemporary Dance Australia will restage his masterpiece, ‘Gloria’. Set to Vivaldi's legendary score, performed live by the New Zealand Symphony Orchestra and Voices New Zealand. A celebration of life, dancers will fly, twist, and turn among the grandeur of the historic St James Theatre.
‘Gloria’ was originally performed at the 1992 Aotearoa New Zealand Festival of the Arts. This contemporary trans-Tasman collaboration honours one of Aotearoa's most prolific dance talents. Producing more than 30 major touring works in his life and dancing across the globe, Douglas Wright was a celebrated performer and creative until his death in 2018.
The evening will also feature two new creations. ‘A Moving Portrait’ by Raewyn Hill is an intimate, meditative reflection on ageing and grace. ‘Lament’ by Moss Te Ururangi Patterson will take audiences on a powerful journey through memory and resilience. The performance honours the whakapapa of contemporary dance in Aotearoa.
‘Gloria’ is exclusive to Wellington. It's presented as part of the Aotearoa New Zealand Festival of the Arts 2026.
label: Arts & Theatre

description:
GOMIL (Grumpy Old Man In Lycra), GOMIL (Grumpy Old Man In Lycra)
The Lycra is back: GOMIL – the hilarious new sequel to MAMIL hits the road across New Zealand!

One of New Zealand’s biggest theatrical success stories is back in the saddle! Following the phenomenal popularity of MAMIL (Middle Aged Man in Lycra), which played to over 70,000 people across the country, comes its laugh-out-loud sequel: GOMIL – Grumpy Old Man in Lycra. And this time, it’s going national.

From the comedic genius of writer and director Gregory Cooper (MAMIL, That Bloody Woman) and starring Kiwi acting royalty Mark Hadlow ONZM (King Kong, The Hobbit, SNAG), GOMIL is primed to bring a fresh wave of laughter, Lycra, and life’s mid-life absurdities to 14 cities throughout New Zealand in a major national tour kicking off this September.

After a critically acclaimed, sold-out debut season in Ōtautahi Christchurch, GOMIL is shifting gears and going full speed ahead across Aotearoa. Audiences who laughed (and winced) along with the unforgettable antics in MAMIL will now follow the journey of our favourite cyclist as he faces a new life stage: grumpier, greyer, and still clad in way too much Lycra.

Hadlow, one of the country’s most beloved performers, reprises his role with impeccable comic timing and emotional depth, bringing to life a story that’s not only hilarious, but also touching, timely, and unashamedly relatable.

Whether you’re a weekend warrior, a reluctant spouse, or just someone who enjoys watching others sweat the small (and stretchy) stuff, GOMIL is a must-see. This show digs deep into the world of ageing men, fragile egos, friendship, family, and the undeniable need to keep moving—no matter how creaky your knees may be.

Get ready to laugh, reflect, and maybe even wince in recognition as GOMIL pedals its way across the country this spring. It’s more than a show—it’s a celebration of growing older (and slightly wider) with humour, heart, and a healthy dose of spandex.

Don’t miss the next chapter in this iconic Kiwi comedy saga. GOMIL is coming to a theatre near you—lycra, laughter and all.
label: Arts & Theatre

description:
John Bishop | Wellington, John Bishop | Wellington
Comedy superstar John Bishop is set to return to Australia & New Zealand with his new show 25 Years Of Stand Up, to celebrate his incredible 25-year career.

John Bishop said: “I can’t believe that next year it will be 25 years since I first performed at the Frog and Bucket in Manchester. It’s been a rollercoaster! And I can’t thank the fans enough who have supported me all the way. I really hope you can come and celebrate with me.”

John has achieved huge success with a number of his own comedy, entertainment and documentary TV shows including: ‘John Bishop’s Australia’, ‘John Bishop’s Britain’; ‘John Bishop’s Only Joking’; ‘The John Bishop Show’ (BBC1); ‘The John
Bishop Christmas Show’ and ‘John Bishop’s Gorilla Adventure’, ‘John Bishop’s Ireland’ and four series of the critically acclaimed ‘John Bishop: In Conversation With…’ which saw him chatting one to one with some of the biggest names in entertainment, music and sport. Other TV credits include two series of ’The John Bishop Show’, ‘Doctor Who’ and the documentary John & Joe Bishop: Life After Deaf.

Last year, John starred in the UK & Ireland tour of Mother Goose with Ian McKellen, which included a hugely successful run in London’s West End.

‘John Bishop has taken on the mantle of Britain’s top comic…the funniest two hours you’ll have any time soon’ ★★★★★ Daily Mirror

‘Bishop has funny bones… everything is infused with his startlingly natural personality’ ★★★★The Times
label: Arts & Theatre

description:
Heartbreak Hotel, This one's for the young hearts, the old hearts, and the broken hearts.
Direct from a season at London’s Soho Theatre, Circa Theatre and EBKM are delighted to present a limited season of the Heartbreak Hotel. 11 Shows Only.
‘One of the best productions I’ve seen this year.’
★★★★★ Time Out Melbourne
‘It hijacks your nervous system and fast tracks its way into your soul.’
★★★★ Scotsman
“A brilliant production which I loved”
Suzie Miller, writer of Tony award-winning Prima Facie
Story, science and a synth combine in an exhilarating new play that examines what happens in our bodies when we’re bereft.
From acclaimed Wellington-based theatre company EBKM, who brought their ground-breaking Gravity & Grace to Circa Theatre last year (Production of the Year, Wellington Theatre Awards 2024), Heartbreak Hotel tracks a woman’s broken heart in a wrenching and relatable journey that’s studded with classic break-up songs and razor-sharp observations on the physiology of love.
Featuring award-winning performances from Karin McCracken (Gravity & Grace, Yes Yes Yes) and Circa Theatre mainstay Simon Leary (Blithe Spirit, Gravity & Grace, Transmission Beta), as well as exquisite direction from Eleanor Bishop (Gravity & Grace, Girls and Boys), Heartbreak Hotel is a hilarious, honest take on a universal human experience.
label: Arts & Theatre

description:
Grass Roots, Written and performed by Raureti Ormond.

Grass Roots is a heartfelt and charming musical about the colossal culture of rugby. From club fields to Eden Park, a queer boy embarks on an epic odyssey through the New Zealand Rugby ages. Join him in this historical exploration of takatāpuitanga, masculinity, fatherhood, and what it means to grow up in Aotearoa. Created for rangatahi and whānau, this powerful story speaks to all generations.

This show was created as part of the TAHI Festival 2025 Creative Residency programme, in partnership with Creative NZ and Taki Rua Productions.

Audience Care: Recommended for audiences aged 13+. Contains mild coarse language.
label: Arts & Theatre

description:
Hexaflexagon, Directed by Jim Fishwick

A hexaflexagon is a brightly-coloured six-sided shape that folds in on and out of itself to reveal face upon face upon face.

This show is also a hexaflexagon.

Six brightly-coloured shape-shifting actors fold scenes in on and out of themselves to reveal face upon face upon face. We wear lip gloss and carry a sword and play Super Mario and explore the forest and cry wet tears and eat giant pink-frosted donuts and party until dawn. We’re hexaflexagons. And so are you.

HEXAFLEXAGON is a high-art, high-energy improv show drenched in neon colours and backed by a hyperpop soundtrack. Six actors improvise scenes that are simultaneously very silly and very earnest, angular and amorphous, which weave together and snap apart.

As this show is improvised, we cannot guarantee the presence or absence of specific content or themes beyond what is in the description above. The show may contain mature themes and language, but not gratuitously. The show may contain voluntary audience interaction, such as giving a suggestion for a scene.

Image credit: Kirsty McGuire
label: Arts & Theatre

description:
Is It Off?, Created and performed by Mamaeroa (Mo) Munn

This sold-out Pōneke favourite returns for one night only at Hannah Playhouse!

An oversharer with a splash of OCD, comedian, improviser and playwright Mo Munn was once called “unhinged” by a reviewer - and now she’s made it her whole personality! In her first solo hour, Mo squishes stand up, experimental and improvised comedy together for a rapid-fire whiplash of a show! Think one woman comedy buffet, packed with chaotic jokes, outlandish stories and a touch of spectacle. Fresh from debuting at the NZ International Comedy Fest, and taking home two comedy awards, Is it off? will keep audiences on their toes, delivering a comedy experience more hectic than a high school rave.

“… her show goes off in a very good way. It deserves to travel far and wide, as long as the oven is up for that." - John Smythe, Theatreview

" She jabs and slices at her audience and draws laughs instead of blood.... Thematically it's perfect" - Wellyott

General admission - pay what you can: $8 -$40

description:
It’s Alive!, Follow two young aspiring scientists as they sneak into their mum's secret lab to conduct their Best Experiment Ever — only for things to go horribly wrong, leading to the accidental creation of a puppet! Will the puppet be a friend? Or will they cause chaos that the kids will need to clean up before mum gets home?

Created by Francesca Browne, It's Alive! is brought to you by Improverished, the improvised theatre company behind family friendly shows like Can I Get an Underground Location and a Mythical Creature? and Random Fairytale Generator. Combining theatre, comedy, science, and improvisation, It's Alive! is full of silliness and joy.

All science experiments have been designed with careful consultation with chemists to ensure the safety of the audience.

Designed especially for tamariki ages 5 to 12 and their whānau. We do not recommend this show for children aged 3 and under.

The show may contain voluntary audience interaction, such as giving a suggestion for a scene.
label: Arts & Theatre

description:
Community Agency - a conversation with Markus Luczak-Roesch and Gerhard Reese, Two scholars share their perspectives on Community Agency and discuss the links between the Global environmental and global mental health crises.
  Gerhard Reese
Gerhard Reese works as Associate Professor for Climate Change at Te Herenga Waka - Victoria University Wellington in Aotearoa / New Zealand. Before, he was Professor and head of the Environmental Psychology Research Unit at the University Kaiserslautern-Landau in Germany since 2016. He got his PhD in Psychology from Friedrich Schiller University Jena, Germany, in February 2010. His research focuses on individual, social and systemic catalysts and barriers of pro-environmental behaviour and the nature-health nexus. He attempts and sometimes succeeds to spend more time outdoors than indoors and he still is a serious competitor in Super Mario Kart.
Markus Luczak-Roesch
Markus Luczak-Roesch is Professor of Informatics and the inaugural Chair in Complexity Science at Victoria University of Wellington’s School of Information Management. He is also one of two Co-Directors of Te Pūnaha Matatini, Aotearoa New  Zealand’s Centre of Research Excellence in Complex Systems. He founded and leads the Complexity & Connection Science Lab, an interdisciplinary group developing theories and computational tools to understand how complex systems unfold over time. His research investigates how structure and meaning emerge in systems - from language and brain activity to online communities and the environment - using models that reveal meaningful coincidences and unexpected system-level behaviors.
label: Health & Wellness

description:
Putin’s Russia and Southeast Asia: The Kremlin’s Pivot to Asia and the Impact of the Russia-Ukraine War, Dr Ian Storey will discuss his new book on Russia’s relations with Southeast Asia. The first major study of Russia and Southeast Asia since the end of the Cold War, it traces the dramatic shifts in Moscow’s relations with the region since President Vladimir Putin took power in 2000. Dr Storey assesses the legacy of the Soviet Union, charts the evolution of Putin’s foreign policy and identifies the drivers behind the Kremlin’s ‘Turn to the East’ or Asia pivot. His book also examines Russia’s dialogue partnership with the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) and the development of Moscow’s political, economic and military ties with each of the 11 regional states over the past 25 years. A large part of the book is devoted to Southeast Asia’s responses to Russia’s full-scale invasion of Ukraine in February 2022. At the end of the talk Dr Storey will also provide an update of Russia-Southeast Asia relations in 2025 and how the region views the on-going Russia-Ukraine War.
Dr Ian Storey is a Senior Fellow at the ISEAS-Yusof Ishak Institute, Singapore. He specializes in regional security issues, focusing on Southeast Asia’s relations with the major powers and maritime security, especially the South China Sea dispute. Since joining ISEAS in 2007 he has been the editor of the ISEAS academic journal Contemporary Southeast Asia. Prior to ISEAS, Ian held academic positions at the Asia-Pacific Center for Security Studies, Hawaii and at Deakin University, Australia. Ian received his PhD from the City University of Hong Kong, his Master’s degree from the International University of Japan and his BA (Hons) from the University of Hull, England. He is the author of Putin’s Russia and Southeast Asia: The Kremlin’s Pivot to Asia and the Impact of the Russia-Ukraine War (2025) and Southeast Asia and the Rise of China: The Search for Security (2011)

Ballroom is a safe space created in the 1960's, forged by the Black, Latinx and queer Americans in protest against the racism and queerphobia that they faced from the non-queer community and white queer community. It is a space held to protect trans womxn of colour, so as guests and participants within this culture it is imperative that we all do our best to respect and honour this sacred space. Homophobia, Transphobia, and any discriminatory language and/or beliefs will not be tolerated. Remember to check your privilege at the door.
To learn more about the culture of Ballroom check out this link: 
https://artsandculture.google.com/project/ballroom. 
The HOUSE OF MARAMA honours the whenua in which this event is able to take place on, belonging to the true sovereigns: 
Te Ātiawa iwi. We also stand in solidarity with indigenous peoples across the world facing injustice. 
TOITŪ TE TIRITI
FREE PALESTINE
FREE CONGO
FREE WEST PAPUA
FREE KANAKY
FREE INDIGENOUS PEOPLE EVERYWHERE. 
LAND BACK.
Be sure to check out the growing Wellington Ballroom scene and community by following @houseofmarama and @ova_collective on Instagram.
Please do not hesitate to contact us via houseofmarama@gmail.com or on any of our socials for any questions or concerns you may have.
---------
BALLROOM TERMINOLOGY*
OTA = Open to All, not limited to a specific gender identity/expression, or category style.
SHAKE VS SHAKE = We wanna see you shake that ass, shake that hair, shake those thighs. We want to see why YOU have the best shake.
FACE = Serve FACE, highlighting your structure, eyes, teeth, skin and nose. Makeup allowed.
BODY =The ability to sell your confidence in yourself, specifically through your body (not through sex appeal).
PERFORMANCE = Performing and battling in a style of Vogue (Old Way, New Way, or Vogue Fem).

About Te KuraHuia

Also known as Thee Bad Mana Wahine, Te KuraHuia pours positive energy into her beats to empower rangatahi to chase their dreams and inspire all to love themselves.

description:
Behind the Headlines: Talking Books with Mike McRoberts, Mike McRoberts (Ngāti Kahungunu ki te Wairoa) is one of New Zealand's most respected journalists and broadcasters, with an award-winning career spanning four decades. Join us to hear him talk about the books that have shaped his life at this special fundraising event for Katherine Mansfield House & Garden.

After anchoring Newshub's 6pm bulletin for 20 years and reporting from conflict zones and natural disasters worldwide, Mike is a familiar face in New Zealand homes. His work involves telling other people’s stories, but what stories have influenced him? Books have played an important role in Mike’s life, taking him from student librarian to author of two books himself.

Mike’s latest book, Speaking My Language | Te Kōrero i Tōku Reo, explores his deeply personal journey into Te Reo Māori and Te Ao Māori - captured in his acclaimed documentary, Kia Ora, Good Evening.

The evening will begin with a glass of Hunter’s Wines’ award-winning MiruMiru™ and delicious canapés. A non-alcoholic option will also be available.

This event is being held to raise funds for our Category 1 Historic Place and writer’s museum in Thorndon, which is open six days a week. We offer an annual programme of events and activities designed to encourage creativity and we host school and tour groups to share the life, literature and legacy of Katherine Mansfield.
label: Arts & Theatre

description:
Kotahitanga: Artist Series | Riki Gooch and Bennett Pomana, Kotahitanga: Artist Series | Riki Gooch and Bennett Pomana
Join Te Waka Huia for the final Kotahitanga event featuring a collaborative response to He Kura Toi Tangata from Wellington taonga Riki Gooch and Bennett Pomana.

Be prepared for textured sound and thought gymnastics with Riki on the drums and Bennett on the mic, closing out the series with one epic jam from these two legends.

5:30pm Doors open, bar open
6pm Artist response begins
6:30pm Interval
6:45pm Artist Q&A
7pm Closing Karakia and time to explore He Kura Toi Tangata exhibition
8pm Bar closes, event ends


Te Waka Huia Wellington Museum

Thursday 18 September | 6pm–8pm

Tickets: $25–$35


About Riki Gooch

Dr Riki Neihana Gooch lives in Te Whanganui-a-Tara, Aotearoa. His work spans multiple disciplines, including composition, performance, sound art, production, and academic research. He has led and conducted large-scale ensemble projects, performed in a wide range of collaborative settings, and created work for both recorded and live contexts. His ongoing projects include solo and group performances, conduction ensembles, DJ sets, and sound-based installations. He is also involved in cultural leadership and mentorship roles, holding wānanga and contributing to intergenerational knowledge exchange within the arts.


About Bennett Pomana

Bennett Pomana (Te Aitanga-a-Māhaki, Ngāi Tāmanuhiri) is a musician raised in Upper Hutt, with roots in Tūranganui-a-Kiwa. A longtime contributor to Aotearoa’s hip hop legacy, he has been part of pioneering groups including Upper Hutt Posse and Dam Native. His work is deeply influenced by his Māori identity, drawing inspiration from whakapapa, lived experience, and the ongoing pursuit of justice and expression through sound.


This event has been developed by Te Waka Huia Wellington Museum and is presented in collaboration with our programme partner Kāhui Legal.

description:
George Fenn is: Sexy Ghost Boy, Sexy Ghost Boy is a wordless interactive comedy that came from the challenge to make work exploring consent without using words. Thematically this show is a celebration of the micro-neurosis and little rituals we have around sex and appearing sexy. It is an uplifting and exciting show, which is satirical in its burlesque and invigorating through its clown. It is very, very funny.
The performer’s approach to interaction and participation is gentle, with a focus on ensuring the audience is enthusiastic consenting to each action. George Fenn is an interactive theatre comedian with decade of experience. This is not an experimental show. This is a weird show. A very good, weird show.

Official and unofficial praise Sexy Ghost Boy:
Organised Chaos Award at Auckland Fringe / 2024
Bizarre and Charming Award / Hasting Fringe Festival 2024
Nominated for Outstanding Performer / Dunedin Fringe 2025
“A theatrical alchemist, Fenn has the rare talent to create something utterly ridiculous yet very clever…he worms his way into our brains making it crazy, yet safe. There’s an element of consent in the interaction that is miles away from the experience of sitting in the front row of some stand-ups.” - Rosheen Fitzgerald, Theatreview
"but we both feel so… I don’t even know how to describe it. I feel like I’m floating while simultaneously feeling grounded, I’m ecstatic while also very chill. Maybe it’s the full moon, or maybe I’m just a little bit possessed by the Sexy Ghost Boy." - Laura Ferguson, Art Murmurs
"... Like Mr. Bean, but Sexy." - Audience member
"What the **** that was incredible." - Audience member
The show is strictly R18. It contains sexual themes and nudity up to underwear.
label: Arts & Theatre

description:
Lads Lads Lads! A Drag King Show, Are you ready for a boisterous band of bros?
A hefty helping of handsome heirs?!
A smorgasbord of sweaty studs?!

description:
A good time to sing!, There is so much going on in the world right now, and that can be overwhelming! Now is a good time to sing. A good time to get together and feel the power of community and connection through singing.
Sing for renewal and hope. Sing for harmony, joy, and inspiration. Sing for healing. Sing to regain your strength and empower others.
Spend the day at the serene sanctuary that is the Home of Compassion in Island Bay and restore yourself.
We will breathe together, listen, create beautiful sounds, let go of our worries, and lift each other up to a sense of fulfillment and joy.
And for the perfect finishing touch, a delicious lunch and morning tea are all included. All you need to do is come along!
Jonathan Berkahn and Lala Simpson have been working together, leading workshops and performing for many years. They are both highly skilled song leaders that lead from the heart and joyfully share their gifts. You will be in safe hands.

description:
The Lunch Society: Spring Edition, Join us for 'The Lunch Society: Spring Edition' , an afternoon of delicious food, meaningful connections, and inspiring conversations to warm the soul.

The Lunch Society is a quarterly ladies’ lunch event designed to bring together women in Wellington for networking, entertainment, and philanthropy.

This event is all about bringing together like-minded individuals to connect, learn, and share in a vibrant and welcoming atmosphere. Expect an engaging guest speaker, valuable networking opportunities, and plenty of moments to inspire you.

Settle in for a beautifully curated experience featuring:

• A powerful keynote by Kristy Grant on New Voices, Fresh Stories: Women Leading Creative Change
• A delicious three-course set menu and a refreshing welcome drink on arrival
• An exclusive goodie bag for every guest + spot prizes
• A chance to give back, with a portion of all ticket sales donated to a charity : KidsCan + Cancer Society

Whether you're a returning guest or joining us for the first time, you’ll be welcomed into a warm, inclusive space that celebrates women, ambition, and community. Come to be inspired, stay to be part of something bigger.

description:
Hātaitai Spring Seed Swap, Keen to get your garden going?
Come along Sat 6 Sept to swap any seeds you don’t need and get a start on the spring planting season.
Don’t know when or how best to sow your seeds? We can show you and get you going!
As always there will be some free tea and coffee (sponsored by Peoples Coffee), maybe even some home baking too!
Bring any:
Spare seeds
Seedlings (aren’t you keen!)
Spare potting mix
Spare seedling trays
Based on a Crop Swap these events aim to connect the community and reduce food & produce waste, and encourage sustainable practices.
WHAT IS CROP SWAP?
It is a wonderful welcoming monthly community gathering to share the abundance from our kitchens and gardens!
Been madly making chutney? Silver beet going crazy? Been collecting flower seeds? Got some foraged berries or a delicious cake to share?
Come along for a kōrero with our friendly community and enjoy free coffee, usually with a scone or muffin that someone has brought along. Everyone is welcome - with or without something to share.
You can find us upstairs at the Hataitai Bowling Club, 157 Hataitai Rd. We gather from 12pm with the event / swap part kicking off at 12:30pm SEE YOU THERE!
(Thanks @CropSwapTeWhanganuiaTara for support and ideas!)

description:
Manage Your Expectations | Circa Theatre, You decide the ending...
Solo performer Eliza Sanders has a simple task: to tell you everything that will happen in the show, so you can decide if you would like to see it. Nothing is ever so simple.
This genre-defying work of dance, theatre, live film, clown and absurd philosophising takes the idea of the ‘trigger warning’ to its absurdist extreme to question how ‘informed’ consent can really be, and asking ‘How much do you really want to know?’
Created and performed by multi-award-winning maverick of the stage, Eliza Sanders, Manage Your Expectations helps us to see the limits of the power to communicate and our failures to say what we mean. Through movement, multimedia, and razor-sharp wit, it examines the impossibility of perfect communication, musing on the influence of context, identity and personal history while creating something beautiful from our collective mess.
"Clever, witty, evocative, subversive, immersive, despairing, poignant, personal and universal" — Deirdre Tarrant, Theatreview, 2024
"Beautifully vulnerable" - Chloe Jaques, Theatreview, 2024
Full of vigour, energy, chaos and a hint of confrontation, Manage Your Expectations is a mind (and body) bending show about how we connect in an increasingly complex world. And you decide the ending…
Content warning: this show contains explicit content, mild coarse language, heavy nudity, themes of abortion and rape.

description:
Monument, Sculpting the future of our nation

“Succession meets Barbie” -Showcase Victoria
Edith Aldridge is the youngest woman to be elected leader of her country. In a lush presidential suite, she has just ninety minutes to get ready for the most monumental day of her life. But things are not going to plan. Due to heavy fog, her team is stuck in another city. Enter Rosie, a twenty-two year old makeup artist from the David Jones counter, sent last minute to help Edith get camera ready.
From very different worlds, these two women, though face to face, do not see eye to eye in this provocative, slick and funny play that is “sparkling fresh and urgently of the now”.

The team that brought you PRIMA FACIE, brings you this dynamic new work that “explores the role that makeup and fashion play in how we perceive and receive women in power.” -review quotes from Arts Hub & Australian Arts Review.


Written by Emily Sheehan
Produced by Kavanah Productions & BRAVE Theatre
Directed by Lyndee-Jane Rutherford

description:
MAMIL 2: GOMIL, MAMIL 2: GOMIL
The Lycra is back: GOMIL – the hilarious new sequel to MAMIL hits the road across New Zealand!

One of New Zealand’s biggest theatrical success stories is back in the saddle! Following the phenomenal popularity of MAMIL (Middle Aged Man in Lycra), which played to over 70,000 people across the country, comes its laugh-out-loud sequel: GOMIL – Grumpy Old Man in Lycra. And this time, it's going national.

From the comedic genius of writer and director Gregory Cooper (MAMIL, That Bloody Woman) and starring Kiwi acting royalty Mark Hadlow ONZM (King Kong, The Hobbit, SNAG), GOMIL is primed to bring a fresh wave of laughter, Lycra, and life’s mid-life absurdities to 14 cities throughout New Zealand in a major national tour kicking off this September.

After a critically acclaimed, sold-out debut season in Ōtautahi Christchurch, GOMIL is shifting gears and going full speed ahead across Aotearoa. Audiences who laughed (and winced) along with the unforgettable antics in MAMIL will now follow the journey of our favourite cyclist as he faces a new life stage: grumpier, greyer, and still clad in way too much Lycra.

Hadlow, one of the country’s most beloved performers, reprises his role with impeccable comic timing and emotional depth, bringing to life a story that’s not only hilarious, but also touching, timely, and unashamedly relatable.

Whether you're a weekend warrior, a reluctant spouse, or just someone who enjoys watching others sweat the small (and stretchy) stuff, GOMIL is a must-see. This show digs deep into the world of ageing men, fragile egos, friendship, family, and the undeniable need to keep moving—no matter how creaky your knees may be.

Get ready to laugh, reflect, and maybe even wince in recognition as GOMIL pedals its way across the country this spring. It’s more than a show—it’s a celebration of growing older (and slightly wider) with humour, heart, and a healthy dose of spandex.

Don’t miss the next chapter in this iconic Kiwi comedy saga. GOMIL is coming to a theatre near you - lycra, laughter and all.

--
For accessibility seating information and wheelchair space bookings please email or call 04)9740535 during office hours.

description:
Messengers, ‘Animals first entered the imagination as messengers and promises,’ John Berger.
Messengers explores the enduring gaze shared between humans and other animals. The exhibition title is inspired by a line from John Berger’s seminal 1977 essay ‘Why Look at Animals?’ Berger argued that the relationship between humans and animals – ‘our unspeaking companionship’ – has been transformed by capitalism.
Messengers brings together historical and contemporary ways of looking at animals in photography and art. It features archival photographs from the National Library and Alexander Turnbull Collections, first taken by newspaper photographers in the mid twentieth century. The images capture everything from the polar bears once housed in Wellington Zoo, to an elderly gentleman standing amongst the life size concrete animal sculptures in his garden. These images are at once tender and loving, sentimental and silly, kind and indifferent.
Messengers places these archival photographs in proximity and conversation with contemporary sculpture and moving image works by four Aotearoa-based artists: Denise Batchelor, Brit Bunkley, Jane Dodd and John Ward Knox. From eerie AI and computer-generated animals to the hypnotic stare of a real live Ruru; from carved wooden godwits you can hold in your hand to ‘hominoid’ brooches, each artist’s work speaks to the ‘unspeaking companionship’ between humanity and other animals.
IMAGE Brit Bunkley, still from Transit, single channel video, 2025

Make. Pull. Carry. Work. Repeat.

Donkeys! Are you not tired? Atomised and alienated? It’s time to lay down your burdens and join us at our retreat. Be among friends. Feel the cool gleam of the moon upon your ears. Find and then heal your inner donkey. A most rare vision awaits.

description:
Mother Tongue- Opening Event, Join us to celebrate the opening of Mother Tongue, opening event 27th of August, Wednesday 5.30pm
The exhibition with run till September 20th
Wednesday to Friday 11-2pm
Weekends 11-4pm
Mother Tongue is a love letter written in paint. Three mixed-race artists from across Te Ika-a-Māui — Carmel Aroha Salmanzadeh, Jessica Miku and Anthony Zemke — trace the echoes of matrilineal language and culture, reaching for words that live in their mothers’ voices but not their own. The show speaks to the intricacies of love, loss, grief and gratitude. To inherit a tongue but not its fluency is to stand at the threshold of intimacy — close enough to hear it, yet unable to fully enter. At its heart are nine paintings that pursue a multifaceted visual language that expresses the artists’ ability (or inability) to connect without language.
To love without saying “I love you” – “ka nui taku aroha ki a koe” / ”دوستت دارم” / “いつもありがとう”
Anthony Zemke (b. 1998, Aotearoa) is an Iranian-Pākehā illustrator and painter based in Tāmaki Makaurau.
Working within a conceptual framework guided by the Baha’i teachings, Eastern mysticism, and Continental philosophy, Zemke’s practice sees abstraction as the ideal vehicle for communicating psychosocial and spiritual realities. His works explore the boundaries of language, the dialectic of human oneness and diversity, and the various dimensions of radical compassion.
Carmel Salmanzadeh (b. 2002, Tāmaki Makaurau) is of Māori, Iranian, Samoan and Chinese descent. He uri tēnei nō Ngāti Hauaa, Waikato, Te Aitanga-a-Hauiti, Ngāti Ira me Ngāti Porou. Salmanzadeh traces links
between the pictorial languages and motifs used in the traditional and indigenous practices of her multiethnic
whakapapa; exploring how visual narratives transcend cultural boundaries. Manifested in large-scale pieces, their works are influenced by the structure and design of Persian carpets, Samoan siapo and Māori taniko.
Jessica Miku (b. 2000, Whangārei) is a Japanese/Pākehā artist based in Te Whanganui-a-Tara. Using the Japanese cultural anthropological concept Hare-Ke, which harmonises the fantastical with the mundane, they produce paintings of imagined female figures within ecological fantasy. These portals of otherworldliness are used to explore notions of tenderness—in heart, soul, and flesh.
Promotional Design by Tamara Irvine
This exhibition will be accompanied by a written work by Yue Pibrow

description:
New Zealand International Comedy Festival, Every May, the capital comes alive with laughter, thanks to the New Zealand International Comedy Festival (NZICF). New Zealand’s homegrown talent shares the stage with some of the world’s most exciting comedians. You could catch a big-name international artist, or discover a new local rising star. 
Since it began in 1993, the aim of the festival has been to champion the craft of comedy so everyone can share a laugh. Every year, a huge group of comedians descend on Wellington from local shores and beyond to deliver three weeks of merriment. 
The festival offers a diverse range of high-quality laughs. It showcases the best of local comedy and gives audiences a taste of some of the world’s best acts. Catch over 100 comics performing at The Opera House, BATS Theatre, Fringe Bar, San Fran, and more.

Enter if it calls you.

Do you know a child who loves craft and making a splash? Join us for a fun family papermaking session!

We’ll be getting our hands wet as we explore the creative world of handmade paper using native harakeke (NZ flax) pulp. You will start off learning the simple skills of how to form a sheet of paper from wet pulp, then develop these skills by making different shapes and sizes, such as sheets, cards, envelopes, and ornaments. Step into a world of elegance and precision at The Art of Ikebana Exhibition, presented by Ikebana Wellington. This two-day showcase celebrates the centuries-old Japanese art of flower arranging, where every stem, leaf, and bloom is placed with care and intention.

Wander through the Begonia House and enjoy a stunning display of spring arrangements that combine natural beauty with artistic expression. Members of Ikebana Wellington, a passionate group connected through the Wellington Sogetsu Teachers’ Association, will be on hand to share their love for this timeless craft.

Free public demonstrations:
Saturday – 11:30am & 1:30pm
Sunday – 1:30pm

Whether you’re an avid gardener, an art lover, or simply curious, this is a chance to slow down, be inspired, and experience the quiet artistry of Ikebana.

This event is part of the Wellington Gardens Te Wā o te Kōanga - Spring Festival 2025. Join us in celebrating spring with free events throughout September. Full line-up on our website.

description:
Pub Choir - Wellington, Aotearoa - Michael Fowler Centre (Average at Best Tour), Pub Choir - Wellington, Aotearoa - Michael Fowler Centre (Average at Best Tour)
Do you have the best singing voice in the world? Unlikely. But do you have the WORST singing voice in the world? EQUALLY UNLIKELY. Your voice is probably average (at best), and at Pub Choir: we think that’s great!

Now in it’s 8th year, Pub Choir is the easiest, funniest, largest music lesson in the world. Created and led by the human rubber band Astrid, be snapped into shape and flicked by her quick humour as she teaches everybody how to make a BRAND NEW PIECE OF ART TOGETHER.

What will happen at the show? An entirely improvised, comedy music lesson, where you are the main attraction. Astrid will teach you one song (yep, just the one) in 3-part harmony, and you will do your best to follow her instructions and not to cry.

Generally, you should prepare yourself to learn something new and to not be a dickhead in public. But what should you specifically prepare? Nothing. It’s not that kind of choir. There’ll be no auditions and no homework. Just bring your mouth and we’ll do the rest.

So come and bring your average-at-best self, and your average-at-best friends, and let’s try to worry less and feel better. Also worth mentioning, Astrid wrote a book, and it’s called Average At Best and signed copies will be available for pre-order purchase with Pub Choir tickets, to be collected at the show. Vocal health depending, Astrid plans to sit at the merch desk and sign these books after every show until her audience grows tired of her.

This show is 18+ Please be aware that this event will be filmed & photographed. By purchasing a ticket and attending this event, you are giving your consent to be filmed & photographed during this event.
