description:
Celebrating 132 years of women’s suffrage — special lunchtime tour and kōrero, Join our kaimahi for a special lunchtime tour and kōrero, highlighting the 1893 Women’s Suffrage Petition | Te Petihana Whakamana Pōti Wahine, which paved the way for women’s suffrage in Aotearoa.
Tour and kōrero
Mark your calendars for 19 September, the anniversary of the 1893 Electoral Act that granted New Zealand women the right to vote in parliamentary elections.
To celebrate Suffrage Day, join a 45-minute kōrero and tour of the 1893 Women’s Suffrage Petition — Te Petihana Whakamana Pōti Wahine.
Tours are open to visitors of all ages (age 6+). Booking is not required.
Please meet at our waka reception desk on the ground floor before the start of the tour.
The ongoing struggle for equal rights
Come along to the National Library to learn about the journey New Zealand women took to gain the right to vote and about the ongoing struggle for equal rights.
View the 1893 petition that led to the creation of the Electoral Act 1893, which was signed into law on 19 September 1893.
Hear stories about wāhine toa like Meri Te Tai Mangakāhia (Te Rarawa) and suffragists Kate Sheppard, Ada Wells and maybe an ancestor of your own.

Come listen in with Kate our Globus Family of Brands representative. She will talk about the offerings they provide for Land touring with their Globus & Cosmos branded Tours as well as River cruising itineraries with their Avalon Waterways Brand, and how they can intertwine well to create exceptional itineraries around the world.
Let's get you inspired for your next travel adventure, chat to your local Travel Expert from our store and enjoy some drinks and nibbles as well.

description:
Creative Futures: Arts, Economy and System Shifts, Join celebrated artist and cultural leader Teremoana Rapley MNZM for a powerful wānanga exploring the role of creativity in shaping local economies and systems. From local identity and wellbeing to economic growth and policy influence, this workshop invites artists, community leaders, and changemakers to reimagine the power of the arts in our region.
Through kōrero and shared storytelling, we’ll unpack how artistic practice can drive systems change and strengthen Lower Hutt's inclusive, culturally rich creative economy, one that reflects indigenous and local voices of communities across Te Awa Kairangi.
Teremoana Rapley MNZM is a pioneering artist, broadcaster, and cultural leader whose work spans music, television, and indigenous creative advocacy. Of Kiribati, Rarotonga, Aitutaki, Mangaia, Cuba, Jamaica, and Suriname descent, she first rose to prominence with Upper Hutt Posse and Moana & the Moahunters. Her practice is rooted in indigenous storytelling, systems change, and mentoring, often acting as a “Matriarchitect” to uplift others. With accolades including the Pacific Music Awards Lifetime Achievement Award and induction into the Aotearoa Music Hall of Fame, Rapley continues to shape Aotearoa’s creative landscape through collaboration, education, and community engagement.
In partnership with Toi Rauwhārangi College of Creative Arts, Massey University.
Light refreshments provided.
label: Community & Culture

description:
The Art of Ikebana exhibition, The Art of Ikebana exhibition
Step into a world of elegance and precision at The Art of Ikebana Exhibition, presented by Ikebana Wellington. This two-day showcase celebrates the centuries-old Japanese art of flower arranging, where every stem, leaf, and bloom is placed with care and intention.

Wander through the Begonia House and enjoy a stunning display of spring arrangements that combine natural beauty with artistic expression. Members of Ikebana Wellington, a passionate group connected through the Wellington Sogetsu Teachers’ Association, will be on hand to share their love for this timeless craft.

Free public demonstrations:
Saturday – 11:30am & 1:30pm
Sunday – 1:30pm

Whether you’re an avid gardener, an art lover, or simply curious, this is a chance to slow down, be inspired, and experience the quiet artistry of Ikebana.

This event is part of the Wellington Gardens Te Wā o te Kōanga - Spring Festival 2025. Join us in celebrating spring with free events throughout September. Full line-up on our website.

description:
Cèilidh Dance Fundraiser for WMC, Get your dancing shoes on and bring the kids! The Wellington Music Centre invites you to join a vibrant and lively evening of traditional Scottish and Irish social dancing, featuring the sensational VicFolk band! This beginner-friendly, all-ages partner dancing event is designed to bring families and the community together for a night of fun, music, and connection, all while supporting the Wellington Music Centre.

Details

12th September 2025
6 - 9pm
St Patrick's Hall, 17 Rongotai Road, Kilbirnie
Ages 0-99
Tickets:
https://www.wellingtonmusiccentre.org.nz/.../wmc-ceili-dance
(door sales will be available)
Activities
Traditional Partner Dancing: Learn and enjoy traditional Scottish and Irish dances, led by the VicFolk caller*, making it perfect for beginners and families.
Live Music: Dance the night away to the energetic and foot-stomping tunes provided by the sensational VicFolk band.
Raffle: Grab a ticket to our raffle for a chance to win fantastic prizes!
Silent Auction: Bid on unique items and experiences donated by local businesses in our silent auction, including tickets to Roxy cinema, and a family pass to Wēta Workshop, with all proceeds supporting the Wellington Music Centre.
Food and Drinks: Food and beverages are available for purchase throughout the evening. This is an alcohol-free event.
*the caller leads the band and calls out instructions for the dancers, usually with a good sense of humour! They make sure everyone is having a great time, especially those who have never attended a cèilidh dance before.

Supporting Wellington Music Centre:
A cèilidh is about more than dancing, it’s a place to enjoy time with your family and connect as a community. At Wellington Music Centre, we are passionate about bringing joyful and affordable musical experiences to kids and families in South and East Wellington. Proceeds from the event will directly benefit the Wellington Music Centre, helping to fund our great programmes, including the Peninsula Family Choir, the Miramar Kids Choir, the Wellington Music Centre Orchestra, our foundational music courses: Music Explorers and the Ukulele Ensemble, and our free twice-a-year community events.
You can read more about the Wellington Music Centre and our fantastic programmes on our website:
https://www.wellingtonmusiccentre.org.nz/

description:
China and the Media Landscape in the Pacific, Over the last decade, the People’s Republic of China has sought to deepen its ties with Pacific Island countries. Beijing’s efforts to cultivate influence in the region have included expanding economic, diplomatic, and security ties with Pacific Island nations, as well as expanding China’s footprint in the region’s media landscape. This talk will present the findings of recent research on China’s efforts to shape reporting, media coverage and narratives in the Pacific Islands and put Beijing’s efforts within the context of the region’s rapidly evolving information landscape.
 About the speakers:
Heidi Holz is a Senior Research Scientist at CNA. For close to two decades, her work has focused on PRC strategic communications, propaganda, and influence efforts. She is a graduate of Georgetown University’s School of Foreign Service, where she received a master’s degree in security studies and a bachelor’s degree in Chinese and East Asian history.
Genevieve Collins is a research specialist in the China Studies program at CNA, where her research focuses on the behaviour of China’s state-run media and its reactions to US military operations and activities.
 Barbara Dreaver (Discussant) has been the Pacific Reporter for TVNZ 1 News since 2002, breaking stories uncovering social and economic issues affecting Pacific people living in New Zealand and the Pacific Islands. In 2020, she created a two-year training programme through Pacific Cooperation Broadcasting Ltd to support new Pacific journalists across the Pacific region. In the 2024 New Years Honours she was awarded an ONZM for services to investigative journalism and Pacific communities.
 About CNA: CNA is a non-profit, non-governmental research and analysis organization dedicated to providing independent and objective analyses to the U.S. government and the public. This talk will build on previous CNA research on China and the Pacific Islands media landscape which you can find at www.cna.org.
label: Government & Politics

description:
Sound Journey - WELLINGTON, Sound Journey - WELLINGTON
This powerful experience is like a soundtrack that is crafted to go with your life.

Something between an ancient ceremony and a movie soundtrack.

Please bring a yoga mat, pillow and blanket. Be prepared to drop into a deep space.
Door sales will be available if there is space. Advanced booking is recommended.

Sika's Sound Journeys are truly unique. They are sonic explorations that feature didgeridoos, drums, flutes, voice and orchestral elements.�A collection of foraged sounds from objects he has recorded in nature, add even more textures. Many of his sounds are completely unrecognisable and abstract. Immersed in this cocoon of abstract sound, we can find ourselves in the most surprising places in our mind. In this timeless realm, beyond the normal limitations of rational reality, anything is possible.

An epic adventure deep inside yourself.

Journey to worlds within worlds on incredible sound waves.

Sika creates a safe space to relax deeply and connect with our inner guidance. This Sound Journey begins and ends with a short guided visualisation.

There will be two journeys with an interval. Most people choose to lie down, so once again, please bring a yoga mat, pillow and blanket to get really comfortable.

A journal is also recommended.
label: Religion & Spirituality

ENM/Poly Speed Dating, Are you looking to meet like-minded people who embrace polyamory? Join us for an exciting evening of Poly Speed Dating! This event is for those who practice or are interested in consensual non-monogamy, offering a safe and inclusive environment to connect and potentially spark new friendships/relationships.

description:
Fluid Art Workshop, Fluid Art Workshop
Spend an evening unwinding with paint, good food, and good company. This beginner-friendly class is designed for everyone—you don’t need to be an artist to enjoy it. All the materials will be ready for you, and you’ll get to explore blacklight-reactive and glow-in-the-dark paints, experimenting with marble and swirl effects to create something completely your own.
Since the paint takes a few days to fully dry, your artwork will stay safely with us—you’ll be able to come back on Sunday to pick it up.
It can get a bit messy, so come in clothes you don’t mind getting paint on, and tie your hair back if it’s long.
After the painting, relax over a wholesome plant-based dinner and dessert, the perfect way to finish a creative and relaxed night.
Meet your host, Alannah
Alannah has been fascinated by blacklight art since she was 15 and has been exploring different mediums to find what really stands out for 20 years. She takes inspiration from all the wonderful artists she encounters in the real world and online. She noticed that this particular type of fluid art hadn't really been done the way she does it, so she has developed her own unique style utilising blacklight reactive and glow-in-the-dark paints. Let her colour your world and explore the possibilities of fluid art together.

FRISKY FORBIDDEN FOREST, FRISKY FORBIDDEN FOREST
FRISKY is celebrating HALLOWEEN a week early this October 18th! Join us for FRISKY FORBIDDEN FOREST - a magical dance party deep in the woods.

Enter the FRISKY FORBIDDEN FOREST, where the magical world comes alive after dark. This dance party invites all creatures to enter the forbidden forest and lose themselves in a night of spellbinding beats and untamed revelry.

THEME & DRESS CODE: “HALLOWEEN” ✨ Magical, Mysterious, and a Little Bit Mischievous ✨
Costumes are mandatory.

DJS: DJ Jimmy Fade (Wellington), DJ Harry K (Brisbane), DJ James Johnson (Auckland)

COAT CHECK: $5 (Please bring your own bag for loose items)

FRISKY Parties are queer, genderqueer, trans & non-binary friendly parties where all are welcome to join in the fun.

Follow us on social media for updates: @djjimmyfade, @wellington_partyboys and @friskyeventsnz

description:
Echoes of Home: A Musical Journey Across Time, Echoes of Home: A Musical Journey Across Time
An emotional musical journey that brings us back to childhood memories and the timeless charm of traditional Vietnamese melodies

About this Event

Event Information
Some days remind us who we are and where we come from — when an entire nation moves as one to honour Independence.
To celebrate the 80th Anniversary of Vietnam’s National Day (2 September), Viet Hub NZ proudly presents
“Echoes of Home – A Musical Across Time”

This free concert is a heartfelt journey through the sounds of Vietnamese history — from nostalgic childhood songs to powerful wartime ballads and modern melodies of pride and hope. All performances will include English subtitles, making it easy for everyone to follow along and connect with the stories.
Whether you’re Vietnamese or simply curious about a different culture, this is a wonderful opportunity to experience the warmth, resilience, and beauty of Vietnam through music and storytelling.



🎁 Raffle with Over $300 in Prizes
Don’t miss our special raffle on the day. Tickets will be available at the venue for $5 and $10. Payment can be made in cash or by bank transfer.

💛 Support Viet Hub NZ
This event is free to attend, but if you believe in what we do and want to help us continue running community workshops, cultural events, and youth-led initiatives — please consider making a donation.
👉 Donate here: https://givealittle.co.nz/cause/viet-hub-nz-rooted-in-culture-powered-by-community
Your koha helps keep our work going, rooted in culture, powered by community.

description:
Father's Day Quiz, Put your general knowledge to the test while supporting a great cause at the Father's Day Quiz!
Join us for a belated celebration of the fathers and father figures in our lives. We welcome everyone to join us, including students and mothers, so make sure to get everyone a ticket.
Date: Monday 8 September
Time: 6:30pm-9pm
Cost: $25 per person, which includes a pizza dinner and a drink
Please bring gold coins for some exciting games to be played throughout the evening.
This event is part of the 2025 Middle School Challenge fundraiser for Blind Low Vision NZ. Our Middle School Leaders have the unique opportunity to sponsor the development and training of a Guide Dog named Cooper, which costs about $25,000. Your generous donations are greatly appreciated and make a significant difference. Once Cooper is fully trained, he will be placed with a visually impaired person for the rest of his working life. We believe that as the Scots Community bands together, your support can change a life.
To learn more or to make a donation, visit our Givealittle page.

description:
Friends of Karori Cemetery - Tragedies Tour (Jan 2026), Come and hear stories of those who met sad, shocking and untimely ends. This tour traverses some of the older parts of the story where historic headstones mark the stories of lives lost too soon: accidents, murder, misadventure and those who fell by their own hand.
This tour contains a number of adult themes and some graphic descriptions so is not suitable for everyone.
Each tour is $10 per person (plus non-refundable booking fee). Children under 12 are free.
Our tour has a maximum capacity of about 15 persons. If there are insufficient tickets remaining for your party, please email us at info@friendsofkaroricemetery.co.nz to check if we can accommodate you.
Please note:
If we have to cancel a tour due to inclement weather or sickness, we will notify you on the day 1 hour before the tour starts by email and on our Facebook page. The booking fee is non-refundable.
This tour is approximately 2 hours long.
Please dress appropriately for the conditions. While we do our best to guide you on a safe walking route, during the winter months the ground can become slippery in places.
Some of our walks require a moderate degree of fitness and are not suited for those with limited mobility.
There is only one toilet which is located by the cemetery office at the main entrance.
If you have purchased tickets for other people can you please pass our tour information on to them as well.
Please meet us at the shelter (shown as the Historic Chapel on the map at the main entrance)
We look forward to welcoming you to Karori Cemetery.

description:
WECG ANNUAL GENERAL MEETING 2025, ANNUAL GENERAL MEETING
Tena Tatou Katoa, Greetings Everyone
A WARM INVITATION TO ALL TO ATTEND THE 2025 AGM OF THE WAIKANAE ESTUARY CARE GROUP INC
Venue: The Otaihanga Boating Club, Makora Rd,
Otaihanga
Date & time: Wednesday 3rd September at 7pm
Speaker Mike Joy - see Bio below

Mike is a Senior Research Fellow and Lecturer in Environmental Science at the School of Geography, Environment and Earth Sciences, Mike’s research includes ecological modelling, freshwater bioassessment, environmental policy, biophysical limits to growth and the role of energy in society. He is publicly outspoken about the decline in freshwater quality and ecosystems, especially the impact of nutrient pollution from intensive dairying on New Zealand's "100% Pure", clean, green image.
Mike is an outspoken advocate for environmental protection in New Zealand and for this has received several awards including an Ecology in Action award from the NZ Ecological Society, the Charles Fleming Award for environmental achievement in 2013 and in 2023 the Callaghan Medal for science communication from the Royal Society of New Zealand. In 2015 he was awarded the Morgan Foundation inaugural River Voice Award and in 2017 the inaugural NZ Universities Critic and Conscience award. His book 'The Fight for Freshwater' is a memoir that provides a rare first hand look at those whose voices question the health and future of our waterways.
The Meeting will conclude with supper and korero

Your job may be a joke, you're probably broke, your love is likely D.O.A., but we've got something to cheer you up.... for Gee Quiz is at it again, this time bringing Friends trivia to Wellington's favourite establishment, 1852, on Saturday 4th October!

With Ashley Hale-Durham, Georgie Sullivan, Jude Madill, and Julie Lamb leading the charge, and a stellar band backing them up, it's bound to be a night of high-energy performances.

An electrifying time warp! The 70s were a golden era for rock, with bands like Journey, Led Zeppelin, Whitesnake, and Deep Purple defining the sound of an entire generation. The idea of powerhouse female vocalists fronting a live band, belting out classics from these legends, is pure magic.

Early bird tickets are just $20, while door sales are $30—so it's definitely worth grabbing them early. This show is going to be an absolute blast, so securing those cheaper tickets ahead of time is a smart move.

description:
From Pemberley to Pipitea: Celebrating Jane Austen's 250th Birthday, From Pemberley to Pipitea: Celebrating Jane Austen's 250th Birthday
Marking 250 years since Austen’s birth this romp through her irreverent Juvenilia is spliced with deliciously pompous gems from Aotearoa’s earliest newspapers.

From the drawing rooms of Georgian England to the dusty streets of Victorian Wellington – the pretensions of polite society never change.

To mark 250 years since the birth of Jane Austen, her wildly funny Juvenilia is brought to life, including The Beautifull Cassandra, The History of England, Love and Friendship – and more.

Between Austen’s sharpest barbs you’ll hear genuine gems from New Zealand’s early newspapers, courtesy of Papers Past: gossip, pomposity, early etiquette advice, and scandalous society mishaps.

The result? A sparkling, one hour romp proving that the absurdities of status, marriage and manners travel across oceans, continents and centuries.

Performed as a series of readings with lightning character swaps, sly narration, and just a hint of scandal, this is Austen as you’ve never heard her: young, bold, and perfectly at home in 19th century Wellington!


Booking is REQUIRED.
Cost: $25
Booking information here: https://wellingtonheritagefestival.co.nz/event/from-pemberley-to-pipitea-celebrating-jane-austens-250th-birthday/


Health & Safety

description:
Antü Mārama, The Undercurrent presents Antu Marama!
Wellington band Antü Mārama brings you the vibrant evocative folk music of Latin America, with traditional tunes and original compositions. From Chile, the UK, New Zealand and the Canary Islands the group's ethos is represented by the name - Antü is the Mapudungún word for sun, while Mārama is the Te reo Māori word for Moon.
The group combines both the life-giving energy and vitality of the sun with the deeper emotions and more reflective energy of the Moon. Antü Mārama is a synthesis of the group's diverse backgrounds and musical experiences, united by a love of playing music, and a desire to share the rich folk tradition of Latin America with a local audience.
Watch them perform here:
https://www.instagram.com/reel/DHcrQc2Rf0O/?igsh=bGV5cHdpeTVqMzB2⁩
Saturday 6th September

description:
Photography - Street and Urban, Street and urban settings provide many opportunities for unique and exciting photographs to be taken. This course shows you how to capture candid and rich street and urban scenes. Includes a Saturday field trip.


Description
Join David of D Jensen photography, as he takes you to the city streets and into urban life to take candid and exciting street photography photos. Street photography candidly captures people in everyday life, taking place in public places. Urban photography is not only limited to photographing people and is concerned with urban scenes and spaces. These two distinct genres naturally complement each other in this fresh course.

Includes an evening field trip.

description:
Futuna Lecture Series 2025: Francis Kéré, The Futuna Lecture Series commenced in 2011 and has been one of the main annual events on the NZ Architectural calendar for the last 14 years. It is the Futuna Chapel Trust’s major fundraiser each year and attracts a large audience of architects, architectural designers, technicians, architecture and design students and interested members of the public. The Trust exists solely on koha/donations as well as financial support from selected sponsors and donors.
Our sponsors, Dulux NZ, APL, Plytech, Warren Trust and the Auckland, Christchurch and Wellington NZIA branches have continued their support for the Futuna Lecture Series 2025.
This year the Trust welcomes three new sponsors being Roofing Industries Limited, AGP and Big River Panels. The additional support of these new sponsors is very much appreciated and ensures that the Futuna Chapel Trust can continue to attract speakers to NZ of a similar calibre to that of the 2025 Futuna Lecture, Francis Kéré.
The Trust takes this opportunity to thank Metalcraft Roofing for their support of the Futuna Lecture Series from 2012 - 2024.
The Trust looks forward to welcoming architects, designers, graduates, students and interested members of the public to attend this event and support the Trust in its work and well as that of the Kéré Foundation.
The Trust will donate 20% of the ticket income to the Kéré Foundation to support the work of Francis Kéré in Gando, Burkina Faso.
The Futuna Trust is a charitable organisation and all funds raised from the Futuna Lecture Series go towards the ongoing care, maintenance and operation of Futuna Chapel and also to support various initiatives undertaken by the Trust. Please register using the ticket types of $10, $15, $25 or $30 GST inclusive. Booking fees are in addition to the ticket prices.
BOOKINGS ARE ESSENTIAL TO ATTEND THIS EVENT
There will be 15 Design CPD points available for NZ registered architects attending the event. Please include your NZRAB registration number when purchasing Architect tickets

description:
Kotahitanga: Artist Series - Tusiata Avia, We are honoured to host acclaimed poet; Tusiata Avia who will be opening Kotahitanga with her response to He Kura Toi Tangata.

Expect nothing less than the power of the word steeped in truth and machete-sharpened wit from this New Zealand Samoan poetry pantheon.

5:30pm Doors open, bar open
6pm Artist response begins
6:30pm Interval
6:45pm Artist Q&A
7pm Closing Karakia and time to explore He Kura Toi Tangata exhibition
8pm Bar closes, event ends



About Tusiata Avia

Tusiata Avia MNZM is a poet, writer and performer. She has published 5 books of poetry, children’s books, short film, radio documentary. Her iconic play Wild Dogs Under My Skirt showed Off-Broadway in 2020, where it won the Fringe Encore Outstanding Production of the Year. Her most recent play, The Savage Coloniser Show won Best New Play at Wellington Theatre Awards 2024. Both plays are based on books of poetry of the same name.

Tusiata was awarded a Member of the New Zealand Order of Merit for services to poetry and in 2024, the Prime Ministers Award for Literary Achievement: Poetry.


This event has been developed by Te Waka Huia Wellington Museum and is presented in collaboration with our programme partner Kāhui Legal.

description:
Georgina Beyer – Diamonds are Forever (Wellington Heritage Festival), Georgina Beyer – Diamonds are Forever (Wellington Heritage Festival)
STARTS: 1pm, SUNDAY 2 NOV

In 2004, Georgina Beyer, the first openly transgender Member of Parliament in the world, famously confronted members of Destiny Church during the Enough Is Enough rally on the grounds of Parliament.

Never a bystander, Georgina faced down the bigots, telling them straight, “Your hatred is totally intolerable!” This was just one of many significant moments that shaped the life of the extraordinary Georgina Beyer.

Born in Wellington, Georgina went on to have an unprecedented local, national and international impact through her commitment to equality and her desire to give everyone the opportunity to reach their full potential in society.

Join us for this special 90-minute walking tour as we pay tribute to the late Georgina (1957–2023) by visiting locations around central Wellington that shaped her journey. Along the way, we’ll honour some of her heroes and listen to first-hand archival audio clips that showcase her humour and resilience.

Georgina’s story is defiantly optimistic – confronting hardship and using her lived experience to change the world for the better.

Time/Date: 1pm, Sunday 2 November 2025

Starts: meet outside St Peters Church, 211 Willis Street

Ends: Vivian Street

Duration: 90 minutes

Cost / Bookings: the tour is free but you do need to register here: https://walktoursnz.wordpress.com/book/

Accessibility information: the tour is on flat public footpaths. Tours are limited to approximately 20 walkers.

Image courtesy of the amazing Kym Strathdee

This tour is part of the amazing Wellington Heritage Festival - https://wellingtonheritagefestival.co.nz

description:
Hogsnort Bulldogs Goodtime Band, Hogsnort Bulldogs Goodtime Band are back with a new show featuring more of their skiffle-pop n’ jug music!

The band, that includes original stars from the sixties and seventies hit bands, Hogsnort Rupert, Bulldogs Allstar Goodtime Band and Dave and the Dynamos, is excited to be back on the Kāpiti coast to perform their energetic and fun-filled show.

Founding members, Dave Luther, Kevin Findlater and Neil Worboys, have collaborated with other great Wellington musicians to develop the “Hogsnort Bulldogs Goodtime Band”. During their two hour show the band perform all their great chart-topping hits from the era including ‘Pretty Girl’, ‘Miss September,’ ‘Aunty Alice Bought Us This’, ‘Everyone Knows’ and ‘Life Begins at Forty’. Other well-known skiffle and jug band songs, blues and popular standards are also featured. After very successful shows across 2023 and 2024, the guys are looking forward to performing once again on the Kāpiti Coast in 2025.

Videos featuring many of the songs they’ll be performing can be viewed on the band’s website: www.hogsnortbulldogs.co.nz and on YouTube.

Support act, Andrew and Kirsten London, are celebrated Kāpiti musicians and entertainers who’ve played everywhere from Dubai to Dannevirke. They have released a number of very successful albums of original material with a humorous focus on the unpredictable nature of day to day life.

--

For accessibility seating information and wheelchair space bookings please email kiaora@teraukura.nz or call 04)9740535 during office hours.

description:
It’s Alive!, Follow two young aspiring scientists as they sneak into their mum's secret lab to conduct their Best Experiment Ever — only for things to go horribly wrong, leading to the accidental creation of a puppet! Will the puppet be a friend? Or will they cause chaos that the kids will need to clean up before mum gets home?

Created by Francesca Browne, It's Alive! is brought to you by Improverished, the improvised theatre company behind family friendly shows like Can I Get an Underground Location and a Mythical Creature? and Random Fairytale Generator. Combining theatre, comedy, science, and improvisation, It's Alive! is full of silliness and joy.

All science experiments have been designed with careful consultation with chemists to ensure the safety of the audience.

Designed especially for tamariki ages 5 to 12 and their whānau. We do not recommend this show for children aged 3 and under.

The show may contain voluntary audience interaction, such as giving a suggestion for a scene.

description:
Kapiti Crop Swap PUKERUA BAY, Kapiti Crop Swap PUKERUA BAY
THIS INVITE IS FOR THE PUKERUA BAY SWAP😁🌱
Everyone is welcome to our CROP SWAP meetings!
1st Saturday of the month – Otaki (1-2pm)
2nd Saturday of the month – Raumati (1-2pm)
3rd Saturday of the month – Pukerua Bay (3-4pm)
4th Saturday of the month – Waikanae (2-3pm)
To be clear, at Crop Swap, we swap more than just crops! We share everything homegrown and homemade: Vegetables, fruits, herbs, plants, seedlings, flowers, seeds, baking, preserves, sauces, jam and all things yummy! You can also bring everything garden and kitchen related like empty containers, tools, labels, planting pots, worm juice, coffee grounds, gardening magazines, cook books, recipes, a SKILL…possibilities are endless.
The key is that this is a cashless event, no koha can offered or accepted.
This is generally how a Crop Swap will run:
3-2.15pm
• People arrive with their crops and put them out on the tables provided.
• You are then free to chat and mingle with your fellow garden enthusiasts, exchange tips, make new friends or just wait until it starts.
3.15-3.45pm
• We conduct a quick briefing outlining the guidelines for swapping.
• If there is not a lot of people, we can listen to anyone who wants to introduce their crop.
• Once everyone has placed their crops we like to do a Karakia to bless the kai. We want to emphasise our values regarding generous giving and mindful taking.
3.45-4pm
• Close out, put away tables and clear the hall.
The meetings will be held regularly on the 2nd Saturday of every month in Raumati and the last Saturday of every month in Waikanae.
Further information:
1. There will be a koha food box for anyone who wants to donate food or seedlings in addition to their swaps. The Crop Swap team will distribute any koha crop and left over crops to local food pantries.
2. If you do not have any crops to swap but need fresh fruit or veges for the next week, you can bring plants, flowers, seedlings, herbs, eggs, preserves, jams, baking, liquid manure, gardening books, magazines, planting containers, sometimes even chooks who need a new home! We want this to be accessible to everyone, especially those who are struggling to put fresh fruit and veges on the table!

description:
Kelburn Community Garden Working Bee - Last Sunday of the Month, Kelburn Community Garden Working Bee - Last Sunday of the Month
Join Kelburn Community Garden and Seeds to Feeds on the last Sunday of every month at 11am for a volunteer working bee.

Tasks may include weeding, spreading mulch, and watering. As the newest community garden in Wellington, we need your help to get off the ground! We'll provide the tools, materials, and instructions. We're a friendly bunch who welcomes any and all to join. No experience needed.

We'll garden rain or shine, but we'll post on Facebook and have someone there at 11am if we need to cancel due to any weather warnings or hazards. Speaking of health and safety - please bring sunscreen, weather-ready clothes, robust shoes, and a water.

Hope to see you there!

description:
Baby Rock & Rhyme, Join us in PlayHQ for these Tuesday sessions.
Baby Rock & Rhyme with Wellington City Libraries & Nōku te Ao Capital E
Ideal for babies and tiny tots, Baby Rock & Rhyme is a weekly drop-in programme for you to spend quality time with your baby through rhymes, fingerplays and stories.
Delivered by an experienced facilitator, you and your baby will have fun exploring their first introduction to literacy and music, set inside the inspiring and ever-changing PlayHQ.
Best suits ages 0-2, Baby Rock & Rhyme is part of our E Tipu E Rea term-time programme.
Free, donations appreciated.
Nōku te Ao Capital E, 4 Queens Wharf. Pram parking and accessible bathrooms available.
Learn more at: https://www.capitale.org.nz/event/baby-rock-n-rhyme/
label: Family Friendly

description:
Kids Rock 4 Palestine, Kids Rock For Palestine
One Day. One Stage. One Cause.
This event is organised by kids in Pōneke to raise funds for kids in Palestine.
Join us for a one-day-only music fundraiser where young voices take centre stage to amplify hope and raise money for children in Palestine.
This isn’t just a concert, it’s a movement. Under-18 musicians, solo artists, and bands (some joined by over-18 allies) are coming together to rock out with purpose, showing that music knows no borders and compassion has no age limit.
These young performers are using their talents to stand in solidarity with kids just like them who are living through unimaginable circumstances.
Organiser Eddie 12: "We see children in Palestine who are being bombed and shot and are starving. We kids want to help. So that is what we are doing."
There will be stalls and crafting available for kids attending - Please come and support so we can raise money for Gaza's families.
100% of proceeds go directly to emergency aid and child-focused relief in Palestine - Convoys of Good and Kiwi Trust for Palestinian Childrens Relief.
Witness the next generation of artists and activists sharing the stage and raising their voices. Please support them with your attendance. Show them young people can make a difference.
Be part of an event where music becomes action, and community becomes change.
Do you want to volunteer to help? Email aotearoa2gaza@gmail.com
ALL UNDER 18s MUST ATTEND WITH A PARENT OR GUARDIAN.
label: Community & Culture

description:
Katherine Mansfield's Thorndon: Guided Walking Tour, Katherine Mansfield's Thorndon: Guided Walking Tour
Part of the Wellington Heritage Festival 2025

"How hard is it to escape from places. However carefully one goes they hold you – you leave little bits of yourself fluttering on the fences – like rags and shreds of your very life.” Katherine Mansfield in a letter to Ida Baker, 1922

Explore the Thorndon that Katherine Mansfield knew and the traces of her legacy that remain in the landscape today. Beginning with an introductory talk, a viewing of the exhibition 75 Tinakori Road: “This marvel had come to the lane” and a hot drink at Katherine Mansfield House & Garden, the guided walking tour will finish at the National Library of New Zealand.

Please note: This is a guided walking tour which will involve approx. 30 minutes of walking on flat ground with frequents stops. Participants are encouraged to wear comfortable shoes and bring appropriate protection from sun and rain. The tour will begin upstairs at Katherine Mansfield House & Garden, if you have accessibility requirements, please see the accessibility information on our website or contact us to discuss.

Bad weather postponement dates: The tour will go ahead if there is light rain, so please bring a raincoat. If there is heavy rain and/or strong winds the Saturday 18 October tour will be postponed to Saturday 25 October; the Thursday 23 October tour will be postponed to Thursday 30 October. Participants will be notified by email and text message (if a mobile number is provided when booking) by 9am on the day of the tour if there is a postponement.

(Image: The Katherine Mansfield Memorial photographed by Charles P S Boyer, c1930s. Wellington City Council Archives, 00157-99)

description: Wellington Jazz Fest: The Seth Boy Trio, Join us at LBQ this Wellington Jazz Festival for an evening with the Seth Boy Trio. Led by Wellington bassist, composer, and bandleader Seth Boy, the trio features Eilish Wilson on alto saxophone and Dillon Butcher on drums. Together, they bring a rich mix of original compositions and fresh interpretations of jazz standards, moving easily between blues, lyrical ballads, and playful bursts of improvisation.

To avoid overcrowding the number of visitors may be limited at busy times to give everyone a chance to appreciate the Museum's collection.

description:
Live & Work in Japan! Q&A Evening with JET Programme Alumni, Have you ever wanted to live and work in Japan?
Come talk
to some people who've done it!
Every year, a diverse range of New Zealanders representing a variety of backgrounds, ages, interests, and cultures start a life-changing adventure in Japan-and next year that could include you!
With applications for the New Zealand JET Programme around the corner, you may have questions about what it's actually like to be sent off to live and teach in Japan for a year or more!
The JET Alumni Association of Wellington, in coordination with The Embassy of Japan, have organised a casual evening event for prospective applicants to ask those questions, and hear some stories to help you make a better decision about if the JET Programme is right for you.
Q&A event details
Date: 6th October 2025
Time: 17:30 - 19:30
Location: Yoshi Sushi & Bento (Press Hall, Willis Street)
Doors open from 5:30, with Q&A starting from 6:00.
Enjoy free
courtesy of Yoshi Sushi & Bento.
(Drinks, including Japanese
will also be available for purchase).
Admission to the event is FREE!
So come along and bring your friends
to this great opportunity to meet a handful of the thousands of Kiwis who've taken part in this programme over the past 40 years
Anyone interested in applying is welcome to attend!

What is the Japan Exchange Teaching (JET) Programme, you ask?
The JET Programme is an overseas employment opportunity to live and work in Japan for a year or more! You could soon head abroad on the adventure of a lifetime, and get paid for it!
Programme criteria includes the following-are you:
A New Zealand citizen?
Already graduated?
Or will have your Bachelor's Degree/Teaching Diploma conferred by early July 2026?
Interested in international activities?
Interested in teaching English to young people and living in Japan?

Positions available:
Assistant Language Teacher (ALT)
ALTs help the Japanese foreign language teachers in class and help prepare teaching materials and class activities. They may assist in English language clubs and other extra-curricular activities. Knowledge of Japanese is not required to be an ALT.
Coordinator for International Relations (CIR)
CIRs work in local government offices and are involved in international activities, which might include editing publications, translation work, advising on the planning and implementation of exchange programmes, and interpreting at international events. A functional knowledge of written and spoken Japanese is required to be a CIR.
For more information about the New Zealand JET Programme, visit:
https://www.nz.emb-japan.go.jp/itpr_en/jet.html
https://www.facebook.com/JETProgrammeNZ/
We hope to see you there!
label: Community & Culture

description:
Letters out Loud 2025 — Part of Friends of the Turnbull Library Public Programme Series, A 1940 newspaper exhorted its readers to ‘write a letter! Take a little chunk of your heart and spread it over some paper; it goes, oh, such a long way!’
Letters out Loud will expose some of those heart-felt issues people addressed on paper in the past. Well-known personalities will read letters from the Alexander Turnbull Library Collections which reveal concerns, among other things:
* the oldest extant Māori letter, written and read by a child
* the ups and downs of farm life
* Yehudi Menuhin in the bath
* a Member of Parliament in love
* on board the sinking Wahine in 1968.
Brought to life by familiar voices
Letters out Loud will be an evening of historical texts brought to life by familiar voices. Come and enjoy an enlivening of the past that has many resonances for today. Speakers include Ngahiwi Apanui- Barr, Una Cruickshank, Tanea Heke, Michele Leggott, David O’Donnell, Karen O’Leary, Trevor Richards, Vaughan Slinn, and Jennifer Ward-Lealand.
Doors open at 5pm for drinks and nibbles, readings begin at 6pm.
Book your tickets
Tickets to this gala fundraising event include a souvenir programme and refreshments.
https://events.humanitix.com/copy-of-letters-out-loud
All profits go to support grants for research at the Alexander Turnbull Library. The Friends of the Turnbull Library (FOTL) offer grants of $20,000 available to scholars whose research involves the use of the collections of the Alexander Turnbull Library.
https://turnbullfriends.org.nz/research-grant/

description:
Mahi Ready Day, Are you job hunting at the moment? Are you fixing up your CV and not sure where to start?
Come along to Mahi Ready Day: A friendly, supportive, community-led event to help you build confidence and practical tools for finding work.
You can drop in any time between 10am and 2pm to chat with one of our helpful facilitators, or listen to a talk about career prepared-ness.
Everyone is welcome!
Timebank members can pay using time credits, and everyone else is welcome to contribute koha.
Workshops & stalls including (keep an eye on this event for more updates and a full programme!)
CV & Cover Letter help
Practice interviews
LinkedIn headshots
Style and clothing advice
Employment red flags to look out for
Online and tech support
Here's what's on (+more to be announced)
Here are some examples of what's on:
10:30am - 11.15am - Talk: Showcasing Your Strengths: Turning Skills and Experience into Employment
Job hunting can feel overwhelming, especially in this very tough market. This will be a relaxed, mana enhancing, practical session where you can ask questions in a safe environment. Angelique has hired people for over 30 years and will share insider tips on how to write a good cover letter, what makes a CV stand out and how to prepare for interviews.
11:30am-12pm - Talk: Employment red flags
Dhilum from Community Law Wellington and Hutt Valley will lead this session on what to look out for when it comes to employment, in particular for people in ethnic and migrant communities - including discrimination, unpaid wages and visa precarity.
12:30pm-1.10pm - Making a Living as a Freelancer
Roger has been working 'portfolio' for many years and prefers the freedom that this style of work provides. He has run workshops & coached 00's of people working in this way originally under the NEWORK Centre banner. He will share some tricks on how to find work & also to juggle several roles simultaneously.
10-11am & 1-2pm - Professional Headshots
Need a new LinkedIn profile pic? Starting a public facing role? Setting up a portfolio? David will be offering professional headshots and can make you feel at ease while taking a great photo of you!
10am-2pm - CV & Cover Letter Support
Get some advice and support on how to make your job application stand out in a crowd.NB: Bring a paper copy of your CV and Cover Letter, or make sure you can access it through your email account on one of our laptops.
10am-2pm - Practice interviews
Come and practice your interview skills with Lisa - a friendly, supportive face with years of experience interviewing job candidates.

description:
Makara Churches and Historic Cottage Tour, Makara Churches and Historic Cottage Tour
The Makara Churches St Matthias and St Patricks date back to the 1800's. Monk Cottage built in 1867 is used as a local musuem for the area.

The churches and cottage will be open over one weekend from 10am till 3pm for people to visit. They are all within walking distance of each other.

Local people will be on site to talk to visitors. The cottage has information about early settlement of the area. St Patricks church has beautiful stained glass windows dedicated to early settlers. St Matthias has a graveyard where the early settlers are buried.


Cost: Koha
Event information here: https://wellingtonheritagefestival.co.nz/event/makara-churches-and-historic-cottage-tour/


Health & Safety:
No particular health and safety issues apart from possibly someone tripping on an entry step. None of the buildings have difficult entryways, only 2 or 3 steps to get inside.

The road outside is quite busy at weekends so care must be taken getting in and out of cars if parked outside the grounds. There is plenty of parking inside the venue area off the road.

description:
Meet Dr Hinemoa Elder – Ara, A Māori Guidebook for the Mind, Come and meet bestselling author Dr Hinemoa Elder as she introduces her new book, Ara: A Māori Guidebook of the Mind.
Dr Hinemoa will be speaking about how her experiences as a psychiatrist, mother, whānau member and descendant have informed her writing.

She’ll share Māori resources for thinking about thinking, and provide much-needed and practical life guidance for our local and global communities.

Hinemoa’s short talk will be followed by a Q&A with the opportunity to meet this inspiring wāhine, ask questions and have her sign your books.

Everyone is welcome at this free event.

We expect this one to be popular, so please RSVP to Hedley's Books if you can to help us manage numbers.
RVSP in store, email sales@hedleysbooks.co.nz or call/text 0272816421.

description:
Tony Lindsay (USA) with Stirling Hern, Tony Lindsay is a GRAMMY award-winning vocalist and was the lead singer for Carlos Santana. He performed with Santana during their most successful period, from 1995 to 2015, including singing on the 30m-seller, Supernatural.
Lindsay has also performed with many other world-leading acts including Steve Winwood, Al Jarreau, and Aretha Franklin.
“We know and we revere Donny Hathaway, Stevie Wonder and Ray Charles. Tony Lindsay is on par with all three of those,” says GRAMMY-winning producer Narada Michael Walden.
Local Wellington favourites Stirling Hern, provide the backing, featuring Michael Stirling (guitar and vocals), Geoffrey Hern (bass and vocals), Deane Hunter (guitar), and Andrew Richardson (drums) with special guests Andre Paris (saxophone), and Damian Forlong (trombone).
This is a one-off chance to get up close to a world-class vocalist, and multi-million selling artist.
Do not miss this one.

description:
Mātai Moana / Mount Crawford Historic Walking Tour, Mātai Moana / Mount Crawford Historic Walking Tour
Explore Māori settlements, one of New Zealand's oldest farms, military fortifications, and prison buildings, on a guided walking tour of Mātai Moana, Miramar.

First settled in the 1350s, Mātai Moana / Mount Crawford has a rich and layered history of Māori settlement and conflict, early agriculture, and farming, military fortifications, and changing prison populations.

Today, it is a predator-free paradise for a thriving native wildlife population, occasional filming site, and much-loved recreation space for locals and visitors alike.

Join Kate Curtis, history educator and creator of the Mātai Moana historic trail map, on a guided walking tour full of stories of life up the hill. The tour will begin outside the now-closed Wellington Prison, and end with a cuppa in the historic Miramar Prison Garden.

Children and on-leash dogs are welcome.


Booking is REQUIRED
Cost: suggested koha $20

The Sunday 19 October session is fully booked.
Booking information here: https://wellingtonheritagefestival.co.nz/event/matai-moana-mount-crawford-historic-walking-tour/


Health & Safety
This is a walking tour with some uneven terrain. A reasonable level of fitness is needed. Please wear comfortable shoes and dress for the weather.

Please wear good shoes and dress for the weather. The tour may be cancelled in bad weather.

description:
NZBW After 5 Wellington 15.10.25, Let’s Party !!
BA5 Wednesday 15th October from 5.30pm for a 6pm start
Chamber of Commerce Level 3 / 15 Daly Street Lower Hutt
Come along and receive a complimentary Mocktail and Nibbles on arrival.
The evening includes how to
Make a fabulous Mocktail (the one your drinking)
Make your table and your home stylish for a party OR Christmas Party
Make great your home storage with an amazing range of homewares.
Your lovely hosts are
Andrea from Botanical Homeware
Carol from Foxy Teas
Lyndal from Little Lace Flower Company
 From Andrea
Discover fun and creative ways to use our decorative tins – from stylish storage solutions to thoughtful, unique gifting ideas. I’ll show you how these beautiful tins can be repurposed for every occasion, turning a simple container into a memorable gift or a charming piece for the home. I’ll offer 10% off for purchases made on the night and I’ll also have a raffle basket of tins. So, every purchase gets a raffle ticket.
From Carol 
Join Carol from Foxy Tea as she shares creative ways to enjoy herbal and fruit teas. Discover how to turn them into refreshing mocktails and explore simple, delicious ideas for using them in your cooking. I’ll offer a 15% discount for purchases on the night.
From Lyndal
In my presentation, I will show how you can create a range of stunning looks for your dinner table that won’t break the bank or involve hours of work. As I demonstrate how to put together each look, I will discuss some general planning and design ‘rules’ that make styling your table a breeze. Throughout the demonstration, I will use décor items that are available to hire from my hire stock - an easy, great value and eco-friendly option for decorating. For everyone attending the presentation, these items will be available for hire at a 30% discount (subject to availability). One lucky person will also win an $80 voucher to spend on décor hire for their next party or event.

- Learn how making your own household plan beforehand will make a positive difference in an emergency.

description:
October Full Moon Drumming, Please remember this is a ZERO WASTE and *NO ALCOHOL* community gathering.
Kia ora!
Full Moon Drumming Wellington is a registered public event with the Wellington City Council. We are a group of humans from all walks of life who gather under the full moon each month to connect through drumming and dance around the fire. This gathering is participatory, that means if you made it to the circle you are part of the circle. As in Africa, there is no audience! Everyone is invited to participate as part of the ‘chorus’ (singing/clapping), dancing, or drumming.
The event is weather permitting, we check the forecast a few days prior and aim to make a decision the day before the event, although this is not possible and sometimes we make the decision on the day. All updates are posted on the event page.
This gathering is entirely run by volunteers, if you'd like to contribute in any way please get in touch.
There are a few things that we need help with:
- FIREWOOD: Please bring dry firewood as a koha, no wood no fire! Please NOTE we DO NOT burn pallets (due to nails) or treated timber. Driftwood from nearby south coast beaches is often abundant, feel free to post or reach out if you have a vehicle and are keen to help gather firewood on the day of the event.
- BEAUTIFYING THE CIRCLE SPACE: Anyone has fairy lights, oil burners, or is keen to make some signs?
NOTE: We hold a fire permit for this event. For safety reasons we don't allow participants to feed the fire, and while is generally okay to roast some marshmallows early in the evening we don't allow the use the fire for cooking or heating food.
This is an **ALCOHOL FREE EVENT**, please help us uphold this kaupapa and remind those who are unaware and might be new to the event. As hosts we are responsible for your safety and we take that responsibility seriously, especially given that the event is authorised through both fire and event permits. Large, public, all ages gatherings require administration and logistics so please respect this and the guidelines provided.
Princess Bay is within Taputeranga Marine Reserve (https://octopus.org.nz/taputeranga-marine-reserve), we are welcomed to gather each month in this special place so let’s all make sure there is NO RUBBISH LEFT BEHIND and that we take care of the space. Dogs are NOT ALLOWED at the gathering - there are Korora (Blue Pinguins) nesting under the rocks nearby and we've had issues with dogs in the past.
Children are welcome at the fire, though, especially after dark, please make sure that all children have adult supervision, that the supervisors are aware of the children they are looking after, and that the children are aware of who is looking after them.
Feel free to bring:
- Your friends.
- Drums or any percussive instrument.
- Warm clothing; jackets and wool blankets are good.
- Something to seat on (otherwise sand is often wet)
- Drinking water.
- Food, tea to share.
- Your lovely selves.
- Fire spinning kit and fuel.
FIRE SPINNERS: Please take all precautionary safety measures and make sure to set up fire-spinning downwind from the fire circle.
PARKING: There's a parking lot a few hundred meters from the fire circle where there's also public toilets. Please also be aware of our neighbors driveway opposite the stairway and do not park directly in front of it.
CARPOOLING: If you don't have a way to get to Princess Bay, or if you have spare seats in your car, feel free to post it on the event page. The less cars driving the better.
Feel free to share the event page and send an event invite to whomever you feel would be interested, not everyone sees the notifications and advertising
label: Community & Culture

description:
Out in the Pool, Our Out in the Pool sessions are regular monthly sessions for all queer, transgender, gender diverse and non-binary folks
We invite the LGBTQI+ community and allies to dive in and swim in a safe and welcoming environment at Keith Spry Pool. These sessions are held on the first Sunday of every month and run 6pm-8pm.
Out in the Pool evenings at Keith Spry have:
Gender neutral changing rooms and bathrooms, as well as our Men's and Women's changing facilities.
Recreation lanes with inflatables, as well as the Dive board open (as staffing allows).
Lane space will be available to swim some lengths or aqua jog, and the teaching pool will be open as staffing allows.
Spa and Sauna available
Music, swimming and good vibes only.
There is no additional cost for these sessions, simply turn up and pay our regular pool entry fees. There is no need to register, just come on down!

description:
Plimmerton Rotary Garden Tour 2025, Join us for a Springtime treat- a tour of ten gardens around the Pauatahanui Harbour.

The gardens are varied, from bijou suburban hideaways to a lifestyle block, and from an 1860s cottage garden to a modern design gem. They are testaments to the care and creativity of their owners.

Included is the iconic Heritage Rose Garden beside St Alban’s church in Pauatahanui, which features legacy and modern rose varieties around the burial ground.

Gardeners will be inspired by the experience - it will be an unforgettable day out.

Times - Gardens are open from 9.30 am to 4.30 pm on both days, except for the Pauatahanui Rose Garden/Burial Ground, which will be closed on Sunday morning until 1 pm.

Garden competition – A prize voted for by entrants for the “Best Garden” for Consultancy Services has been offered by Distinctive Home and Landscapes Limited to the value of $600. Other spot prizes will be drawn at the end of each day for entrants.

Ticket holders:


Note that when ticketing, select the Zone to start at: Camborne, Paremata/Aotea, Whitby, or Pauatahanui.

Preplan your garden tour from the map provided when tickets are issued, and have the plan available on the day.

Note that every effort is made to ensure gardens are as safe as practicable. All gardens are entered at visitors’ risk.

must obtain the garden owner's consent if you wish to take cuttings.

Note that the event will occur wet or fine, pets are not allowed, and no ticket refunds will be available.


This is a Plimmerton Rotary fundraiser for community benefit, and net proceeds will be shared by:


Gillies McIndoe Foundation, founded by Dr Swee Tan, benefits research work in developing accessible life-changing treatment options for brain cancer, vascular birthmarks and keloid scars through the use of affordable repurposed medications. https://www.gmri.org.nz/

“HAROLD” - North Wellington Life Education Trust - visits primary schools with an intriguing mobile classroom, furthering the Education of unique Life Skills for primary school children in the Porirua Johnsonville regions. northwellington@lifeed.org.nz


A special thanks to Titahi Bay Horticultural Society for their early support.
label: Community & Culture

description:
Over the Rainbow, Over the Rainbow
There’s no place like Pōneke.

Queer historian Will Hansen and legendary barman Malcolm Vaughan kōrero the capital’s vibrant LGBTQIA+ nightlife for Wellington Heritage Festival.


About Will

Will Hansen (he/him) is a transgender historian based in Pōneke. He is the recipient of a Judith Binney Trust Writing Award and is currently working on turning his PhD thesis – ‘Queer Activism in Aotearoa, 1961-2013’ into a book. Will is also a trustee of Kawe Mahara Queer Archives Aotearoa.


About Mal

Malcolm Vaughan is a Wellington gay icon. Before the Homosexual Law Reform Act of 1986, Mal worked at a series of bars and late-night haunts in the capital. More than just places to drink, venues like The Dominion, Bamboo Bar, Casper’s, The Dome (to name a few) provided a safe place in the capital for the city’s rainbow community to meet without prejudice. Today, Malcolm alongside husband, Scotty Kennedy ow and run the iconic Cuba Street establishment Scotty & Mal’s Cocktail and Lounge Bar.

Advocates for many LGBTQIA+ causes, they have supported many community initiatives over the years. In 2000 they co-founded the After Life Memorial Trust, now called the Chrissy Wītoko Memorial Trust, which originally provided financial support for AIDS patients of the rainbow community. The Trust continues to provide a wide range of support for the Wellington rainbow community.
label: Community & Culture

description:
Paddy the Wanderer, Paddy the Wanderer
A dog’s eye view of Wellington waterfront history with Wellington Museum Senior Curator, Taonga, Ian Wards.

Bring your canine family member. Dog treats included!

Who was Paddy the Wanderer?

Paddy the Wanderer was a beloved Airdale Terrier known for roaming Wellington waterfront in the 1930s. After many adventures and years of dedication to the city’s maritime community, the Wellington Harbour Board bestowed Paddy the title of “Assistant Night Watchman in Charge of Pirates, Rodents and Smugglers.”

A life-sized statue of Paddy is proudly on display at Wellington Museum and the drinking fountain for dogs and their humans outside of the New Zealand Academy of Fine Arts is also dedicated to him.

Retrace Paddy’s pawprints and fetch fascinating stories with Wellington Museum’s history dog-walk.

Note: please bring socialised/trained dogs only. And don’t forget to BYO doggy-doo bags!

Walk begins at Wellington Museum and ends at Oriental Bay.

Sunday 19 October | 10am–12pm
Dogs go FREE

Tickets:

Adults: $20

Children: $12

Family of 3: $40

Family of 4: $55
label: Community & Culture

description:
Quintessential Quiz for Kaibosh! Mövenpick Hotel Wellington, Gather your friends for a great night out in support of Kaibosh at the beautiful Mövenpick Hotel Wellington in partnership with SKÅL Wellington.
If you're a fan of our Kaibosh Quiz Night for Cheats of the past, the Quintessential Quiz is still for cheats - a glammed-up version!
DATE: Thursday 4 September
TIME: Doors open: 6:00 PM
Quiz starts: 6:30 PM sharp
VENUE: Mövenpick Hotel Wellington, 345 The Terrace (venue generously donated by Mövenpick)
HOST: The evening's MC will be the incredible Erin Rush, VP of NZ Rugby and former Black Fern.
Great prizes for top teams. Awesome raffle prizes to be won

Come along for quizzical fun and fundraising - with all proceeds from the quiz going direct to Kaibosh to help us provide healthy, rescued food to people in need in the Wellington region.
HOW TO ENTER
Teams of 4
$120 per table
Limited tables available – book early via Humanitix! Hit the ticket booking link above
https://events.humanitix.com/quintessential-quiz-for...
Don't worry if you don't have a team yet, we can connect you with others on the night. You can buy an individual ticket at $35.00 pp.
WHAT TO EXPECT - QUIZ FOR CHEATS

Five rounds of 10 questions
Choose your bonus round – earn double points!
It’s a Quiz for Cheats – so you can buy up to 6 correct answers to boost your score!
FOOD & DRINK
Delicious food and drink will be available to purchase throughout the evening.
LOCATION & PARKING
Mövenpick Hotel Wellington is at 345 The Terrace.
There is very limited street parking.

description:
REVELRY - Celebrate Footnote at 40, REVELRY - Celebrate Footnote at 40
Footnote New Zealand Dance are celebrating 40 years of daring, world-class, trailblazing contemporary dance.

40 years of connecting communities, pushing the boundaries, and uplifting Aotearoa’s artists. In 40 years, Footnote New Zealand Dance has created 100 works, and employed 100 company dancers. That’s a lot to celebrate, and we want to celebrate it with you.

Come join us for a night of boisterous festivity and unrestrained merrymaking.

What’s an arts event without a bit of fundraising? Curated just for Revellers, our Silent Auction is packed full of goodies. Bidding is open soon, and will close at the end of the night.

Entertainment for the evening provided by the fabulous Chocolate Box (Vanessa Stacey & Lisa Tomlin)

Bubbles and canapés on arrival. Cash bar serving tipples and treats all evening.

Early Bird tickets available till 14th August!

Speakers include Rebecca Macfie, Tracey McIntosh, Brigitte Bönisch-Brednich and Caroline Mareko
Thursday 11 September
Room RHLT 1
Rutherford House
33 Bunny Street
Wellington
Doors open from 5.30pm, event starts 6pm
Nau mai, haere mai. Public event, no RVSP needed.

This event is supported by the Stout Research Centre for New Zealand Studies. Unity Books will be selling the texts on the night.

description:
Rainbow Elders: Our Aspirations, Our Well-Being, Our Rights - a panel discussion, Rainbow Elders: Our Aspirations, Our Well-Being, Our Rights - a panel discussion
Te Kāhui Tika Tangata Human Rights Commission is proud to host this discussion for International Day of Older Persons in partnership with Kawe Mahara Queer Archives Aotearoa (formerly LAGANZ).

Panelists from the Wellington rainbow community - 𝗠𝗮𝗻𝗶 𝗠𝗶𝘁𝗰𝗵𝗲𝗹𝗹, 𝗞𝗲𝘃𝗶𝗻 𝗛𝗮𝘂𝗻𝘂𝗶 𝗮𝗻𝗱 𝗟𝗮𝗶𝗻𝗲𝘆 𝗖𝗼𝘄𝗮𝗻 - will join Chief Commissioner Dr Stephen Rainbow for the discussion and a brief Q and A session. 🌈🎙️💫

Prudence Walker, Disability Rights Commissioner and Rainbow rights spokesperson will host the panel.

𝗣𝗿𝗲-𝗿𝗲𝗴𝗶𝘀𝘁𝗿𝗮𝘁𝗶𝗼𝗻 𝗶𝘀 𝗿𝗲𝗾𝘂𝗶𝗿𝗲𝗱 𝗳𝗼𝗿 𝘁𝗵𝗶𝘀 𝗳𝗿𝗲𝗲 𝗲𝘃𝗲𝗻𝘁 𝗱𝘂𝗲 𝘁𝗼 𝗹𝗶𝗺𝗶𝘁𝗲𝗱 𝘀𝗲𝗮𝘁𝗶𝗻𝗴. Pre-register here: https://events.humanitix.com/rainbow-elders-our-aspirations-our-well-being-our-rights-a-panel-discussion 🎟️🎟️🎟️

The discussion runs from 10.30am to 11.30am.

NZSL will be available. The venue is accessible.

Light refreshments will be available.

A recording of the discussion may be made available afterwards via the Commission's website.
❤️🧡💛💚💙💜🩷

description:
SS Hikitia Steam Crane Showcase and Ship Tours, SS Hikitia Steam Crane Showcase and Ship Tours
Come see a nearly 100-year-old steam crane in action! The Hikitia and her crew will be operating a floating crane to showcase technology from the age of steam

You may already know the SS Hikitia as one of the world's oldest floating steam cranes, but did you know that the crane still works?

Our dedicated group of volunteers will be undertaking demonstration lifts with Hikitia’s crane and also opening the ship for tours.

Come see what it takes to operate a heavy piece of lifting equipment from the golden era of steam!


Cost: Koha
Event information here: https://wellingtonheritagefestival.co.nz/event/ss-hikitia-steam-crane-showcase-and-ship-tours/


Health & Safety
During operation of the crane there will be no members of the public on board the vessel, an exclusion zone set up around the ship, and a crew member on the wharf side providing commentary about the ship and the operations.

During ship tours, there will be 2 tour guides with each group (maximum of 10 people per group) and a full H&S induction will be undertaken. The ship is equipped with first aid equipment and one of the guides will be first aid trained.

Footnote New Zealand Dance are celebrating 40 years of daring, world-class, trailblazing contemporary dance.

40 years of connecting communities, pushing the boundaries, and uplifting Aotearoa’s artists. In 40 years, Footnote New Zealand Dance has created 100 works, and employed 100 company dancers. That’s a lot to celebrate, and we want to celebrate it with you.

Come join us for a night of boisterous festivity and unrestrained merrymaking.

What’s an arts event without a bit of fundraising? Curated just for Revellers, our Silent Auction is packed full of goodies. Bidding is open soon, and will close at the end of the night.

description:
Site Visit - Wellington Airport Fire Station, Join us for an exclusive behind-the-scenes look at the new Wellington Airport Fire Station, currently under construction by Naylor Love. This purpose-built facility is designed to support future air travel and will enhance the airport’s emergency response capabilities, replacing the existing station on the eastern side of the runway.
📍 Location: Wellington Airport Fire Station, Coutts Street, Rongotai
📅 Date: Friday, 5 September 2025
⏰ Time: 3:30 PM – 4:30 PM (arrive at 3.15pm)
🎟️ Tickets: FREE – but limited to 20 NAWIC members only
🛠️ What You’ll See and Hear About:
Importance Level 4 Building
Challenges of designing and building in an airport environment
Sustainable features of the build
Landscape improvements and viewing areas
💬 Why You Should Come
👷‍♀️ Learn from an active, high-profile infrastructure project
🧯 Gain insights into the unique requirements of an airport fire station build
🤝 Network with fellow NAWIC members and industry professionals
🛠️ See how construction is adapting to new aviation technologies
🦺 PPE requirements (hard hats, hi-vis, glasses, steel-capped boots). We have spare hi-vis, hard-hats and safety glasses available – please advise us in your RSVP if you require any help with this.
This is a NAWIC members-only event with limited capacity — please book your space consciously! 
🙏 A special thank you to Wellington Airport and Naylor Love for generously hosting this site visit and supporting women in construction.
We look forward to seeing you there! 🚒
Please note: NAWIC is a voluntary organisation, committed to its obligations as a PCBU under the Health and Safety at Work Act 2015.   Amongst other things, this requires NAWIC to take all practicable steps to eliminate, isolate or minimize hazards that our event attendees are exposed to. Health and safety is a shared responsibility.

Expect monsters. Expect madness. Expect the unexpected.

label: Arts & Theatre

description:
The Griegol, From Trick of the Light Theatre (The Bookbinder) comes a charming, moving, and wildly inventive work.

After their grandmother passes away, a child suspects they are being pursued by the smoke demon shapeshifter of the old woman’s stories. The Griegol is a dark fantasy in the vein of Spirited Away, for older children and adults. Drawing from the techniques of silent film, it utilises silhouettes, smoke, puppetry, live music, and live animation. With the operation kept in sight, audiences see both the stage effects and how they are made. Combining hi-fi with lo-fi technology, and the mythic with the everyday, The Griegol is a show without words about death, love, and monsters. After winning Director, Composer, and Production of the Year at the 2022 Wellington Theatre Awards, and touring to the USA, The Griegol returns to the Hannah Playhouse this October.

Recommended for ages 7+
Contains references to death and grief
label: Arts & Theatre

description:
Site Visit - Studio of Pacific Architecture - Te Aro Double-Header!, Join us on Wednesday 20 August, for an exclusive NAWIC members-only site tour of two very different but geographically close projects in Te Aro. The National War Memorial and FPC Martin Square are both undergoing major refurbishment - join us for a look behind the scenes!
National War Memorial: Refurbishing a Wellington Icon
Step behind the scaffolding and witness the National War Memorial Project – a complex seismic strengthening project where heritage sensitivity is of utmost importance. With construction works being carried out by Maycroft Construction, join us for the rare opportunity to explore a significant piece of the capital’s cultural fabric.
Known to many as the backdrop of ANZAC Day commemorations, this national memorial is undergoing a meticulous refurbishment to ensure its legacy endures for generations to come.
 What’s Happening On Site:
Seismic strengthening of the tower and bell frame 
Stone remediation to preserve its historic façade
Asphalt roofing works
The real challenge? Balancing modern engineering with heritage preservation. Every upgrade is being carried out with deep respect for the building’s historical significance.

Then, just around the corner, we will move on to another refurbishment project – at a much different scale and for a very different purpose!
 FPC Martin Square: from Workshop to Office Space
Leading industrial design-and-build specialists First Principles Constructors are celebrating seven years of innovation with a bold move - into a brand-new headquarters in central Wellington. Take a look inside the transformation of a former engineering workshop into the new HQ for FPC. With exposed services, raw materials, and an industrial aesthetic, this compact yet clever refurbishment shows how much can be achieved in a small urban footprint. Construction is well underway by Aoraki Construction, with completion coming up in September.
What’s Happening On Site:
•     Structural steel installation, new roofing, cladding, a new concrete mezzanine slab
•     Interior fit-out works
•     Full building services upgrades
 The Details:
🕒 DATE and TIME: Wednesday, 20th August, meet at 2.45pm for a 3.00pm start at the National War Memorial
📍 LOCATION: Meet at the National War Memorial (19 Buckle Street) to explore this site first. We will then walk over to 21 Martin Square as a group, for the next site visit.
🎟️ COST: Free to NAWIC members, with a maximum of 18 people on the tour, so please book your space consciously. Get in quick! You can join NAWIC here.
👷‍♀️PPE: Hard hat, hi-vis, steel-capped boots. (Spare hard-hats/hi-vis are available if required, please make sure you advise us of what you need on your RSVP.)
 🎉 After the site visits, unwind with drinks and nibbles sponsored by First Principles Constructors at a nearby venue (TBC) – a chance to connect, reflect, and chat all things design and construction.
🧡 Huge thanks to Studio of Pacific Architecture, Aoraki Construction, Maycroft Construction, and First Principles Constructors for teaming up to make this event possible.
Please note: NAWIC is a voluntary organisation, committed to its obligations as a PCBU under the Health and Safety at Work Act 2015.   Amongst other things, this requires NAWIC to take all practicable steps to eliminate, isolate or minimize hazards that our event attendees are exposed to. Health and safety is a shared responsibility.

description:
THE GRAND KIKI HOUSE OF MARAMA BALL, The Trailblazing Kiki House of Marama present THE GRAND KIKI HOUSE OF MARAMA BALL 🌙
Proudly supported by OVĀ Collective and Te Papa Tongarewa.
The Grand Kiki House of Marama Ball will celebrate five years of the Kiki House of Marama excellence and the legacy of the growing Wellington Ballroom scene.
Join us for a night of high-energy performances and out-of-this-world fashion as walkers compete for trophies and prizes in a display of Black and Brown queer and trans joy, liberation, and Ballroom* artistry.
With a fabulous line-up of Categories, Judges, Commentators and DJ, including major local and international Ballroom figures, we invite you to wear your best outfits and prepare to finger snap ✨ 🤏 dance 💃 and cheer 🥳 the night away at Te Papa Tongarewa on Sat 4th Oct.
Ballroom Community Walkers & Spectators Ticket Access
Contact our House account on Instagram @houseofmarama or your local Ballroom leaders for the access codes to Ballroom Community Spectators & Walkers tickets.
There is a discount code for Fem Queens FREE access for FQ who are not walking/competing, please contact us or your local leaders for the discount code.
Categories & Themes
Virgin Vogue - A Marama Storm (Treasure)
Bizarre - Nocturnal Creatures of Folklore
Realness (FQ, TM and BQ) - Date Night Under the Moonlight
Hands Performance - Memoirs from Mother Marama
Body (Slim, Thicc and Luscious) - Heavenly Bodies
Butch Queen Vogue Fem - A Marama Storm (Pirates)
Face (FF, MF and GNC) - Beauty of the Blood Moon
OTA Best Dressed - Once in a Blue Moon
Commentator vs. Commentator - Echoes of the Moon
Femme Queen Performance - A Marama Storm (Mermaids)
OTA Runway - The Phases of Marama
House of the Night (no theme)
Judges, Commentators & DJ announcement coming soon...
Please do not hesitate to contact us via houseofmarama@gmail.com or on all social media @houseofmarama for any questions or concerns.
⎯
Ballroom* is a safe space created in the 1960's, forged by the Black, Latinx and queer Americans in protest against the racism and queerphobia that they faced from the non-queer community and white queer community. It is a space held to protect trans womxn of colour, so as guests and participants within this culture it is imperative that we all do our best to respect and honour this sacred space. Homophobia, Transphobia, and any discriminatory language and/or beliefs will not be tolerated. Remember to check your privilege at the door.
To learn more about the culture of Underground Ballroom check out this link: https://artsandculture.google.com/project/ballroom. Be sure to check out the growing Wellington Ballroom scene and community by following @houseofmarama and @ova_collective on Instagram.

description:
Lost Wax in Three Sessions - Hard Wax, Over three sessions create stunning jewellery using the age-old lost wax technique. This is an excellent opportunity to treat yourself to some creative fun!

In weeks one and two you'll learn how to work with jeweller's hard wax to create beautiful textures in metal that can be used to create amazing rings or objects. Your waxes will be sent away for casting in the metal of your choice.

Then there will be a week's break before the third session, to allow time for everyone's waxes to be cast. The third session covers how to trim, clean and finish your casts, turning them into original jewellery ready to wear!

More advanced students can use these sessions to complete projects in a class setting.

Included in the class fee are all your different types of waxes, sandpaper and courier costs.

Not included are the casting and metal costs which vary from student to student depending on what sized ring they want to make and the type of metal you choose. Small castings can cost around $6.65 - $12 and might cost between $7 to $30 in metals depending on if you use red bronze, white bronze or silver.

This class is great for teens and kids over 12 or so. Anyone under 16 must be accompanied by an enrolled parent or caregiver.

description:
VOGELMORN'S BEST QUIZ, Secure a spot and come jump in on a classic, family friendly quiz night at your favourite new local. This will be a reoccurring event on the last Thursday of every second month!
~~~ How it works ~~~
-Pre-register by emailing ordishquiz@gmail.com
-Turn up from 6.30pm for a 7pm start
-Max 6 people per team
-$5 per person, then $30 for a 6 members team (bring cash!)
-We have a maximum number of teams so best to get in quick or try your luck on the night
-Awesome prizes to be won
The bar will be open from 3pm with a great selection of local tap beers, wine and non-alcs. Happy Hour from 3pm to 6pm.
Smoked and Pickled will be dishing up delicious kai to keep your brains switched on! You can book your dinner in advance.
Vogelmorn Bowling Club is not a accessible building
Don't forget to pre-register by email at: ordishquiz@gmail.com
Not quizzing? No stress, we will still be open to the public!
"Vogelmorn Upstairs is not a wheelchair accessible building. There is an accessible
bathroom in the space. This is an all ages venue but those under the age of 16 must be
accompanied by a designated adult after 8pm. The Vogelmorn Precinct is a community
space located in a residential area. With that in mind, the team ask that you be kind to
others' and that when you leave the gig, you do so quietly to avoid disturbing our
neighbours.”
“The Upstairs Bar and Smoked and Pickled Restaurant will be open from 3pm, to book a
table for pre-show kai email Alice at smokednpickled@gmail.com”

Tours of New Art Centre at 3-6 Market Lane, We’re excited to announce tours of the new Toi Pōneke Arts Centre whare at 3-6 Market Lane, Wellington. We will be occupying a portion of the building on the corner of Cable Street and Market Lane.
Before our new premises undergo a refit, we invite you to tour the interior of the building and see where the artist studios, arts offices and workshop space will be located.
Tours are available on Tues 2 and Wed 3 Sept at 10am, 11am, 12noon, 1pm, 2pm and 3pm.
The re-imagined Arts Centre Moemoeā (Vision) is:
He kaiwhakatere i te tupu me te whanaketanga o ngā ringatoi o Te Whanganui-a-Tara
A catalyst for the growth and development of Wellington artists
Our new Arts Centre will create a vibrant space that nurtures collaboration, creativity and cultural exchange among artists of all generations using Tuakana-Teina Kaupapa. 
For more information head to the Toi Pōneke Arts Centre website.
