description:
Getting the Most from ChatGPT: Practical AI for Everyday Use, AI tools like ChatGPT are everywhere, but how do you get the best out of them? In this hands-on, phone-based workshop, Jon Bell will guide you through practical techniques to make ChatGPT a more useful, reliable partner in your work and life. Whether you’ve tried it a few times or use it regularly, you’ll learn how to write better prompts, refine responses, and avoid common pitfalls without needing any technical background.
We’ll cover real examples, answer your questions as they come up, and spend plenty of time experimenting together so you leave feeling confident and ready to put your new skills to use.
Please bring: A phone with the ChatGPT app installed, and enough battery to last the day.
By the end of the workshop, you’ll be able to:
Write effective prompts that get clearer, more useful responses
Use ChatGPT for research, brainstorming, and creative work
Recognise the tool’s limitations (and how to work around them)
Apply practical strategies for using AI in your personal or professional projects
Confidently troubleshoot when ChatGPT gives unexpected or unhelpful answers
A condition of enrolment is that you must provide photo ID when you attend.
Note:  Courses need a minimum number to go ahead so if we don't have enough enrolments a few days before the start date, we have to cancel. We'll let you know by email so please check yours regularly. If you need to cancel your registration, here are our terms and conditions: "What You Need to Know".
label: Education & Learning

description:
Karanga taonga, karanga tangata, karanga whenua |Reversing Cultural Amnesia: Activating Māori Practice in Museums, In 1947, Māori leader, politician, and scholar Apirana Ngata spoke to his scholarly peers at the Polynesian Society, announcing his greatest desire to revive Māori culture as a living force within communities, not be relegated to dead exhibits in museums (Ramsden 1948, 85).
This lecture acknowledges the concerns of visionary leaders and champions of cultural practice and their activation within museums. Through her work as a Māori curator, writer, cultural practitioner and post-doctoral researcher, Awhina Tamarapa advocates for cultural restoration as a form of liberation in a museum context. In her research, Tamarapa is exploring strategies for the recovery and reclamation of taonga puoro (singing treasures) and karetao (animated storytellers) for new generations.
There are challenges regarding taonga held by overseas museums. Concepts such as keeping taonga warm, and mana taonga, recognises the connection and authority of descendants to their taonga, that underpin this work.
The focus on the reclamation of Indigenous practice has been bolstered by working with First Nations, Canada BC. Led by Professor Bryony Onciul, University of Exeter, UK, Tamarapa was privileged to be part of a research project “The Future of Indigenous Rights and Responsibilities: Ancestral governance, environmental stewardship, language revival, and cultural vibrancy” funded by the Arts and Humanities Research Council, UK.
_________
The Michael Volkerling Lecture series is a partnership event with the Museum and Heritage Studies programme at Te Herenga Waka | Victoria University of Wellington, National Services Te Paerangi and Te Papa Tongarewa. This annual public lecture series recognises the legacy of the late Dr Michael Volkerling who was one of the principal architects of New Zealand's cultural and creative sectors.
label: Education & Learning

description:
Honouring Te Tiriti: Totes, What does it actually mean to honour Te Tiriti?

Join Te Waka Huia for a three-part workshop where we will unpack our nation’s constitutional founding document and explore practical ways to honour it today.

The session begins with kōrero facilitated by tauiwi (non-Māori) guides Gaayathri Nair and Krissi Smith followed by light manaaki and time to explore He Kura Toi Tangata: 50 Years of the Waitangi Tribunal, 1975–2025. After the short break, we’ll regroup for a Q&A session and finish with a tote bag-making activity led by Paekākāriki artist Selina Tuomey.

He Kura Toi Tangata exhibition ends Sunday 12 October.




About Gaayathri

Gaayathri Nair is a double diaspora person hailing from the southwest of India via Malaysia and coming to Aotearoa through economic migration in the 1980's under Rogernomics. She grew up in Tāmaki Makaurau and now lives in Te Awakairangi and works in Te Whanganui-a-Tara. She is a counsellor and facilitator, novice gardener, passionate knitter, frazzled PhD student, and shares a home with a delightfully awkward greyhound named Kevin.



About Krissi

Krissi Smith is of primarily Scottish (Clans McColl, Ross, Hogarth, Sutherland, Buchanan, Mactavish), Irish and English descent, but she grew up in Te Upoko o te Ika on Taranaki Whānui land. She currently lives in Te Ngaengae in Te Awakairangi, still on Taranaki Whānui land, and close to Waiwhetū. Krissi is a Tiriti educator, an accredited interpreter and translator, and a teacher of te reo Māori. She co-directs Kūwaha Ltd, with two of her besties: Tāwhana Chadwick and Raihānia Tipoki. She's also a māmā to one kid, one step kid, and Nanna to one moko. She has three dogs and five chickens. She loves growing kai and cooking it for people, singing karaoke, and sewing. She's a lover of learning and is getting pretty damn comfortable with not knowing the answers!



About Selina

Selina Tuomey has an Irish father and an English mother. She came to Te Whanganui-a-Tara, Aotearoa for the love of this land and a man. As a child in England, her most cherished possession was an Air New Zealand green, plastic tiki sent to her by her pen friend.

She is a mother to three sixth-generation, beautiful, young Pākehā people. Selina has a Fine Art BA Hons and is all about art and nature, acting, painting, murals, clay play and drawing. She has a love of colour, growing trees, food and going bush. Selina is a mermaid and loves people. He tangata, he tangata, he tangata.
label: Education & Learning

description: Inaugural Professorial Lecture - Professor Angela Ballantyne, Inaugural Professorial Lecture "Making things right". What does it mean to make things right? Medicine and science often turn to bioethics for concrete solutions to ethical challenges. But in reality, there is rarely a single, obvious ‘right’ answer. Human systems are inherently messy, and challenged by a legacy of injustice, unequal distributions of power, and declining social trust. This talk will describe the potential for bioethics to help clarify and navigate ethics dilemmas; pragmatically inching us closer to making things – if not right, then at least – better.
label: Education & Learning

description:
Wellington Heritage Festival - Porirua Cemetery walk, Porirua City Council is undertaking a project to memorialise over 1700 unmarked graves.

Come along to hear about the history of Porirua Cemetery and the Porirua Hospital (Asylum) and how this has resulted in hundreds of unmarked graves.

Hear stories of some of those people that died while in the hospital care and hear about the project underway to remember these people with funding from the government.

This is a direct result of funding available from the Royal Inquiry into Abuse in Care.

Parking on roadside, tour will start at the Cemetery Chapel.

Please wear good shoes and dress for the weather. The tour will happen rain or shine, we have a small chapel on site to host the talk if it is wet.

Hutt Valley (Upper Hutt/Lower Hutt) Mathematics Leadership Community 2025, Are you the maths lead in your school? Do you feel equipped to lead the roll out of the new mathematics and statistics curriculum? Would you like to be part of a group of like-minded leads?
Register to join our Mathematics Leadership Community (MLC) and build your mathematics and statistics knowledge and leadership skills.
These MLC’s have been supporting mathematics leaders and teachers for over 18 years and we are excited to offer you the opportunity to be part of this network in 2025, which is shaping up to be a pivotal year in mathematics education.
Through engaging with current research and best practice, these meetings will enable leaders and teachers to:
stay up to date with changes and implement Te Mātaiaho, Mathematics and Statistics Curriculum
build capability in leading mathematics and statistics within and across their school
investigate effective pedagogy and strategies for teaching and assessing mathematics and statistics
connect and network with other leaders and teachers.

Testimonials from 2024
“These days have been invaluable in supporting me to lead whole school maths review with our teachers.”

“It has given me more knowledge and confidence when leading my own meetings, knowing I have research and work behind me when I lead.”

“I love the resources and the connections that develop through these meetings.”

“This year the mahi we have done around the curriculum refresh has been instrumental in beginning our school’s development of our localised curriculum.”

description:
Māori, Christianity & the Spirit World — Public lecture by Bradford Haami, Māori, Christianity & the Spirit World — Public lecture by Bradford Haami
In lecture theatre 2 (GBLT2) in the Law School at Victoria University / Te Herenga Waka.

Ramsey Library presents a public lecture by Bradford Haami.

What happens when vastly different ways of being meet? Dame Anne Salmond writes of ‘competing cosmologies’ and ‘ontological collisions’ — European missionaries arriving in Aotearoa in the early 19th century brought a Biblical cosmology that began such a collision. In this public lecture Bradford Haami will explore the interactions between Biblical and Māori cultural and spiritual worldviews that continue to evolve up to the present.

* How do Biblical and Māori cultural and spiritual beliefs and thought relate?
* How 19th century rangatira negotiate between traditional beliefs and the Biblical narratives?
* Where do Christian and Māori ways of knowing and seeing clash, compete or enrich each other?
* What does being Māori and Christian look like today?


Bradford Haami (Ngāti Awa) is a Māori historian, researcher and author with research interests in Māori worldviews, spirituality, Christianity and cultural preservation. He is Pou Amorangi (Māori Director) at Laidlaw College in Auckland, New Zealand, where he lectures in biculturalism and sits on the governing board of the college. Haami has written several books on Māori history, culture and spirituality, with recent works including Urban Māori: The Second Great Migration (Oratia Media 2018) and Bringing Culture into Care (Huia 2019). He was the Māori curator/expert on the acclaimed Te Taiao / Nature exhibition at Te Papa Tongarewa Museum.

--
To browse the Ramsey Library catalogue, and sign up to borrow books (free), go to https://library.chaplaincyvuw.org.nz

description:
Professor Brian Cox: Emergence, It’s a stage show that covers vast rivers of galaxies in the cosmos, the ecosystems of Earth, and the structure of the human brain. Emergence is the latest show by English physicist, presenter, and personality Professor Brian Cox. He takes to the stage at TSB Arena to contemplate the dazzling complexity of the universe and how it’s built on profoundly simple principles. 
Emergence is also a scientific history of 400 years of human discovery. How did we come to understand so much about the cosmos? Guided by mathematics, curiosity, and an aesthetic sense of symmetry, our species has begun to read the story of the Universe. We’ve started to carry our spacecraft to the edge of the solar system and outwards to the stars. Brian’s engaging style makes these questions come to life. The audience will be left awestruck and thrilled as the show covers vast topics in an accessible way. 
Brian has appeared in many landmark science programs for BBC radio and television over the last 15 years, from the Peabody Award-winning Wonders of the Solar System to the worldwide hit series The Planets. His previous touring show, Horizons, was performed to nearly half a million people across the world.

The construction of Pukeahu National War Memorial Park revealed a wealth of archaeological discoveries, some expected, others surprising.

Join Principal Archaeologists Sarah Phear and Richard Shakles from Underground Overground Archaeology for a special guided tour of the park. Hear firsthand about the excavation process, uncover the stories behind the artefacts, and view a selection of conserved items unearthed from beneath Pukeahu.

The tour begins at the fountain below the Tomb of the Unknown Warrior.
This is an accessible tour. Bring clothing for the weather and any burning questions.

description:
Sir Ian Athfield Memorial Lecture 2025 | Whakatū Nelson, Te Kāhui Whaihanga New Zealand Institute of Architects are excited to welcome Ian Moore to New Zealand to present this year’s lecture series ‘The Past Needs a Future’ which will focus on adaptive reuse.
Ian is the principal of Ian Moore Architects, established in 1990. The practice has won numerous Australian and international awards and has been published and exhibited widely, including at the Venice Architecture Biennale in 2008 and 2012.
Initially studying civil and structural engineering at the Auckland Technical Institute in New Zealand, Ian moved on to study architecture at the University of Technology, Sydney, graduating with honours in 1988.
Ian has taught at numerous universities and been a speaker and guest lecturer throughout Australia as well as internationally.
Ian has also been a member of awards juries in Australia, New Zealand and at the World Festival of Interiors in 2013 and the World Architecture Festival in 2015. In 2003, Ian was the inaugural Creative Director for the Australian Institute of Architects annual conference.
About the Sir Ian Athfield Memorial Lecture
The annual Sir Ian Athfield Memorial Lecture commemorates the late Ian Athfield, a singular and much-loved figure in New Zealand architecture.
Affectionately known as ‘Ath’, Ian was knighted in 2014 and was one of New Zealand’s most influential architects. He won more than 60 national and international architecture and design awards and the lecture series was established to honour his legacy and celebrate his larrikin spirit.
In keeping with that spirit, each year the lecture is given by a person with something to say – someone who is challenging orthodoxy and a business-as-usual approach to practice, and life.
During his career, Ath designed many significant buildings, none more so than his own home in Te Whanganui-a-Tara Wellington, which enraged the neighbours, perplexed the Council and inspired the city for decades.
Ath was talented, original, insightful, opinionated, provocative, and sometimes outrageous. His architecture is stimulating, challenging, ever-changing, but never careless.
In 2004, Te Kāhui Whaihanga New Zealand Institute of Architects awarded Ath the Gold Medal for career achievements, noting at the time “What defines Athfield above all is his contagious enthusiasm, his devotion to architecture, and his unswerving belief in its possibilities. Believing architecture to be a civilising force, he has demonstrated a strong commitment to architecture’s public realm: the streets we live in; the urban centres we inhabit; the countryside we love and so often abuse.”
The Sir Ian Athfield Lecture Series is proudly sponsored by Resene.
Timing:
Doors open: 5.00pm
Lecture: 5.30pm - 6.30pm
Q&A: 6.30pm - 7.00pm
Lecture dates:
Te Whanganui-a-Tara Wellington | Wednesday 3 September | Michael Fowler Centre
Tāhuna Queenstown | Friday 5 September | Crowne Plaza

description:
Steve Sinclair - public lecture, Steve Sinclair - public lecture
'fourth_space, beyond Architecture as a Narcissistic Entity'

LT2 at the School of Architecture and Design VUW.

About this Event

Steve Sinclair is co-founder and director of fourth_space, a practice that seeks to "rescue space to make places," to "recycle bits of left-over architecture," and to make Architecture as "a unifying discipline - politics, regulation, location, design, finance, construction and user experience - that should maintain social and artistic concerns."


https://cdn-az.allevents.in/events10/banners/b883d840-741c-11f0-867e-7d1fd93eb1fd-rimg-w1200-h597-dcd5d5d5-gmir.jpg

Steve studied at the Mackintosh School of Architecture and the Bartlett School before completing an MSc at the London School of Economics. He worked at Morphosis, Ron Arad Associates, FAT (Fashion Architecture Taste), and Harper Mackay (MAK), before joining Paolo Mozzato in 2004, and subsequently Huw Williams, to form fourth_space.
In addition to directing fourth_space Steve is a design advisor to the Hackney Estate Regeneration Design Group, teaches at the AA and is co-owner of award winning Ombra bar & restaurant - where the “Negroni_Talks...!” happen. Available on podcast, these events "promote looser, all-encompassing engagements with greater participation, as well as dispelling false authority and un-challengable ‘expert’ opinions.... "
Steve's lecture is hosted by Te Kāhui Whaihanga ~ New Zealand Institute of Architecture in association with School of Architecture and Design, Victoria University of Wellington ~ Te Herenga Waka and the Architectural Centre.
label: Education & Learning

description:
Site Visit - Holcim Readymix Wellington, Ever wondered how concrete is made?
Join us on Thursday 4th September, for an exclusive NAWIC members-only site tour of the Holcim Readymix NZ plant. Grab a behind the scenes look at:
 🏗️ The Process: How raw materials like cement, aggregates & water are mixed to create concrete
⚙️ Batching & Mixing: How mix designs are selected and adjusted
📏 Quality: Quality controls & production oversight, including testing & slumping
🚚 Dispatch:  Loading, scheduling & delivery coordination
🌱 Sustainability: Low carbon products and how Holcim is approaching driving a circular economy
 The Details:
🕒 DATE and TIME: Thursday, 4th September, 1pm
📍 LOCATION: 121 Centennial Highway, Ngauranga Gorge
🚗PARKING: Parking is tricky! Please carpool if possible, limited parking is available at the front of the Holcim offices (2 car parks) and one more at the top car park. Alternatively, bus route #1 stops off at Ngauranga Gorge (Kiwi Point) stop and is a short walk away
🎟️ COST: Free to NAWIC members, with a maximum of 10 people on the tour, so please book your space consciously. Get in quick! You can join NAWIC here.
👷‍♀️PPE: Hard hat, hi-vis, steel-capped boots, glasses (Spare hard-hats/hi-vis are available if required, please make sure you advise us of what you need on your RSVP.)
 ABOUT HOLCIM: Holcim is a global company across Europe, Asia, Pacific, Latin America, Middle East and Africa.  Holcim NZ  is a leading supplier of cement, aggregates and ready-mix concrete in New Zealand dating back to 1888. You may have noticed their big silos on the Centre Port (near the Interislander). Holcim have a network of plants throughout New Zealand, and one of their main missions is around sustainability, where they actively promote low-carbon concrete solutions, including their premium range ECOPact ECOplanet.
Please note: NAWIC is a voluntary organisation, committed to its obligations as a PCBU under the Health and Safety at Work Act 2015.   Amongst other things, this requires NAWIC to take all practicable steps to eliminate, isolate or minimize hazards that our event attendees are exposed to. Health and safety is a shared responsibility.

West Auckland Mathematics Leadership Community 2025, Are you the maths lead in your school? Do you feel equipped to lead the roll out of the new mathematics and statistics curriculum? Would you like to be part of a group of like-minded leads?
Register to join our Mathematics Leadership Community (MLC) and build your mathematics and statistics knowledge and leadership skills.
These MLC’s have been supporting mathematics leaders and teachers for over 18 years and we are excited to offer you the opportunity to be part of this network in 2025, which is shaping up to be a pivotal year in mathematics education.

Through engaging with current research and best practice, these meetings will enable leaders and teachers to:
stay up to date with changes and implement Te Mātaiaho, Mathematics and Statistics Curriculum
build capability in leading mathematics and statistics within and across their school
investigate effective pedagogy and strategies for teaching and assessing mathematics and statistics
connect and network with other leaders and teachers.

Testimonials from 2024
“These days have been invaluable in supporting me to lead whole school maths review with our teachers.”

description:
the Jesus Lizard, After initially calling it a day in 1999, the Jesus Lizard officially return full time to save us from the current state of musical mediocrity with their latest album, Rack. A blistering resurgence of the so-called ‘noise rock’ they helped define alongside contemporaries Big Black, Flipper, The Birthday Party, with their previous and most noted albums Head, Goat and Liar. For those of us who live in fear of the reunion album and subsequent tour, the Jesus Lizard thankfully display not only the same chaotic and dark nihilism of their earlier careers but also the maturity and seasoning of a band riding a wave of renewed and reinvigorated form.

Once slated by famed engineer Steve Albini as “the greatest band I’ve ever seen’ the Jesus Lizard not only lived up to this lofty praise in their prime but continue to do so in their advancing years. David Yow still leads the charge as the maniacally possessed frontman entering crowds with reckless abandon and a stamina that much younger vocalists would kill for. The original rhythm section of David Wm Sims and Mac McNeilly further continue to prove why they were and are the best bass & drum combo since Jones and Bonham, anchoring the ship as Captain Yow and first mate Denison navigate the wild seas of their songs. And while he may not always feature (as he rightly should) on many modern music journalists ‘best guitarists lists’, Duane Denison could perhaps be the most innovative and idiosyncratic punk rock guitarist EVER. However, each member is a sum of their parts but combined they are as Albini also once said “the purest melding of the sublime and profane.”

Whether you are a longtime disciple of the Jesus Lizard, seeing them when last here in ‘98, or perhaps your fandom is more recent and have only seen videos of their legendary live performances, you will know that these shows are not to be missed.

Saturday 11th October 2025 - The Tuning Fork, Auckland (All ages)

Sunday 12th October 2025 - San Fran, Wellington (R18 unless accompanied by your legal guardian)

description:
Wellington Rowing Club AGM, Lotto 8’s & Season Opening, The Wellington Rowing Club Annual General Meeting (AGM) and opening of the season will be held on Sunday 24 August 2024, 12 noon, at the WRC Function Centre.
We look forward to seeing you all at the Club at 9:30 for Lotto 8’s (weather permitting).
Following the meetings, a light lunch will be provided. This is also WRC’s opportunity to unveil the Function Space renovations to the membership.

Information about the AGM
The WRC AGM will commence at 12noon, in the WRC Function Centre. There will be provisions for online attendance.
At this year’s AGM, we have several board and committee positions that we will be seeking to fill. Many hands make light work, and we all depend on volunteers to keep the club growing and thriving. A variety of experience levels, skill sets, and perspectives are needed for a well-functioning club.
The positions to be filled this year are:
-Club Captain (2-year term, Officer role)
-Vice President (2-year term, Officer role)
-Club Treasurer (2-year term, Officer role)
-Club Secretary (2-year term, Officer role)
-3 Committee roles (1-year term, non-Officer role)
-3 Board members (2-year term, Officer role)
Officers of the must consent in writing to being an officer and certify that they are eligible and not disqualified from holding office as described under section 36B of the Charities Act 2005.
The Club by-laws outline the current role descriptions, can be found here, note that the roles can be tailored to suit individuals’ skill sets and experience. Mentoring and support can be provided to develop individuals in these positions.
If you are interested, but have further questions- please reach out to the people holding the current role or any of the board or committee members to discuss.

description:
Aunty Records Presents: Jazmine Nikitta [AUS] with Benny Salvador, Aunty Records Presents: Jazmine Nikitta [AUS] with Benny Salvador
Caribbean-Australian DJ Jazmine Nikitta is one of the most exciting names in global dance music right now. Fresh off her first world tour, she supported SiR across Europe and headlined parties across North and South America. She’s shared the stage with Brent Faiyaz, Bryson Tiller, Davido, Tems, and became the first Australian DJ to tour with Soulection, performing across Miami and Jamaica. Festival highlights include Splendour in the Grass, Dark MOFO, and a headline slot at Promiseland between Ms. Lauryn Hill and Tems.


Beyond the decks, Jazmine served as Spotify AUNZ’s exclusive Hip-Hop and R&B Editor (2021–24), launching Australia’s first Afrobeats and Amapiano playlist, Afro Fusion, and curating the platform’s biggest local dance playlists. She also hosted A1 The Show, a Spotify-exclusive podcast, interviewing artists like Uncle Waffles, Central Cee, and Saweetie.


She’s joined by Wellington’s Benny Salvador — DJ, producer, multi-instrumentalist, and one of New Zealand’s most exciting young talents. Benny’s eclectic sets blend house, techno, disco-funk, dub, and electro, with releases on Rush Hour, Racquet Club, Juke Bounce Werk, and his own Aunty Records.


Support from Awa.

Wellington Brick Show 2025, Wellington's largest display of LEGO® builds is back, bigger than ever!
Mark the 13th & 14th of September in your calendar and be sure to come along to see the amazing LEGO® creations from some of NZ’s best builders. This year’s show is our biggest yet, featuring over 150 passionate exhibitors from across the country to showcase their newest, most mind-blowing LEGO® creations. From towering cities to pop culture tributes, from amazing spaceships to fanciful unicorns, we have something to inspire and amaze LEGO® fans of all ages.
Come along to Walter Nash Stadium in Lower Hutt and experience amazing LEGO® displays, interactive activities, brick pits to get creative, raffles, food trucks and much more!

Adults $10

Door sales will also be available.
Be sure to like and follow the Wellington Brick Show on Facebook and Instagram to find out more about this amazing weekend of LEGO®fun! @WBS.nz

description:
Ōtari Glow Worm Tour, Ōtari Glow Worm Tour
Take a guided night tour through Ōtari-Wilton’s Bush and discover some of the fascinating night-time residents on your way to see the titiwai/glowworms. Enjoy the tranquil beauty of the bush after dark and witness the magical glow of these unique creatures.

This outdoor night-time tour takes just over an hour.
If bringing children, we find it most suitable for those aged 5 years and older.
The tour requires a moderate level of fitness, the route includes numerous steps to and from the glowworms.

Meet at the Ōtari Visitors Centre, 150 Wilton Road. Bring warm clothes, walking shoes, and a torch.

This tour is operated by the Ōtari-Wilton’s Bush Trust. Join the Trust from just $20 a year and the glow worm tour is free, plus you’ll be supporting the amazing work the Trust does. Join today at owbt.nz/membership-donations/

Glow Worm Tour Ticket Refund Policy
• No Refunds: We do not offer refunds for Glow Worm Tour tickets.
• Ticket Transfers: If you can’t attend your booked tour, we will put you on a future tour, subject to availability. Please contact us as soon as possible to arrange this.
• Weather Conditions: Tours operate rain or shine. In the event of extreme weather or unsafe conditions, we will reschedule your tour or provide a refund.

For any changes or inquiries, please get in touch with us in advance at or call 04 499 1400.

description:
Waikanae Makeup Masterclass - 27.09 @9:15 am, About this event
Join Nikki, a Professional Makeup Artist & Colour Expert with over 14 years of experience, for an engaging and practical Makeup Masterclass. Nikki and her team focus on enhancing natural beauty and making makeup easy for everyone.
As we journey through life, our skin and style evolve. The best way to update your look and learn techniques that suit your unique face shape, style, and colouring is to attend one of our masterclasses. Whether you're a performer on stage, a busy professional, or a multitasking mum, this class will teach you how to apply your makeup quickly, flawlessly, and with confidence.
During the class, Nikki will demonstrate step-by-step techniques on a model while you get to apply your own makeup. You'll have access to professional products and tools to follow along and create your flawless everyday look. It’s fun, interactive, and designed for all skill levels.
"I can’t wait to share my knowledge with you and help you create a makeup routine that leaves you feeling fabulous and confident every day!" – Nikki
What You Need to Know:
No equipment required! We’ll provide all makeup products, brushes, and mirrors.
Bring a willingness to learn and a positive attitude.
Classes are capped at 12-15 participants to ensure personalised guidance.
Arrive 10–15 minutes early to get settled.
Please come with a clean, makeup-free face so you can get the best results.

description:
Kapiti Wedding & Events Expo 2026, Kapiti Wedding & Events Expo 2026
Get ready for a day of love, celebration, and unforgettable inspiration at the Kapiti Wedding & Events Expo 2026 – the Kapiti Coast’s premier event for anyone planning a wedding, special event, or milestone celebration. Taking place on Sunday, 19 April 2026, from 10am to 3pm at the Paraparaumu Memorial Hall, this vibrant expo brings together over 40 of the region’s top wedding and event professionals, all in one beautiful space. Best of all? Entry is completely FREE!

From breathtaking florals and stunning venue styling to expert celebrants, creative photographers, world-class entertainment, and delectable food and drink offerings, this expo has it all. Whether you’re newly engaged, planning a birthday bash, organising a corporate event, or simply love all things celebration, the Kapiti Wedding & Events Expo is your one-stop destination for inspiration and expert advice.

This year’s expo promises an immersive experience packed with exclusive show-only offers, giveaways, and dazzling live performances on the Main Stage. Meet the creative minds behind Kapiti’s most iconic celebrations, explore dreamy decor ideas, and uncover the latest wedding and event trends that will help you bring your vision to life. Our hand-picked exhibitors are the best in the business, offering fresh ideas and tailored solutions to make your event truly unforgettable.

But that’s not all – your free ticket also unlocks exclusive deals across the Kapiti Coast. From boutique shopping and cosy cafes to scenic stays and local attractions, our Explore Kapiti program gives you access to fantastic discounts and experiences from our local business partners. Simply show your expo ticket to take advantage of these offers while you’re in town.

The Kapiti Wedding & Events Expo is proudly brought to you by Kapiti Castles, experienced event organisers who understand how to make moments magical. With a deep love for creativity, community, and connection, we’ve crafted this event to help you dream big and plan with confidence.

So don’t miss out – grab your free tickets today and join us for an extraordinary day of discovery, excitement, and inspiration. Whether you're planning a wedding, a party, or something truly unique, this is where your perfect celebration begins.

description:
Treasury Guest Lecture with Michael Keen: IN-PERSON attendance, Join us for our special Fiscal Policy for the Future seminar
New Zealand faces significant long-term fiscal challenges, including the rising costs associated with an ageing population, increasing demand for public services, and the need to adapt to a changing global economy. These pressures will require careful planning to ensure the sustainability of government finances while maintaining fairness and efficiency in the tax system.
Inland Revenue’s draft Long-Term Insights Briefing explores these issues by asking critical questions about the future shape and scale of our tax system. Similarly, the Treasury’s Long-Term Fiscal Statement highlights the importance of future-proofing our tax framework and other broader policy settings to address these challenges.
Join us for this seminar delivered by a highly regarded economist and expert in tax policy and administration, and a prolific author, Michael Keen, as he shares his insights on future proofing our tax system.
This will be a hybrid event, and we encourage you to attend it in person for an opportunity to engage in a discussion on all those issues with our guest speaker.
About this event
This will be a hybrid event. Please use this site to register if you plan to attend it in person.
If you would like to attend it virtually, please use THIS LINK to register.
The Tax Policy Charitable Trust has arranged Mick’s visit to New Zealand. The Trust was established to support leading tax policy thinking in New Zealand. You can read about the Trust’s work here.
About the presenter
Michael (Mick) Keen is a former Deputy Director of the Fiscal Affairs Department at the International Monetary Fund, where for over twenty years he played a central role in shaping and delivering IMF policies and advice on tax matters.
He has advised finance ministries in all parts of the world, including missions to over forty countries, and led the preparation of influential papers for the G20 and the Executive Board of the IMF.
Before joining the Fund, Mick was Professor of Economics at the universities of Essex (UK), Queens (Canada) and Kyoto, and is now Ushioda Fellow at the University of Tokyo.
Mick was the keynote speaker at the 2014 conference on the Future of Tax Administration in New Zealand and has provided peer review for Inland Revenue’s previous Long-Term Insights Briefing.
Mick has jointly authored, with Joel Slemrod, Rebellion, Rascals and Revenue – an entertaining account of how history illuminates the perennial challenges and timeless principles of taxation—and how the past holds clues to solving the tax problems of today.
About this seminar series
New ideas, innovative concepts, research evidence and expert advice are all crucial to stimulate and inform the Treasury’s economic analysis and advice. Our current theme for guest lectures - Fiscal Policy for the Future - explores the role of stabilising, sustainable and effective fiscal policy. Speakers provide insights into how fiscal policy can be designed to support government to meet its current and future objectives and obligations while adapting to changing circumstances and delivering value to the New Zealand public.
Fiscal policy has a stabilising role in helping to smooth the business cycle, while sustainability in fiscal policy is foundational for resilience to both shocks and longstanding challenges, such as climate change, technological advancements, and demographic trends. Ensuring effective and value for money expenditure is important so that fiscal policy contributes to the living standards of New Zealanders, both now and in the future.
Please note that the views, opinions, findings, and conclusions expressed in the Treasury Guest Lecture Series are those of the individual presenters. They do not necessarily reflect the views of the New Zealand Treasury or the New Zealand Government.
For updates and our latest research visit: www.treasury.govt.nz
Keep in touch
If you would like to be the first to hear about our upcoming events in the Treasury Guest Lecture Series, please SUBSCRIBE to stay up to date.

description:
Discover Te Muna - Go behind the scenes, Join us for a unique full day experience immersing yourself in the viticulture, wine making and wines of Te Muna valley. This spectacular valley lies nine kilometres east of Martinborough. Visit the vineyards, meet the producers, go behind the scenes and taste the wines where they are made.

We will pick you up from the Martinborough Square at 9.30 am to start your day at Big Sky Wines. Founders, viticulturists, and winemakers Katherine Jacobs and Jeremy Corban will give you a first look at their 2025 ferments, which have been produced from their organic vineyard. We will then take you to tour Blue Earth Estate vineyard and olive grove and enjoy a long lunch, accompanied by a glass of wine of course. From there we will take you to the stunning winery at Escarpment, and then to explore the beautiful terraced Craggy Range vineyard and taste their wines among the vines, both of which are not normally open to the public. We will finish the day with some of the other Te Muna producers joining us to share their wines and their stories. It will be a day of discovery - the place, the people and the wines of the beautiful Te Muna Valley.

Tickets are strictly limited to 18 people.

description:
NZ Brewers Fest, NZ Brewers Fest is moving to April!
Lining up with Fresh Hop season, we will be bringing the all the incredible beers, outstanding entertainment and delicious kai you expect, with a fresh hop twist!
Save the date and watch this space for more info, coming soon!

TICKETS ON SALE SOON!

Drinks!
It wouldn’t be NZBF without great beer, and this year 20 of Aotearoa’s best breweries will descend on Brewtown to pour every style you could possibly desire, from crisp Lagers, cold IPAs and hoppy Pale Ales, to funky Sours, smoky Porters, rich Pastry Stouts – and everything in between!
Visit Brewtown’s own custom Unimog Bar for 13 beers handpicked by our craft beer experts, but get in quick – we only have 1 keg of each, and they won’t last long!
New for this year! Step into our cocktail bar for some seriously scrumptious spirits! Our mixologists have been hard at work creating some delicious drops just for you.
We’re bringing in some of the best wines the Wairarapa has to offer, so whether you prefer a crisp Sauv, a fruity Pinot or a refreshing Frosé there will be something to enjoy.
Still not enough for you? Then head down to the Everything Else Bar, for NZ crafted ciders, as well as bourbon, rum, gin and vodka alongside a range of low and no alcohol beers, cocktails and soft drinks.

Kai!
The NZBF food court hosts the region’s top foodies, bringing you big, bold, flavour-packed festival eats that’ll satisfy every craving.
Watch this space as we announce our festive foodie lineup!

Entertainment!

Lose yourself in a cabaret of the bizarre, where the performances are as dark as they are dazzling.
Witness the brutal thrill of buhurt armoured combat, as warriors face off in full medieval kit in a raw display of might and mayhem.

Dance the day away at the main stage, as Welly’s top talent smash out tune after tune, all building up to a headline show from Brewtown favourites, The Blueprint.

Grab your mates and get stuck in at the Games Zone, where a bit of friendly rivalry meets festive fun, and the loser buys the next round.

With affordable return coaches from Welly and Petone and great discounts for group tickets it's scarily easy to get involved!

description:
Boost Your Business: Take the Stress Out of Digital Marketing, Take the Stress Out of Digital Marketing
Calling all Pasifika entrepreneurs, small business owners, and innovators in the Wellington region.

Join us for a free, hands-on workshop led by Katie Brown. We’ll break down digital marketing and social media into clear, actionable tools you can use immediately. You’ll do this in a friendly and open environment, where you can ask questions, share ideas, and learn from others. Plus, enjoy refreshments and kai (catered by Amilagis) to keep you energised.

By the end of the workshop, you’ll leave with real, usable tools. This is perfect for anyone in Wellington wanting to build confidence online, make social media easier, and drive forward your business idea.

Attending these workshops gives you the chance to join the WLG NZ RPBN programme, where Katie’s full course supports your next steps in growing your digital presence. Spaces are limited, book your spot today and step into your digital strength!

**Doors open at 5.30pm, session begins at 6pm**

About the Speaker:
Katie Brown (Ngāti Whātua, Ngāti Raukawa) brings over 15+ years’ experience in social media, digital strategy, and communications. She’s the founder of Social Good and has held key roles in government and corporate spheres, including setting up ACC’s social media strategy and leading Aotearoa’s all-of-government digital communications response during COVID-19. Katie is also a certified Meta (Facebook) Community Trainer and regularly delivers workshops across Aotearoa, helping organisations to tell stronger digital stories.

description:
Welly Biotech ‘n’ Beers - Speaker Series - September, BioTech N Beers presents the second instalment of its speaker series!
Once a quarter we will be running a fireside chat with those that have been there done that, the up and coming and everything in-between.
Kindly hosted by LabWorks, our speaker will be John Robson telling us about his journey in investment from banks to BioTechs.
Generously sponsored by FB Rice, come along for a yarn, some war stories, and drinks and kai.
Check out John’s bio below and we hope to see you there!
 Event Details:
Date: Friday, 26 September, 2025
Location: Level 10, 76 Manners Street, Wellington
Time: 4:30 pm – 6:30 pm
Speaker: John (JR) Robson
Description: My journey from banks to BioTechs
  About John Robson:
JR is the Managing Director of cell therapy company, BioOra Limited. BioOra addresses both access and scale issues by providing an affordable and accelerated pathway to market for CAR-T therapies via lower cost, high throughput, GMP licensed manufacturing capabilities from clinical trial through to registration and commercialisation.
 JR is also the General Manager of Bridgewest Ventures in New Zealand, and he holds an executive position within the Bridgewest Group, a San Diego based privately held investment company that focuses on disrupting industries through innovation and with investment assets in excess of US$4 billion, and JR is responsible for the deep tech investment programme in New Zealand.
 JR has nearly 30 years of investment experience across global markets and he has been intimately involved in the start-up community in New Zealand since 2008 through a number of early-stage technology companies as an executive and non-executive director. JR regularly writes and speaks about technology in a number of forums and is an avid futurist.
 In addition to his executive roles, JR has been active in the Not-for-Profit ecosystem in New Zealand for 20 years and was the Chair of the National Board of the Child Cancer Foundation for 4 years, and is currently a Board Member of the One Percent Collective Trust. He was awarded Life Membership of the Child Cancer Foundation in 2017 by the Governor-General of New Zealand, Her Excellency The Rt Hon Dame Patsy Reddy, for his services to Childhood Cancer.
 FB Rice:
FB Rice is a leading independent intellectual property firm with a strong focus on biotechnology and the life sciences. With more than 75 years of experience and a dedicated Wellington office, we’re proud to support New Zealand’s growing biotech community through local presence and expertise.
Our Biotechnology Group brings deep scientific and industry knowledge across areas such as gene therapy, diagnostics, biologics, vaccines, and medical technologies. We work closely with clients across academia, research, and industry to protect innovation and support commercial success—offering strategic advice on patentability, prosecution, due diligence, and portfolio management.
As active participants in New Zealand’s innovation ecosystem, we value collaboration and are committed to helping the local biotech sector thrive.
 Lab-Works:
With over 30 years’ experience, Lab-works Architecture are New Zealand’s leading laboratory design architects, with a proven track record across research, teaching, healthcare, and analytical facilities. We believe well-designed laboratories and support spaces enhance capability, productivity, and competitive advantage, so we ensure our clients benefit from best practice in facility planning, design, and technology. Science is always evolving, and so are we—continuously updating our skills and staying at the forefront of new research to deliver leading-edge projects. Through active involvement in international conferences, standards committees, and ongoing research and development in the built environment, we provide design and technical solutions that are robust, fit-for-purpose, and future-focused.

description:
Whāia te mātauranga hei oranga mō koutou: A Review, Nau mai, haere mai, hoki mai.
Te Waka Huia Wellington Museum is proud to present the Te Waka Huia Wellington Museum Legal Series, an informative lecture series about the purpose, historical significance and ongoing mahi of the Waitangi Tribunal held alongside the exhibition He Kura Toi Tangata: 50 Years of the Waitangi Tribunal, 1975-2025.
The Government recently announced a review of the Treaty of Waitangi Act 1975, which comes as the statute approaches its 50-year milestone on 10th October. The review is part of the coalition agreement between New Zealand First and National and will be led by an Independent Technical Advisory Group (ITAG), supported by Te Puni Kōkiri, to examine the whether the Waitangi Tribunal is “fit for purpose, not just for today, but for the generations to come.”
Joining us to discuss the topic of reform are Former Attorney-General and Treaty Minister Christopher Finlayson, and Matanuku Mahuika, who co-chaired the Waitangi Tribunal’s own Strategic Direction Review Group in 2024.
Tickets are $35 per session, or $25 for students and SuperGold Card holders, and include one drink and light kai. Doors open 5:30pm. The exhibition He Kura Toi Tangata will remain open to view until 8pm.
Te Waka Huia Wellington Museum
Wednesday 20 August | 6pm–8pm
Tickets $25–$35
This series has been developed by Te Waka Huia Wellington Museum and is presented in collaboration with our programme partner Kāhui Legal.
Speakers:
Christopher Finlayson
The Hon. Christopher Finlayson served as an MP for 12 years, including as Attorney-General and Minister for Treaty of Waitangi Negotiations from 2008 to 2017. During his Ministerial career he also held a number of other portfolios. He is the co-author of He Kupu Taurangi: Treaty Settlements and the Future of Aotearoa New Zealand. He left politics in 2019 and now works for Bankside Chambers as a barrister.
Matanuku Mahuika
(Ngāti Porou, Ngāti Raukawa)
Matanuku Mahuika is one of Aotearoa’s leading Māori lawyers in private practice. He co-founded Kāhui Legal in 2003. Prior to establishing Kāhui Legal, Matanuku was a partner at Walters Williams & Co and in-house counsel at the Treaty of Waitangi Fisheries Commission.
This series has been developed by Te Waka Huia Wellington Museum and is presented in collaboration with our programme partner Kāhui Legal.
label: Education & Learning

You’ll be greeted by a singing group of talented Pōneke rangatahi and there’ll be live music throughout the evening. But most importantly, you’ll get to meet the 47 gifted children’s writers, illustrators and translators who are finalists in this year’s awards, and applaud the winners as they are announced.

This is a popular event with a limited number of seats, so secure your place today and enjoy this wonderful showcase of the very best books of the year for young New Zealand readers.

description:
Christof van der Ven - Abandoned Brewery - Lower Hutt, Christof van der Ven - Abandoned Brewery - Lower Hutt
After 5 years Christof is coming back to New Zealand to tour his newly released album.

He plays at the Abandoned Brewery taproom in Petone on the 30th of October.

Christof van der Ven has built a truly impressive CV over the course of his career, from supporting the likes of Bon Iver, The Staves, Mel Parsons, Bear’s Den, Lisa Hannigan, and Nick Mulvey, to playing in front of thousands of fans across the world.

Hailing originally from Holland, Christof van der Ven moved to Galway in 2007 before settling in London. He has released two LPs, Empty Handed (2018) and You Were The Place (2019), alongside multiple EPs. His career has been supported by DIY, Clash, Gold Flake Paint and his music has been played on BBC6 Radio and Radio X.

NEW ALBUM “Is this what we’ve become?”

Throughout ‘is this what we’ve become?’ Christof speaks to loved ones and past selves, reflecting on years of promise, regret and loss. His storytelling is characterized by gentle melodies and rich, textured arrangements, as his younger selves confront him with unfulfilled ambitions and perceived failures. When Christof turns towards friends and family, he finds them too in moments of upheaval, in need of support. Amidst the unpredictable and uncontrollable, community and friendship emerge, providing roots, giving comfort as Christof ruminates on how he came to be - and can come to accept - who he is now.

Written by Christof, ‘is this what we’ve become?’also features musical contributions from Jools Owen (Bear’s Den, Bess Atwell), Tommy Heap (Billie Marten, Matthew and the Atlas), Marcus Hamblett (Villagers, Bear’s Den), and Estilo String Quartet. The album was produced and recorded by Christof and Ian Grimble (Daughter, Manic Street Preachers, Matt Corby, Fionn Regan), who also mixed the LP. ‘is this what we’ve become?’ incorporates recordings from both studio sessions in London, as well as ad hoc recording sessions engineered by Christof across the UK.
label: Music & Concerts

description:
Sir Ian Athfield Memorial Lecture 2025 | Te Whanganui-a-Tara Wellington, Te Kāhui Whaihanga New Zealand Institute of Architects are excited to welcome Ian Moore to New Zealand to present this year’s lecture series ‘The Past Needs a Future’ which will focus on adaptive reuse.
Ian is the principal of Ian Moore Architects, established in 1990. The practice has won numerous Australian and international awards and has been published and exhibited widely, including at the Venice Architecture Biennale in 2008 and 2012.
Initially studying civil and structural engineering at the Auckland Technical Institute in New Zealand, Ian moved on to study architecture at the University of Technology, Sydney, graduating with honours in 1988.
Ian has taught at numerous universities and been a speaker and guest lecturer throughout Australia as well as internationally.
Ian has also been a member of awards juries in Australia, New Zealand and at the World Festival of Interiors in 2013 and the World Architecture Festival in 2015. In 2003, Ian was the inaugural Creative Director for the Australian Institute of Architects annual conference.
About the Sir Ian Athfield Memorial Lecture
The annual Sir Ian Athfield Memorial Lecture commemorates the late Ian Athfield, a singular and much-loved figure in New Zealand architecture.
Affectionately known as ‘Ath’, Ian was knighted in 2014 and was one of New Zealand’s most influential architects. He won more than 60 national and international architecture and design awards and the lecture series was established to honour his legacy and celebrate his larrikin spirit.
In keeping with that spirit, each year the lecture is given by a person with something to say – someone who is challenging orthodoxy and a business-as-usual approach to practice, and life.
During his career, Ath designed many significant buildings, none more so than his own home in Te Whanganui-a-Tara Wellington, which enraged the neighbours, perplexed the Council and inspired the city for decades.
Ath was talented, original, insightful, opinionated, provocative, and sometimes outrageous. His architecture is stimulating, challenging, ever-changing, but never careless.
In 2004, Te Kāhui Whaihanga New Zealand Institute of Architects awarded Ath the Gold Medal for career achievements, noting at the time “What defines Athfield above all is his contagious enthusiasm, his devotion to architecture, and his unswerving belief in its possibilities. Believing architecture to be a civilising force, he has demonstrated a strong commitment to architecture’s public realm: the streets we live in; the urban centres we inhabit; the countryside we love and so often abuse.”
The Sir Ian Athfield Lecture Series is proudly sponsored by Resene and GIB.
CPD points: 10
TIMING:
Doors open: 5.00pm
Lecture: 5.30pm - 6.30pm
Q&A: 6.30pm - 7.00pm
LECTURE DATES:
Te Whanganui-a-Tara Wellington | Wednesday 3 September | Michael Fowler Centre

description:
Spring Céilí Dance with The Great Beag Céilí Band, Spring Céilí Dance with The Great Beag Céilí Band
Spring has sprung, the days are getting longer, the rain is falling sideways. Must be about time we had another céilí! Join The Great Beag Céilí Band at St Michael’s Hall in Kelburn for a rousing evening of dancing to foot-stomping celtic tunes. Our Autumn céilí sold out so make sure you get your tickets early!

If you’ve never been to a céilí (or ceilidh) before, fear not - céilí dancing is very easy! No fancy moves or any previous experience required: our caller will explain each dance, and we’ll all walk it through a couple of times before adding the music.

This is social dancing so bring all your friends! No need to bring a specific partner - there’ll be lots of friendly people to dance with.

Discounted online tickets are available on Humanitix until midnight on September 26th: $24 / $16 concession
https://events.humanitix.com/beag-ceili-spring-ceili-2025

Some door sales may be available on the day: $30 / $20 concession (cash only)

—

Doors open 7:30pm

Adults and age 10+ welcome. Under 16s accompanied by an adult.

Light refreshments will be available. We recommend bringing a water bottle to grab a quick drink between dances - hydration is key!
This is an alcohol-free event.

Getting here: St Michael’s Hall is located at 81 Upland Road in Kelburn Village, just behind the church.
There is very limited on-street parking in the village. We recommend public transport: the 4, 18, 21, and 22 buses stop regularly right outside coming up from Te Aro or down from Northland and Karori.

Be safe online: Tickets are only available online from the Humanitix event. Do not buy tickets from other sources such as Facebook comments or resale sites - these are always scams. If you can no longer attend, please contact us via Humanitix, our socials, or email to discuss refunds.

Health notice: Céilí dancing is a great way to meet lots of people. If you are feeling unwell then please stay home and rest this time, we will see you at the next one.

Children’s “Matisse” Collage Workshop with Linda Kirkland – 60 minutes of fun and focused creativity for children aged 8 – 12 years. Immerse your child in a world of colour and creativity with the Under the Sea collage workshop, led by experienced educator Linda Kirkland. Drawing inspiration from the bold, large-scale collages of Henri Matisse—who famously described his technique as painting with scissors—Linda will guide the children through an exciting exploration of shape, colour, and composition. Her engaging teaching style will inspire the young artists to create vibrant and unique masterpieces that bring the underwater world to life.

description:
Beer & Spirits Halloween Crawl – Wellington 2025, Beer & Spirits Halloween Crawl – Wellington 2025
Raise your glass to Halloween in Wellington! The Beer & Spirits Crawl brings cocktails, craft beer, costumes, and DJs on November 1st.

About this Event

🍺🥃 BEER & SPIRITS: HALLOWEEN BOOZE CRAWL 2025 – Wellington 🥃🍺 Halloween Saturday in Wellington is about to get boozier. The Beer & Spirits: Halloween Booze Crawl is your pass to explore the city’s best pubs, breweries, and nightlife spots in one epic night of costumes, cocktails, and craft beer.
On Saturday, November 1st, 2025, hundreds of party-ready crawlers will gather to toast the spookiest night of the year. From seasonal ales and spiced lagers to spooky-themed shots and signature cocktails, every stop on the crawl will be serving something worth raising a glass to.



EVENT HIGHLIGHTS
🥃 Beer + Spirits Combo: Enjoy the best of both worlds with craft beer options and premium cocktails at every venue.
🎶 Live Music & DJs: Halloween hits, party anthems, and dance-worthy beats all night long.
📍 Venues: Lulu Bar & Restaurant, El Horno, The Rogue & Vagabond, and BL3 — hand-picked Wellington bars and breweries offering exclusive specials for crawl guests.
🎟 Your Ticket Includes: Wristband for entry, drink specials at each stop, and access to the official crawl map.

HOW TO JOIN THE FUN
1️⃣ Check-In: Pick up your wristband at the starting venue between 7:30–10:30 PM.
2️⃣ Crawl at Your Own Pace: Visit participating middle-stop venues between 8:30–11:30 PM.
3️⃣ Last Call for Halloween: Everyone meets at the final venue at 11:30 PM for the Saturday night send-off party.



PARTICIPATING VENUES The lineup will be released soon — each location is chosen for great drinks, great atmosphere, and great music.
📍 On event day, click the to view the full venue list, drink specials, and schedule.

🎭 Costume Friendly: Whether you’re dressed as a beer-loving ghoul, a whiskey-wielding pirate, or a spooky pop culture icon, you’ll fit right in.

🚨 Saturday-Only Tickets: This is a one-night-only Halloween party. Early bird tickets start at just $15 — secure your spot before they’re gone.

What’s Included in Your Ticket:
🍺 Entry to 4+ pubs, breweries, and clubs in Wellington
🚫 No cover at all participating venues
🎟️ Exclusive Halloween Booze Crawl wristband
📱 Digital crawl map to navigate each stop
🎵 Live DJs & music at every venue
🕺 Closing party to end Halloween Saturday in style



18+ EVENT / GOVERNMENT ISSUED ID REQUIRED


TIPS FOR OUR CRAWL
Pick Up Wristbands On Time: Collect your wristband(s) during the designated check-in time at the scheduled location before 10:30 PM. Late arrivals will not be accommodated — no wristband, no entry.
Assign a Proxy if Needed: Can’t make check-in? Have a friend pick up your wristband for you so they don’t miss out.
Day-Of Updates: Review the Digital Crawl Map on the morning of the event for any last-minute changes or venue updates.
Check Venue Schedule: Each venue’s crawl time is listed in the Digital Crawl Map. Wristbands and drink specials are valid only during these scheduled times.
_______________________________________


IMPORTANT DISCLAIMERS
Age Requirement: You must be 18+ years of age with a valid government-issued ID to participate in this event. No exceptions.
Wristbands: Your wristband is your key to entry. You must present your ticket or QR code at check-in to receive your wristband. Wristbands must be worn at all times to access participating bars and venues. Wristband pickup location and time are listed on the crawl map. If you do not pick up your wristband at the designated location and time, it may not be available, and you will not be able to access crawl venues. No wristband, no entry.
Ticket Policy: All sales are final—no refunds, exchanges, or transfers. In case of event cancellation without a rescheduled date, a refund (excluding fees) will be automatically issued. Event lineup, venues, and specials are subject to change without notice.
Admission & Venue Rights: Participating venues reserve the right to refuse service or entry to any attendee based on intoxication, dress code, inappropriate behaviour, or venue capacity. If refused entry at one venue, you may visit alternative crawl venues available at that time. No refunds will be given if you are denied entry for any of these reasons.
Capacity and Late Entry: Some venues may hit capacity during the event. If a venue reaches capacity or you arrive late, you may have to wait in line to gain entry. There is no guarantee of immediate access or entry to any specific venue once capacity is reached, and no refunds will be provided due to waiting times or access issues.
Self-Guided Crawl: This is a self-guided event with no host leading the group. You must use the digital crawl map to navigate between venues.
Venue Awareness: If bar staff are unaware of the crawl, you must contact the venue representative listed on the crawl map. If you cannot reach them, consider that venue unavailable and proceed to an alternative crawl venue open at that time. Nightlife venues may reach capacity or close early, and not all staff members may be aware of the crawl.
Drink Specials: Drink specials are offered by participating venues and may be modified or discontinued at any time without notice.
Event Time Restrictions: Your ticket is valid only for crawl venues during the scheduled crawl times listed on the crawl map. It is not valid for entry outside these times. If you arrive late or at the wrong venue, refunds will not be issued.
Security Checks: Wristbands do not entitle you to skip venue security checks. All attendees must comply with security screening before entry.
Costume Policy: Do not wear costumes that include items which could be considered or used as weapons. Highly offensive costumes are not tolerated and may result in denial of entry without refund.
Crawl Notifications: Sign up for crawl notification texts to receive updates about when to move to the next venue. There is no host to notify you in person.
Respect & Conduct: Treat others and the event venues with respect. Disorderly conduct, inappropriate behaviour, or damage to the venues will result in removal from the event without a refund. The participating bars reserve the right to refuse entry or remove attendees for inappropriate behaviour at any time.
Liability Waiver: By purchasing a ticket and participating in the crawl, you understand and agree that you are attending entirely at your own risk. You voluntarily assume all risks and dangers incidental to this event, including but not limited to: personal injury, illness, disability, property loss, theft, damage, accidents, death, alcohol-related incidents, and actions of other participants, staff, or third parties. You, on behalf of yourself and your heirs, executors, and assigns, hereby fully release, waive, and discharge Events Per Se, its owners, officers, directors, employees, contractors, volunteers, affiliates, sponsors, participating venues, and their respective representatives from any and all liability, claims, demands, actions, or causes of action whatsoever arising out of or related to any loss, damage, injury, illness, or death — whether caused by negligence, gross negligence, breach of contract, or otherwise — that may occur before, during, or after the event. You agree to indemnify and hold harmless Events Per Se and all released parties from any claims, costs, or expenses (including legal fees) brought by you or on your behalf, or by any third party as a result of your actions during the event. You acknowledge that you have read and understood this waiver, that you are participating voluntarily, and that this waiver is intended to be as broad and inclusive as permitted by applicable law.
Event Changes: Bars and venues may change, but the event will continue rain or shine. Always check the digital crawl map for the latest venue list and updates. Be sure to check your email for any last-minute updates.
*By purchasing a ticket, you confirm that you have read, understood, and agreed to all disclaimers, terms, and conditions stated above, and accept full responsibility for your participation in the event.

description:
Family event: Explore Omnibirding with Giselle Clarkson, We are thrilled and delighted to announce we are going to be hosting a fabulous school holiday event with the multi-award winning Giselle Clarkson to celebrate the release of her latest book Omnibird: An Avian Investigator’s Handbook, a guide to the art and science of omnibirding.
Giselle Clarkson, the author of The Observologist, will be in Tawa for this very special event to explore the inner workings of the book and delights and wonders of the avian world.
Some birds are so commonplace it’s easy to forget how extraordinary they are. These creatures have a secret eyelid, hollow bones and a two-part brain. They dress in feathers. Omnibird, explores what’s remarkable about the birds all around us and the clues we can all use to become avian investigators.
Giselle is an author, illustrator and cartoonist based in Greytown, known for her work on conservation and environmental topics. She has illustrated award-winning picture books and nonfiction and is a 2023 Arts Foundation Laureate, receiving the prestigious Mallinson Rendel Illustrators Award.
This promises to be an unmissable event for bird and nature lovers of any age.
Books for sale thanks to the Children's Bookshop.
We wish to extend our thanks to Gecko Press for helping make this event happen.
This is a free event.
We expect this event to be very popular so to secure your seat early arrival is suggested.

description:
Sir Ian Athfield Memorial Lecture 2025 | Whakatū Nelson, Te Kāhui Whaihanga New Zealand Institute of Architects are excited to welcome Ian Moore to New Zealand to present this year’s lecture series ‘The Past Needs a Future’ which will focus on adaptive reuse.
Ian is the principal of Ian Moore Architects, established in 1990. The practice has won numerous Australian and international awards and has been published and exhibited widely, including at the Venice Architecture Biennale in 2008 and 2012.
Initially studying civil and structural engineering at the Auckland Technical Institute in New Zealand, Ian moved on to study architecture at the University of Technology, Sydney, graduating with honours in 1988.
Ian has taught at numerous universities and been a speaker and guest lecturer throughout Australia as well as internationally.
Ian has also been a member of awards juries in Australia, New Zealand and at the World Festival of Interiors in 2013 and the World Architecture Festival in 2015. In 2003, Ian was the inaugural Creative Director for the Australian Institute of Architects annual conference.
About the Sir Ian Athfield Memorial Lecture
The annual Sir Ian Athfield Memorial Lecture commemorates the late Ian Athfield, a singular and much-loved figure in New Zealand architecture.
Affectionately known as ‘Ath’, Ian was knighted in 2014 and was one of New Zealand’s most influential architects. He won more than 60 national and international architecture and design awards and the lecture series was established to honour his legacy and celebrate his larrikin spirit.
In keeping with that spirit, each year the lecture is given by a person with something to say – someone who is challenging orthodoxy and a business-as-usual approach to practice, and life.
During his career, Ath designed many significant buildings, none more so than his own home in Te Whanganui-a-Tara Wellington, which enraged the neighbours, perplexed the Council and inspired the city for decades.
Ath was talented, original, insightful, opinionated, provocative, and sometimes outrageous. His architecture is stimulating, challenging, ever-changing, but never careless.
In 2004, Te Kāhui Whaihanga New Zealand Institute of Architects awarded Ath the Gold Medal for career achievements, noting at the time “What defines Athfield above all is his contagious enthusiasm, his devotion to architecture, and his unswerving belief in its possibilities. Believing architecture to be a civilising force, he has demonstrated a strong commitment to architecture’s public realm: the streets we live in; the urban centres we inhabit; the countryside we love and so often abuse.”
The Sir Ian Athfield Lecture Series is proudly sponsored by Resene.

description:
Waikanae drop-in session | Reserve Management Plan, Waikanae drop-in session | Reserve Management Plan
Drop- in to Waikanae Park by the old skatepark to chat to us about the Reserve Management Plan.

Council manages over 130 parks and reserves on your behalf – from playgrounds, sports grounds, and esplanades to scenic and native reserves.

We’re drafting an omnibus Reserve Management Plan to set out objectives, polices and rules that guide their use, management, protection and development and want your help. Tell us what you value about your favourite parks and reserves, what might impact their use, protection and enjoyment, and what ideas do you have for their future.

There's lots of ways to have your say - online, on paper and in person.

Come and chat to our Open Space Planning team
Thursday 28 August, 4pm–7pm, Coastlands Shopping Centre
Saturday 30 August, 9am–1pm, Maclean Park, skatepark
Saturday 6 September, 9am–1pm, Waikanae Park, old skatepark
Sunday 14 September, 9am–1pm, Ōtaki Centennial Park

Further information and ways to provide feedback can be found at haveyoursay.kapiticoast.govt.nz/RMP

description:
EBANZ Natural Building Conference 2025, EBANZ Natural Building Conference 2025
This year’s EBANZ (Earth Building Association of New Zealand) national conference will see industry leaders, innovators and enthusiasts come together to profile the latest ideas, technologies and projects shaping the future of low carbon, high performing, sustainable building in Aotearoa.

Set at Te Wānanga o Raukawa and the Forest Lakes Conference Centre on the Kāpiti Coast, the earth building conference will see builders, designers, researchers and earth-building enthusiasts explore how traditional and contemporary earth construction methods are shaping resilient, sustainable futures in Aotearoa and beyond.

Themed ‘Earth, Culture and Community’, the three-day conference in mid-November will include presentations, hands-on workshops, site visits and kōrero with leading voices in natural building, indigenous knowledge, climate-responsive design and regenerative practice, while also profiling New Zealand’s own set of earth building standards (NZS 4297, 4298 and 4299) 2024.

A ‘Professionals Day’ on Friday 14 November at Te Wānanga o Raukawa is aimed specifically at architects, engineers, inspectors, builders and designers interested in earth and natural building techniques. It will dive into the Tennent Brown Architects-designed Pā Reo campus at Te Wānanga (a Living Building Challenge project) and presenters will include Rau Hoskins of designTRIBE, Verena Maeder of Solid Earth and Sigi Koko, founder of Build Naturally USA.

Friday will be followed by the in-depth weekend conference at Forest Lakes, featuring talks and presentations aimed to inform and empower people on different aspects of earth and natural building as well as hands-on workshops in different methods and materials, including clay-based plasters, cob, rammed earth and adobe, straw bale and hempcrete. House tours will feature different building techniques, including straw bale and rammed earth, adobe, natural plasters and more.
label: Conservation & Environment

description:
Humans: Why & What To Do, Humans: Why & What To Do
An evening of inspiration & indulgence! Talk by Devamrita Swami followed by a plant-powered dinner & dessert.

We’re the most connected generation in history — and somehow the loneliest. We’ve built more technology than any civilisation before us — and still can’t solve our basic problems. We talk endlessly about progress — while the planet burns and mental health plummets.

What if the trouble isn’t just what we’re doing… but that we’ve forgotten why we’re doing it?

In this bold talk, Devamrita Swami — a world-traveling monk, strategist, and social critic — unpacks the mess we’re in and asks the questions most of us avoid: Why are we here? And what should we actually be doing about it?

Afterwards, stick around for a plant-based dinner and dessert — fresh, colourful, and made to share. Grab a plate, grab a seat, and dive into real conversations with people who are curious, open-minded, and up for something different.

Meet Devamrita Swami, your host
Devamrita Swami is an educator, author, and monk who has spent over forty years exploring and sharing the wisdom of bhakti-yoga. He brings ancient Vedic teachings to life, effortlessly navigating the latest research in archaeology, consciousness, ancient history, neuroscience, social science, and psychology. Author of Searching for Vedic India and Hiding in Unnatural Happiness, he combines philosophy with practical insights on happiness, wellbeing, and personal fulfillment. For anyone seeking to channel the human drive for fulfilment in a meaningful and sustainable way, Devamrita Swami offers clear, engaging, and indispensable wisdom.

Paint and Wine Night in Wellington - Your Friendly Cow, The concept is simple - take a brush in one hand, a drink in the other and let’s paint a masterpiece!

Join us for a creative night of drinking and painting in the heart of Wellington! No previous painting experience necessary. Get your creative juices flowing and your brush strokes going!

Drinks: No drinks are included in the ticket price, but drinks are available for purchase.

Food: A delicious menu will be available to purchase throughout the event.

What is Paintvine?
It’s a fun social painting class where our artists will run you through step-by-step instructions on how to create your very own masterpiece in a fun and relaxed bar setting. Perfect for dates, catching up with mates or for meeting new friends!

We provide all the materials you need (high-quality canvas, acrylic paint, brushes). All you need to bring is your creative spirit (or find some at the bottom of a glass). At the end of the night you will leave with your own painting ready to hang up on your wall.

For tickets, future events, FAQs and more info head to the Paintvine website.

description:
Improv On a Plate - a Comedy Show, Welcome to Improv on a Plate, the comedy tasting menu no one ordered and everyone regrets. In this unholy fusion of high-stakes improv and low-stakes judgment, three deranged guest chefs (aka format-pitchers) take the stage with one mission: serve up the most unhinged, impossible improv formats they can dream of.

Enter: Catfish Trifecta — your unsuspecting improv victims — who must swallow each cursed format whole and perform it on the spot. No script. No escape. Just raw, unfiltered chaos served à la mode.

The pitchers then get to sit back, relax, and judge the madness they’ve unleashed. It’s improv. It’s pain. It’s Improv on a Plate.

One night only. No refunds. BYO palate cleanser.

* Meditation: Guided meditation to help you find inner peace and clarity.
* Soundbath: A deeply relaxing experience using crystal singing bowls to promote healing and reduce stress.

Private message me if you’d like to join or for more information .

Meet the Characters from Kiwi's Big Hararei show at Zealandia!, These school holidays, Zealandia Te Māra a Tāne will become the playground of a host of incredible critters from Circa Theatre's current children's show Kiwi's Big Hararei!
Brought to you by award-winning company, Horse With No Name, this free "Meet the Characters" event features an amazing array of manu, including kiwi, tūī, kārearea, and tītīpounamu.
The cast of Kiwi's Big Hararei will wow tamariki with a sneak peek of their show, featuring original waiata by Aotearoa singer-songwriter, Benny Tipene. They will also kōrero about the unique adaptations of these manu and how we can all be kaitiaki of them.
Bring your tamariki along to engage with these colourful creatures, with stunning costume design by GRIDLEY by Victoria. Musical performance, native biodiversity, and interactive theatre combine on the Heritage Lawn for an afternoon of spring fun in the sun! The team of talented children’s entertainers from Horse With No Name is so excited to share a snippet of their show Kiwi's Big Hararei with you.
Kiwi's Big Hararei will be playing at Circa Theatre over the school holidays until 4 October: https://www.circa.co.nz/package/kiwis-big-hararei/
General Admission fees to the sanctuary apply, free entry for members. Should the weather turn, this event will be held the foyer of the Visitor Centre on the ground floor. Overflow carparking is available at Birdwood Street during the busy school holiday period.

Poroporoaki for Rosalie & Welcome to Elizabeth & Shaquille, Kia ora e te whānau EHF,
You're invited to a very special evening!
Join us on Wednesday 27 August at 5:30pm for a heart-filled poroporoaki, a chance to celebrate Rosalie Nelson, and to officially welcome our new Co-Executive Directors, Elizabeth McNaughton and Shaquille Shortland.
📍 Te Wharewaka Function Centre, Wellington
🕔 Doors open at 5:00pm | Welcome begins at 5:30pm sharp
🕢 Event concludes by 7:30pm
👔 Dress: Business casual
To RSVP (button)
To register to join online (button)
This will be a joyful evening of reflection, reconnection and looking ahead. Whether you're joining us in person or online, we’d love to have you in the room (or on the screen!) as we mark this milestone in the life of the Fellowship. You are also welcome to bring your partner.
In te ao Māori, a poroporoaki is more than a farewell; it's a ritual of transition and gratitude. A moment to steady the waka, acknowledge the hands that have guided it, and prepare together for the voyage ahead.
We’ll honour Rosalie’s contribution, and we’ll raise a glass to Elizabeth and Shaquille as they step into their new roles. Expect warmth, good company, big-hearted kōrero and a few surprises too.
If you're planning to attend in person and haven’t yet booked travel, now’s a good time to do so.

Ngā manaakitanga,
The EHF Board

description:
Native Plant Papermaking Kids Workshop, Native Plant Papermaking Kids Workshop
Do you know a child who loves craft and making a splash? Join us for a fun family papermaking session!

We’ll be getting our hands wet as we explore the creative world of handmade paper using native harakeke (NZ flax) pulp. You will start off learning the simple skills of how to form a sheet of paper from wet pulp, then develop these skills by making different shapes and sizes, such as sheets, cards, envelopes, and ornaments. Express your own flair by experimenting with bits and pieces to add different colours and textures to your creations.

This workshop is designed for kids and accompanying adults to enjoy together. Adults are expected to assist hands-on and join the fun. Ages 5 and up.
