description:
I-Sarn Thai KanTok, Join Daeng from Tuk Tuk Thai for a deeply personal culinary journey to the heart of E-Sarn, the north-eastern region of Thailand she once called home. This one-night-only event celebrates the traditional Kan-Tok style of dining – a communal meal served on handwoven bamboo trays and shared amongst family and friends. This event is made to be shared, the ticket price is for a shared menu for two. 

Growing up in the small town of Tha Bo near the Mekong Delta, Daeng’s childhood was filled with stories of rice farming, village generosity, and dishes cooked from what the garden offered. In E-Sarn, meals were acts of love, shared daily around the Kan-Tok with laughter, music, and warmth.

Now, Daeng invites you to gather at her table and experience the flavours of her upbringing. You’ll be served nine traditional dishes on a beautifully crafted bamboo tray, designed for sharing, just as they are in her village.

On the Kan-Tok:
Hor Mok Salmon – Steamed salmon in banana leaves, marinated with herbs, spices, and coconut milk
Mok Nor Mai with Pork Belly – Pork belly steamed with bamboo shoots
Larb Gai – A celebratory chicken mince salad with fresh herbs and toasted rice
E-Sarn Sausages – House-made, spiced and fermented in true north-eastern style
Nam Prik Tomato – Roasted tomato dipping sauce with chillies, garlic, and shallots
Som Tum – Green papaya salad with a sweet, sour, spicy kick
Sticky Rice – Soaked overnight and steamed in traditional bamboo baskets
Fresh and Steamed Seasonal Vegetables – To enjoy with sauces and mains

Dessert:
Kanom Chan – Thai layered jelly cake
Kanom Mun – Tapioca and coconut pudding

Pull up a seat at Daeng’s table and discover the stories, flavours, and traditions that shaped her childhood.
Single tickets or odd numbers unable to be catered to.
label: Food & Drink

description:
String Bean Puppets: Once In a Full Moon, Be captivated these school holidays by the gorgeous puppet show, Once in a Full Moon, performed by Anna Bailey of String Bean Puppets.

Deep in the bush, a lonely kiwi looks up at the sky and mistakes the full moon for a giant egg. Can kiwis fly? Can moons fall from the sky? Can wishes come true? This magical string puppet adventure introduces the audience to an intimate encounter with a few of Aotearoa New Zealand's special native creatures.

description:
JETAA Wellington - Brewkaiwa September @ Mean Doses, We will be having our September Brewkaiwa at Mean Doses, a bold and modern craft brewery in the heart of Wellington. Known for its inventive beers and laid-back atmosphere, it’s the perfect place to share a drink and good conversation.
Brewkaiwa is JETAA’s monthly casual meetup for anyone with any connection to Japan.
We’re a diverse group of people who have studied, worked, or lived in Japan or have been invited along by someone who has.
Come join us for a brew and stay for the kaiwa! Bring your friends!
***Japanese or alcohol consumption NOT REQUIRED!***
Brewkaiwaとは
一杯いかがですか？
JETAAがウェリントンで親睦会を開催するとどうなるのか？その結果、BREWKAIWA！
2020年に始まった、ブリューカイワは、ウェリントンの様々なバーで毎月開催されている飲み会です。大人気の国際交流グルップです！！！ 日本で働いたり、住んだり、旅行したことのある人達に人気のあるイベントです！！！お酒を飲んで、友達を出来、素敵なごちそうを食べ、おまけに異文化を知られます！
日本語が話せる外国人も良く参加しているので、日本語しか話せなくても全然大丈夫です！
是非来てください！

You will be visiting 4 of our favourite local sites including: Passo, The Waterfront, Saltys and Hey Coastie. At each venue you will have the chance to try a delicious canape and a beverage that showcases Kapiti's favourite suppliers and producers.

description:
Wairarapa Youth Orchestra: Around The World With Music, Get ready for a global classical musical journey as the Wairarapa Youth Orchestra presents their special concert, “Around the World with Music”!
The vibrant sounds of violins, flutes, cellos, trombones, and more will fill the Wairarapa Events Centre, Carterton as our young musicians from across the Wairarapa share their hard work. These talented tamariki and rangatahi are now ready to take you on an unforgettable adventure through sound.

Under the expert guidance of conductor Andrew Atkins and our dedicated tutors, the Wairarapa Youth Orchestra has been diligently preparing a diverse program that celebrates music from various continents. Prepare to be captivated by everything from the rhythmic pulse of African drums to the sweeping melodies of European symphonies, including the grandeur and pomp of Tchaikovsky’s 1812 Overture, and evocative folk tunes echoing the sounds of Asia. It’s a unique opportunity to experience a rich tapestry of sounds, all brought to life by the passion and talent of our local youth.

This inspiring event is more than just a performance; it’s a vital fundraiser. The Wairarapa Youth Orchestra offers free orchestral music learning to young people throughout the Wairarapa, and we rely entirely on fundraising and donations to keep this invaluable program thriving. Your attendance directly supports the continued musical education of our community’s youth.
label: Music & Concerts

description: Marine Reserves Seminar: Fish Breeding & Biodiversity, A seminar on the importance of marine reserves for fish breeding and biodiversity. Hear from a marine biologist on how marine reserves help protect marine life, the unique species that live in them, and the ongoing conservation efforts to protect our oceans.

Snacks will be served between each tasting while you remove your blindfold, take notes and make your guesses.

description:
Love Language, Calling budding poets and hopeless romantics - this is your opportunity to share your love of language, with a food and poetry degustation. 
This four-course dinner is a physical manifestation of love and an ode to food. Join Simon Sweetman, Wellington writer, critic, musician and poet, as he reads some of his own poetry, and yours too if you're feeling game. Chefs Tim and Aaron Banks will lovingly create a four-course dinner with ingredients locally sourced and lovingly produced by small scale sustainable farmers... and perhaps they will read their own poems too. 
If you're feeling poetic bring along your own poem specially crafted around this year's festival theme 'Food is Love'. It can be as long or short as you like, as happy or sad, comical or tragic, Keats or Bukowski. Spot prizes for various categories including 'Most Related to the Theme' and 'Most Obviously Foodie' poems. Includes four courses, and a welcome glass of bubbles on arrival.
label: Food & Drink

description:
Le Petit Chef, InterContinental Wellington proudly presents the first official Le Petit Chef experience in New Zealand - an extraordinary fusion of theatre, storytelling, and fine dining.

Step into the whimsical animated world of Le Petit Chef, the world’s tiniest and most determined chef, as he embarks on a globe-trotting quest to source the finest ingredients. Using groundbreaking 3D projection mapping technology, your table transforms into a magical stage, where continents shift, spices fly, and the art of cooking comes thrillingly to life before your eyes.

As the journey unfolds, a five-course menu is served in perfect harmony with the story. Highlights include Wairarapa crayfish bouillabaisse, corn-fed chicken with Perigord truffle, and a decadent Valrhona chocolate dessert. Choose from the Grand Menu ($180), Classic Menu ($140), Vegetarian Menu ($140), or a dedicated Kids Menu $70). While each menu offers a distinct culinary experience, the stunning visual show remains the same for all guests and is centered around the Grand Menu storyline.

Please note, while primarily designed for individual bookings, some shared seating may apply due to the technical nature of the performance.
label: Food & Drink

description:
Book Group: Heart of A Dog By Mikhail Bulgakov, Wellington Classic Literature Group meets on the first Tuesday of the month. We read novels that have stood the test of time, whether they were written in 1780, 1880 or even 1980. It's a public group so feel free to come along when it suits.

Our September book is Heart of a Dog (or A Dog's Heart), a 1925 novel by Mikhail Bulgakov, described as a biting satire of Bolshevism. The book wasn't officially published in the Soviet Union until 1987.

Our group very much enjoyed Bulgakov's masterpiece The Master and Margarita back in 2018, so looking forward to reading another of his works...

VENUE
We meet in the ‘Games Room’, The Library bar's private area overlooking Courtenay Place. After you enter the bar, head to your right (up the step) and through a smaller space with booths to the large carpeted space beyond.
label: Hobbies & Interests

description:
Lunch Speaker Series, Noble Rot invites you to enjoy a relaxed lunch in style. While away your afternoon with a leisurely three-course menu as they keep the wine flowing amongst you and your friends. They've lined up two incredible guest speakers at the forefront of the wine industry to entertain you with their stories, knowledge and insights into current trends in a relaxed but intimate atmosphere. You'll wish all learning was done this way. It’s the perfect excuse to treat your friends, your mum or your date.
 
Guest Speakers & Dates:

Saturday 9th — ‘Small Region, Big Sky’
Katherine Jacobs and her husband Jeremy embarked on a dream to produce some of Martinborough’s finest wines from their special vineyard in Te Muna, and they’ve achieved great success! Katherine will speak about upcoming trends, big dreams and hidden secrets in our favourite region’s wine scene.
 
Saturday 23rd — ‘A Rosie Afternoon’ 
Enjoy the company of Rosie Finn of Neudorf Vineyards, second generation of one of New Zealand's most prestigious wineries in Nelson. You’ll have the opportunity to ask Rosie all about current trends as she combines the story of her family winery’s historic roots and its impact on the landscape of New Zealand fine wines.
label: Food & Drink

description:
Macaron Masterclass, MACARON MASTERCLASS
Presented by Le Ciel Bakery
Whisk, pipe, and finesse your way to perfect Parisian macarons

Join us for a hands-on masterclass where you’ll learn the secrets to mastering this delicate French treat — from glossy meringue to flawless feet. Led by Chef Shuchi Bhardwaj, this is your golden ticket to boujee baking greatness.

- Create & take home your own box of beautifully filled macarons
- Learn foolproof techniques, flavour infusions, and piping styles
- Start your evening with a complimentary glass of bubbles and a decadent Black Forest cake for two—because love (and baking) should always begin on a sweet note.

What you’ll learn:
- Mastering macaronage & piping flawless heart shapes
- Avoiding common meringue mishaps
- Chef’s expert tips for achieving that perfect crisp-yet-chewy texture

Only 12 people per class—an intimate setting where you’ll have Chef Shuchi’s full attention and guidance. Whether you're baking with your sweetheart, bestie, or favorite foodie, this experience is sure to be equal parts fun, romantic, and delicious.

Location: Le Ciel, 100 Tory street, Wellington
$62 per person
Limited spots are available—book now before they’re gone!
label: Food & Drink

description:
Men's Singing Workshop with Julian Raphael, Exciting news for men who love to sing ... Julian Raphael is returning to the Wellington region to offer a one day men's singing workshop. It's open to all men who enjoy singing together in harmony. 
This special workshop will feature popular music from the 1960s, songs from Aotearoa and songs of the sea.
Julian is well-known for his masterful song-leading and arrangements for men's voices - including MaleVocale and the Taranaki Songmen.
Places are limited so singers are encouraged to book early.
Where: Paremata Boating Club, 110 Paremata Road. Right on the water overlooking Pauatahanui inlet.
What to bring: Bring your own lunch or some food to share.
Parking: By north end of Mana Bridge; at Paremata Railway Station; or at Ivey Bay parking area.
Further information:
Bernard Dougherty (0274 443 929) Tim Carthew (021 51 99 40)

description:
Maille Sunday Kai, Escape the winter chill and head along to Cuba St Tavern for some Sunday Kai with Maille Mustard, running every Sunday of August. Each week features a different delectable roast, served with either a Maille Dijon Bloody Mary or warming mulled wine, and finished with a house-made dessert. Sunday has never tasted so good! Bookings available from 1pm.

$50 for 2 courses
$65 for 2 courses inc a Maille Bloody Mary or House made Mulled wine

Menu
Every Maille Sunday Kai event will offer a vegetarian option of eggplant parmigiana with buffalo mozzarella, Maille Dijon mustard, tomato ragù, garlic potato and broccolini.

3 August
Free-range roast porchetta served with garlic potato, creamed spinach, broccolini, Yorkshire pudding, Maille wholegrain mustard jus and apple sauce.
Dessert: Sticky toffee pudding with custard.

10 August
Roast duck breast served with duck fat roast potatoes, Chinese broccoli, mushrooms, Yorkshire pudding, and Maille Dijon mustard and onion cream.
Dessert: Dark chocolate torte with orange mascarpone.

17 August
Conscious Valley roast lamb shoulder with garlic roast potatoes, honey-glazed carrots, minted peas, Yorkshire pudding, Maille wholegrain mustard jus and mint sauce.
Dessert: Bread and butter pudding with ginger gelato and crème anglaise.

24 August
Half a roast chicken with duck fat roast potatoes, garlic green beans, cavolo nero, Yorkshire pudding, chicken schmaltz and Maille mustard gravy.
Dessert: Steamed honey pudding with custard and honey gelato.

31 August
First Light roast sirloin served with honey-glazed carrots, duck fat roast potatoes, cabbage and bacon, Yorkshire pudding, horseradish, Maille Dijon mustard and jus.
Dessert: Chocolate fondant with vanilla bean gelato.

Inspired by playful and nostalgic flavours, over three nights Garage Project will bring back the spirit of the original 2015 Milk Bar event while offering something fresh for first-timers. description: Milk Bar, Garage Project and Glou Glou are teaming up to showcase beer’s sweeter side and let the malt shine. This indulgent collaboration pairs a range of Glou Glou's famous pastries, fried chicken and other showstoppers with Garage Project favourites, a curated selection of dessert beers, and two exclusive brews crafted especially for the event. Inspired by playful and nostalgic flavours, over three nights Garage Project will bring back the spirit of the original 2015 Milk Bar event while offering something fresh for first-timers. A must for anyone with a sweet tooth and a love of bold beer.
label: Food & Drink

description:
Talk the Walk: Preparing for An Overnight Tramp, This talk is aimed at people considering their first overnight tramp. Celia Wade-Brown walked Te Araroa in 2017, and will be leading the Wairarapa Walking Festival two-day tramp from Waiohine to Holdsworth on 21st - 22nd November 2025. Celia will bring her overnight backpack and show the gear she is taking on the tramp.

The talk will cover: food and drink, hut wear, toileting tips, keeping your sleeping bag dry, emergency communications, and looking after your feet.

Bring your questions!
Adam Philps from Masterton Foot Clinic, a festival sponsor will be joining us to talk feet and things to consider.

Murray Johnston, chair of Wairarapa Land Search and Rescue will also be speaking. Please bring a gold coin to donate to WaiLandSAR.

Please register for this session.
label: Hobbies & Interests

description:
Mystery Feast on Mischief Night! Halloween dinner with Chef Max Gordy
Supporting Kaibosh., Step inside, if you dare... on the eve of Halloween. It's a Mischief Night!
A chilling murder mystery unfolds over a hauntingly good three-course Halloween dinner by Chef Max Gordy!
On 30 October, gather your cleverest friends and find your darkest ghoulish attire
Who will crack the case first: the Detectives or the Villains?

Expect twists, laughter, and a touch of fright
with spot prizes through the night — plus a reward for the best-dressed.
Award-winning chef Max Gordy ( @grazewinebar ) will conjure up a frightfully delicious Halloween-themed feast.
Your ticket includes one complimentary alcoholic beverage (with more available to purchase on the night).
Every ticket sold helps Kaibosh ensure that no good food is left to die.
TICKET TYPES
Bring a team of six to solve the mystery and devour a fiendishly good feast for $666.
Have a frightening four-some? Book a table for $444.
Spooky single seats available for $111... we will seat you at a mystery table...
VENUE
60 Dixon Street is up a flight of steep steps – with only one way in.
What is Mischief Night?
In parts of Pennsylvania and New Jersey in the eastern USA, 30 October is called “Mischief Night.” The tradition refers to the eve of Halloween in which children and teenagers celebrate the holiday one night early with pranks, tricks and more. While in New England, some call it Cabbage Night...
label: Food & Drink

description:
North City Crack Chicken x Heinz Fried Chicken Sauce Pop-Up, Heinz’s fan-favourite Fried Chicken Sauce has finally landed in Aotearoa, and it’s making its NZ debut in style – with a limited-time pop-up collab at Crack Chicken. Already a hit with fried chicken fans overseas for its creamy, sweet and spicy kick, the sauce is now hitting Crack Chicken menus nationwide for one week only.

On the special menu:
- The Supreme Chicken Burger (crispy fried chicken, slaw, pickles and a generous layer of sauce)

- Crack Chicken’s golden Blooming Onion made for dipping,

- Plus the option to add the new Heinz Fried Chicken Sauce to anything and everything on the menu.

When: Friday 3 – Sunday 12 October 2025

Where:
- Crack Chicken Ponsonby – 168 Ponsonby Road, Auckland
- Crack Chicken Hamilton - Made Mess Hall - 401 Grey Street, Hamilton East
- Crack Chicken Willis Lane – 1 Willis Street, Wellington Central
- Crack Chicken North City - North City Mall – Porirua

Hot tip: Sauce lovers and fried chicken fans won’t want to miss this limited-time pop-up – once it’s gone, it’s gone.

description:
Nutcracker High Tea, QTea twirls into a sun-drenched daydream with a high tea inspired by The Nutcracker. In partnership with the Royal New Zealand Ballet, we’re serving a festive fairytale where Christmas meets choreography – with a Kiwiana twist.

Perched above the harbour, QTea High Tea reimagines its plated treats into a sugar plum dreamland. Think raspberry-layered delights, golden pistachio choux, smoked salmon cups and piroshki that dance on the palate.

Sip in style and cheers to the season with The Mouse King’s Toast, Prosecco and Guignolet fizzing with festive sparkle. Craving something a little nuttier? Try The Storm Master’s Tipple. For pure summer magic in a glass, reach for the Sugar Plum Fairy Fizz.

description:
Next Gen Cook Off, The Next Gen Cook Off returns for its fifth year, and things are heating up at Everybody Eats.
Every Monday in August, four of Wellington’s freshest young chefs will go head-to-head in a high-energy kitchen takeover, serving up epic three-course dinners using rescued food.

Each chef will be given the same protein, generously provided by Meat Direct, but everything else is a surprise—ingredients are revealed that morning, based on what’s come in. Menus are created on the spot, and dishes are served to a buzzing, hungry crowd. It’s fast-paced, creative chaos with serious culinary skills on display. Guests get a front-row seat to the action, while supporting a truly game-changing enterprise.

4 August — Jessie Gibberd, Loretta
Originally from rural Waikato, Jessie Gibberd made the move to Wellington to study, but it was the buzz of hospitality that captured her heart. Swapping textbooks for tongs, she left her degree behind to dive headfirst into the kitchen. Now a chef de partie at Loretta, Jessie brings a grounded, fresh perspective to one of the city’s most beloved eateries.

11 August — Felipe Molina, El Matador
Hailing from Chile, Felipe Molina is a professional chef with over 15 years of experience in kitchens around the world. Having worked in several countries and world-class restaurants, Felipe brings a global sensibility to his craft. With a passion for seafood, meats, and bold, expressive flavours, his cooking is shaped by travel and tradition, blending international influence with creativity on every plate.

18 August — Zane Gupwell, Graze
Zane Gupwell began his hospitality journey at just 15, washing dishes at a local café in Mount Eden. From there, he headed to Queenstown, learning from a wide range of chefs and kitchen styles before challenging himself with a move to Wellington. Since then, he’s worked at some of the city’s top restaurants and now brings his thoughtful, evolving style to Graze Wine Bar.

25 August — Lulu Temmuyin, Mr Go’s
Lulu Temmuyin is a chef who loves pushing boundaries, even when they’re unexpected. Lactose intolerant but obsessed with cheese, and not a fan of lamb but winner of a lamb cooking competition, Lulu is all about surprises. At Mr Go’s, she brings bold, sustainable flavour to the forefront, blending personality with punch in every dish.

Everybody Eats runs on a pay-what-you-can model, transforming food waste into gourmet meals and bringing the community together over good kai. The Next Gen Cook Off celebrates and champions this mission, proving that rescued food can be next-level delicious.

The Next Gen Cook Off is proudly supported by The Gas Hub.
label: Food & Drink

description:
Nyumbani: A Taste of Tanzania, Journey through the heart of Tanzania with dishes that feel like home - comforting, bold, and full of love. This special five-course degustation is created by Chef Shuchi Bhardwaj, a baker who grew up in Tanzania and carries its flavours, traditions, and warmth in her heart. 
Whether it’s the warm embrace of coconut-infused stews, smoky grilled meats, or fragrant spiced rice, each course is a reminder of how food connects us. This menu brings authentic East African flavours to the table, reimagined in a modern way that feels like home. Each course is matched with a carefully selected wine to enhance the flavours of the dish. Expect generous hospitality and a setting that feels like stepping into a Tanzanian family gathering.
label: Food & Drink

description:
Explore Healing For Self - Monthly Event, Explore Healing For Self - Monthly Event
Tania loves creating & holding sacred space for people & in this monthly event she will be creating a space where you can focus on your own healing journey in a group environment. In each session you will be guided through clearing, releasing, healing & remembering processes to help & assist you. We will explore different tools, processes & modalities each time to experience the highest possible energetic shift that is possible at that time.

Each month will have a different focus & flavour with the intention of working on yourself in a safe held space.
Over the next 4 sessions we will explore:

The 12 Chakra system, tools to use to help clear & heal the chakras and then enjoy a beautiful energy healing with the Archangels that are connected to each of the chakras.

Angelic Reiki - Receive an Angelic Cleansing, releasing old karmic connections with Archangel Michael, followed by a group healing with the angels wanting to connect with you.

Full Sensory Perception tools through Pleiadian Lightwork - an explanation on how the tools may feel & work & being in those energies & frequencies to receive the clearing & healing that is possible.

Access Bars - How ‘running the bars’ can help, some key points to use for stress or healing, running clearing statements to release old beliefs & patterns. What else is possible & how does it get any better than this.

There is a lot to explore & embrace and there may be additional processes brought in as Tania is guided or as time allows.

First Tuesday of the month 10am-12pm $30


Tania is a gifted intuitive and holistic practitioner, known for her grounded presence and loving guidance. She is an Angelic Reiki Master Teacher, Pleiadian Lightwork Practitioner & Teacher, conscious channeler, and Access Bars Practitioner. With a rich background in intuitive and energy work, she brings a nurturing and empowering energy to both group workshops and one-on-one sessions.

Bookings are essential. Email Tania:

For more details Text/Phone Tania : 021 030 6507

Venue: the studio @ the art and living space, 17 Bradey Road, Pauatahanui

The Rotten Luck Club is at the Pop-up Parlour!

Come along for a 2 hour cheese-making demonstration and tasting session! Local enthusiast Erin will guide us through the process and share her love for all things cheese.

• What - 2 hr workshop where you'll be shown how to making a fresh batch of cheese (probably halloumi and maybe also paneer), and everyone can take some home.
• When - 2pm-4pm, 28 September 2025
• Where - St Marks, 98 Rāwhiti Road, Pukerua Bay (opposite school)
• Cost - $10 per person BOOK NOW ( https://tinyurl.com/5n7twce7)
• What to bring? Anything yummy for the tasting session. Bonus points if it is home made.
• Who - Kids welcome to join but they will need their own ticket and must be supervised by a caregiver at all times.

We will also have a tasting session of different types of cheeses for everyone to sample.

Bring any questions you have and you'll be able to look at the range of equipment used too. Will have tips and tricks for setting up at home, including sourcing the right type of milk and getting your hands on some rennet.

description:
MESSIE - Wellington, MESSIE is taking Aotearoa’s electronic dance music scene to filthy new levels. As a former drummer, her passion for drumming was the pipeline for her falling in love with genres like Garage, Breakbeat, and Jungle. She has since expanded her sound and it’s safe to say each set will keep you guessing what will come next as she effortlessly merges genres such as Baile Funk, Ghetto Tech, Jersey Club, Juke, Afro beat inspired drums, Techno and many more global club soundscapes that encompass her high energy DJ sets. MESSIE’s sets are guaranteed to be bootleg heavy with something for everyone as she draws from her own music taste of rap and grime, to early 2000’s singalongs, girl-boss anthems and queer music culture in the form of edits you’d never expect.

Alongside her headline tour around Aotearoa in mid 2024, MESSIE has now brought her fresh, high-energy club music to Glastonbury, Reading & Leeds, R&V, Beyond The Valley, Wildlands, Love Saves The Day, Gemfest & Outro Festival. With slots at Pohoda Festival, Hidden Festival, Motion, Truck Festival, AIASOUND and All Points East locked in for the second half of 2025, there is no slowing her down.
label: Music & Concerts

description:
Santa Cipolla, “Holy Onion”. For the entire month, Cicio Cacio Osteria is getting brave and bold, celebrating the magic of vegetables in all their glory, especially the santa cipolla (aka the holy onion). 
Vegetables bring colour, life and joy. In Italy, they mark the rhythm of the seasons, stir up cherished memories and signal the excitement of fresh beginnings. Come along and experience vibrant flavours with playful snacks, fun street food, freshly baked breads, handmade pasta and a brand new range of dishes that celebrate the beauty, bounty and simplicity of Italian cuisine.

description: Santiago to Buenos Aires, Noble Rot sommeliers Maciej Zimny and Jessica Wood invite you to embark on their recent road trip through Chile and Argentina. They will indulge you with stories and share their experiences through these two fantastic wine countries alongside a South American themed five-course degustation menu including dishes they enjoyed on their journey. Relax and enjoy their tales and insight into why the wines taste the way they do, the key stylistic differences between the two countries, and learn from them first-hand the secrets of why Chilean and Argentine wines are ones to watch in the future.

description:
Saturday 'BAKES' By Onslow College, Each Saturday, we offer a variety of sourdough products next to Onslow College. We always have doughnuts, but on Saturdays we offer bread, savoury baked items (this Saturday, we have brioche), and mini-celebratory sourdough doughnuts.
All products can be pre-ordered and picked up on Saturday morning through our website.
https://familykitchenwithmark.co.nz/weekly-menu/
EFTPOS is always available.
Our boxed mini-celebratory doughnuts, 70% of the original size, are available for a sale price of $25 for a box of all six flavours.
Our regular doughnuts cost $6 each or $22 for a box of 4 doughnuts.
We also offer catering at Family Kitchen with Mark, so if you have a function or need for in-house dining, check out all our packages on our website. Our doughnuts are also available for purchase all week. Contact Mark on 021 0223 0824 for next-day pickup.
https://familykitchenwithmark.co.nz/grazing-tables-theme.../
All our doughnuts contain a lively sourdough & biga starter, for a fuller flavour profile and a springy texture.
Have you tried our sourdough doughnuts yet?
Our doughnuts can be pre-ordered and picked up on the day to avoid disappointment (should we run out).
We launch a new flavour every two weeks and have created over 180 combinations since selling three years ago.
Support has been phenomenal, and we thank everyone so very much indeed for the weekly sales.

The Rotten Luck Club is at the Pop-up Parlour!

Come along for a 2 hour cheese-making demonstration and tasting session! Local enthusiast Erin will guide us through the process and share her love for all things cheese.

• What - 2 hr workshop where you'll be shown how to making a fresh batch of cheese (probably halloumi and maybe also paneer), and everyone can take some home.
• When - 2pm-4pm, 28 September 2025
• Where - St Marks, 98 Rāwhiti Road, Pukerua Bay (opposite school)
• Cost - $10 per person BOOK NOW ( https://tinyurl.com/5n7twce7)
• What to bring? Anything yummy for the tasting session. Bonus points if it is home made.
• Who - Kids welcome to join but they will need their own ticket and must be supervised by a caregiver at all times.

We will also have a tasting session of different types of cheeses for everyone to sample.

Bring any questions you have and you'll be able to look at the range of equipment used too. Will have tips and tricks for setting up at home, including sourcing the right type of milk and getting your hands on some rennet.


Other Rotten Luck Fermentation Club events at the Pop-up:

description:
Sip the Sky: Paint, Sip and Stargaze, Paint:
Begin the evening with a night sky-inspired painting session at Ventana Art Space - 7 Kitchener Street. Whether you're a seasoned artist or picking up a brush for the first time, this relaxed, hands-on experience invites you to create under the spell of twilight tones and celestial charm.

Sip:
Then head next door for a guided wine tasting from the passionate team at The Good Way (located beside the Martinborough Brewery on Ohio Street), showcasing a selection of their elegant, small-batch wines. Find your favourite and grab a bottle to take home—perfect for gifting or continuing the magic later.

Taste:
Indulge your senses with a chocolate tasting hosted by Elly from be happy chocolate. Sample her handcrafted, ethically made bars and select your favourite block to take home. Please advise any dietary requirements when booking. Warm your hands around a velvety be happy hot chocolate and...

Stargaze:
Head outside for a gentle stroll to Considine Park with Charlotte from Wairarapa Dark Sky. Walk in the Dark while sipping hot chocolate. A chance to understand the benefits of the dark sky and finish with some star gazing.

Timing is flexible to allow for moving between locations, if you'd like to order food from The Social Kitchen food truck at the Brewery, etc. The latest finish time would be 8.45pm.
label: Food & Drink

description:
Snacks Amore, When the host brings you bread, instead of a red flag...Snacks Amore!
Amuse Snack Bar invites food lovers to ditch the dating apps for one delicious night of light-hearted speed dating and snack-based bonding at their Euro-inspired aperitivo haven. Whether you are after a snack (human) or a snack (sustenance), you're guaranteed to leave with a full heart and a satisfied appetite.
Each attendee will enjoy 12 mini dates and 6 courses of Italian-inspired snacklets – cacio e pepe, agrodolce, pasta alla norma, porchetta, and zabaione, all served in perfect bite-sized form. A glass of Lambrusco kicks off the evening, with a cheeky mini tiramisu maritozzo to take home. Throughout the event, wines curated by the charming Richard Klein of Artigiano Imports will be on offer, alongside Amuse’s house spritz, Negroni, and Parrotdog Lager.
The atmosphere is relaxed and welcoming – more aperitivo hour than high-pressure matchmaking. The Amuse team, also musicians, will guide the evening with playful icebreakers, musical moments, and a light-touch structure that makes meeting new people easy and enjoyable.
Two themed evenings allow guests to choose their best fit:

Evening 1: General Assembly
Grouped on the night by chosen generation:
• 5:30pm – Millennials (28–45)
• 7:30pm – Gen X (40–60)

Evening 2: Rainbow Night
Grouped by dating preference.
• 6:30pm – she for her upstairs, he for him downstairs.

The event warmly welcomes all gender identities and sexual orientations. Attendees will be asked to indicate who they’re interested in dating at checkout, but gender identity remains private unless individuals wish to share it. Symbols and nametags on the night will help create a fun and inclusive vibe. Amuse Snack Bar is proud to be an LGBTQIA+ friendly space.
label: Food & Drink

description:
Welly Biotech ‘n’ Beers - Speaker Series - September, BioTech N Beers presents the second instalment of its speaker series!
Once a quarter we will be running a fireside chat with those that have been there done that, the up and coming and everything in-between.
Kindly hosted by LabWorks, our speaker will be John Robson telling us about his journey in investment from banks to BioTechs.
Generously sponsored by FB Rice, come along for a yarn, some war stories, and drinks and kai.
Check out John’s bio below and we hope to see you there!
 Event Details:
Date: Friday, 26 September, 2025
Location: Level 10, 76 Manners Street, Wellington
Time: 4:30 pm – 6:30 pm
Speaker: John (JR) Robson
Description: My journey from banks to BioTechs
  About John Robson:
JR is the Managing Director of cell therapy company, BioOra Limited. BioOra addresses both access and scale issues by providing an affordable and accelerated pathway to market for CAR-T therapies via lower cost, high throughput, GMP licensed manufacturing capabilities from clinical trial through to registration and commercialisation.
 JR is also the General Manager of Bridgewest Ventures in New Zealand, and he holds an executive position within the Bridgewest Group, a San Diego based privately held investment company that focuses on disrupting industries through innovation and with investment assets in excess of US$4 billion, and JR is responsible for the deep tech investment programme in New Zealand.
 JR has nearly 30 years of investment experience across global markets and he has been intimately involved in the start-up community in New Zealand since 2008 through a number of early-stage technology companies as an executive and non-executive director. JR regularly writes and speaks about technology in a number of forums and is an avid futurist.
 In addition to his executive roles, JR has been active in the Not-for-Profit ecosystem in New Zealand for 20 years and was the Chair of the National Board of the Child Cancer Foundation for 4 years, and is currently a Board Member of the One Percent Collective Trust. He was awarded Life Membership of the Child Cancer Foundation in 2017 by the Governor-General of New Zealand, Her Excellency The Rt Hon Dame Patsy Reddy, for his services to Childhood Cancer.
 FB Rice:
FB Rice is a leading independent intellectual property firm with a strong focus on biotechnology and the life sciences. With more than 75 years of experience and a dedicated Wellington office, we’re proud to support New Zealand’s growing biotech community through local presence and expertise.
Our Biotechnology Group brings deep scientific and industry knowledge across areas such as gene therapy, diagnostics, biologics, vaccines, and medical technologies. We work closely with clients across academia, research, and industry to protect innovation and support commercial success—offering strategic advice on patentability, prosecution, due diligence, and portfolio management.
As active participants in New Zealand’s innovation ecosystem, we value collaboration and are committed to helping the local biotech sector thrive.
 Lab-Works:
With over 30 years’ experience, Lab-works Architecture are New Zealand’s leading laboratory design architects, with a proven track record across research, teaching, healthcare, and analytical facilities. We believe well-designed laboratories and support spaces enhance capability, productivity, and competitive advantage, so we ensure our clients benefit from best practice in facility planning, design, and technology. Science is always evolving, and so are we—continuously updating our skills and staying at the forefront of new research to deliver leading-edge projects. Through active involvement in international conferences, standards committees, and ongoing research and development in the built environment, we provide design and technical solutions that are robust, fit-for-purpose, and future-focused.

description:
Katie Knowles PAM, Title:
Self-Disclosure of Sexual Dysfunction to Romantic Partners.

Abstract:
Sexual dysfunctions (e.g., distress about levels of desire, arousal, orgasm, or sexual pain) are linked with poorer individual and relational wellbeing. Disclosing these dysfunctions to a romantic partner helps to mitigate these effects, however, such disclosures also risk rejection or relationship conflict. Existing models of disclosure do not adequately capture the complexities of disclosing sexual dysfunction, such as how costs and benefits are weighed simultaneously, the role of contextual factors, or how partner responses shape future disclosures. Three studies test a model of people’s disclosure of sexual dysfunction. Study 1 reports a thematic analysis of people’s social scripts about disclosing sexual dysfunction. Subsequent studies will test the influence of positive and negative partner responses and develop a scale to measure the anticipated costs and benefits of disclosing dysfunctions. Altogether, these studies build a framework explaining how and when people will disclose sexual dysfunction to romantic partners.
Primary supervisor: Dr Matt Hammond
Second supervisor: Dr Ally Gibson
Staff and postgraduate students are cordially invited to attend. There will be an opportunity at the end of the presentation for audience to observe the panel questioning the candidate about the presentation and proposed research, and for audience members themselves to ask questions of the candidate.
label: Health & Wellness

description:
Tītahi Bay Spring Community BBQ, Tītahi Bay Spring Community BBQ
It's (nearly) summer so it's time for a BBQ! Come and join us at 43 Kapiti Crescent (St Matthew's Hall) for a BBQ on the lawn. If it's bad weather, we will move into the hall.

All welcome! Dinner will be served from 5pm; we will make dinner, so just bring yourselves!



FAQ

Who is this for? Can I come along?

Yes absolutely, please come, we would love to have you. This dinner is for all the people who live in the beautiful community of Tītahi Bay!

What if I can't make it until a bit later?

That's all good, we will be serving a rolling dinner from 5 to 6.30pm so come whenever suits you. If you can only come a little later than 6.30pm, we will likely have more than enough so come anyway!

Can I bring my kids along?

Yes! In fact, please bring your kids along. We will have some games in the room and some options for crafts on the tables along with the food.

Do I need to bring anything?

Nope! Just yourselves, all are welcome just as you are.

But I really want to bring something to contribute?

If you would like to bring a salad to contribute to the BBQ, feel free to email us at and we can chat! We really just don't want this to be a barrier to anyone coming along.

Can I help?

Yes absolutely, this is a community event so help is always appreciated. It is also a great time to meet some other people. We will have some tasks for set up and also some for packing down and cleaning up. If you are interested in helping, flick us an email at

Will my dietaries be met?

We will make sure there will be options for these dietaries: vegan, gluten free, dairy free, and nut free.

If you have a dietary that isn't on there, feel free to check and flick us an email.

Can I bring my friend(s) along?

Yes, please bring your friends along, especially if they live in Tītahi Bay!

Who is this hosted by?

This idea is hosted by us, the crew who run Tītahi Bay Anglicans, but it is run with the help of our friends around Tītahi Bay. The hope is that this can become a recurring community event where others can join in on hosting this.

This is at a church, will I be preached to?

No, we promise that this isn't a Tupperware party bait and switch. While we definitely are a church, this event is for the Tītahi Bay community as a whole to be able to come eat together and connect.
label: Food & Drink

description:

What's Kölsch service?
It's kinda like beer yum cha but there's only one thing on the menu - 200ml glasses of Kölsch bier!

We keep track of your tab by marking the edge of your coaster and when your glass is empty - voilà, another glass appears!

description:
Urban Wine Walk - Pōneke Wellington, The streets and laneways of Pōneke Wellington are set to come alive this Spring as a line-up of eight venues each play host to an incredible winemaker, who'll be there ready to pour and chat you through an unforgettable afternoon.


HOW IT WORKS
Kick things off at your chosen starting spot with something to eat, and then let the adventure unfold. Wander at your own pace, glass in hand, discovering incredible wines and venues along the way.

With a stellar line-up of winemakers, good vibes at every stop, and a guaranteed sell-out crowd, the Urban Wine Walk is the ultimate self-guided tasting experience you and your crew won’t want to miss!


PARTICIPATING VENUES & WINEMAKERS
1 - Choice Bros Ft. Coney Wines (NZ)
2 - Glou Glou Ft. Halite (NZ)
3 - Little Beer Quarter Ft. Hopes Grove & Aard (NZ)
4 - Lulu Bar Ft. Margrain Vineyard (NZ)
5 - Noble Rot Ft. VALLI (NZ)
6 - Panhead Tory St Ft. The Good Way (NZ)
7 - The Arborist Rooftop Bar Ft. Matawhero (NZ)
8 - The Tasting Room Ft. Tettonica Wines (NZ)

*Please note that traditional venue menus may vary due to the nature of the event.


TICKETS
Vino Lover Pass – $79 + Booking Fee (Limited Availability)

WHAT’S INCLUDED
Wine Tastings – Up to 3 wines per winemaker along the trail
$10 Food Voucher – Redeem at your nominated starting venue (before 1pm)
$25 Wine Voucher – Put towards event-day wine orders (six-pack minimum, participating producers only)
Event Essentials – Your official wristband & keepsake tasting glass


EVENT REGISTRATION & COLLECTION
Before heading to your nominated starting venue, swing by the official registration point to collect your wristband, tasting glass & vouchers.

Where: Panhead Tory St (1 Tory St)
When: Saturday 18th October | 11am – 1pm

Please note: The Urban Wine Walk officially runs from 12-4pm. Arrive early to grab your event pack and avoid the rush!


REFUND POLICY
Tickets are non-refundable (we’re all in for good times rain, hail or shine!). The only exception is if the event is cancelled or postponed by the organisers – then we’ve got you covered.


GETTING AROUND
One of the best parts about the Urban Wine Walk...? It’s totally self-guided! After checking in at your nominated starting venue, the day is yours! Wander at your own pace, discover new spots and sip your way through the trail however you like.


Sorry kids, Urban Wine Walk is strictly 18 Years and Over!

We will endeavour to implement bicultural policies and practices that incorporate and value Māori cultural concepts, values and practices.

description:
Tītahi Bay Spring Community BBQ, Tītahi Bay Spring Community BBQ
It's (nearly) summer so it's time for a BBQ! Come and join us at 43 Kapiti Crescent (St Matthew's Hall) for a BBQ on the lawn. If it's bad weather, we will move into the hall.

All welcome! Dinner will be served from 5pm; we will make dinner, so just bring yourselves!



FAQ

Who is this for? Can I come along?

Yes absolutely, please come, we would love to have you. This dinner is for all the people who live in the beautiful community of Tītahi Bay!

What if I can't make it until a bit later?

That's all good, we will be serving a rolling dinner from 5 to 6.30pm so come whenever suits you. If you can only come a little later than 6.30pm, we will likely have more than enough so come anyway!

Can I bring my kids along?

Yes! In fact, please bring your kids along. We will have some games in the room and some options for crafts on the tables along with the food.

Do I need to bring anything?

Nope! Just yourselves, all are welcome just as you are.

But I really want to bring something to contribute?

If you would like to bring a salad to contribute to the BBQ, feel free to email us at and we can chat! We really just don't want this to be a barrier to anyone coming along.

Can I help?

Yes absolutely, this is a community event so help is always appreciated. It is also a great time to meet some other people. We will have some tasks for set up and also some for packing down and cleaning up. If you are interested in helping, flick us an email at

Will my dietaries be met?

We will make sure there will be options for these dietaries: vegan, gluten free, dairy free, and nut free.

If you have a dietary that isn't on there, feel free to check and flick us an email.

Can I bring my friend(s) along?

Yes, please bring your friends along, especially if they live in Tītahi Bay!

Who is this hosted by?

This idea is hosted by us, the crew who run Tītahi Bay Anglicans, but it is run with the help of our friends around Tītahi Bay. The hope is that this can become a recurring community event where others can join in on hosting this.

This is at a church, will I be preached to?

No, we promise that this isn't a Tupperware party bait and switch. While we definitely are a church, this event is for the Tītahi Bay community as a whole to be able to come eat together and connect.

No previous art experience is required as these workshops are suitable for both beginners and artists who’d like to fine tune their skills and style a little further. A step-by step teaching style is used and this all happens in a wonderful, relaxed and enjoyable classroom overlooking the harbour.

Check out other classes, each has a different subject to choose from, Also available are Saturday family art classes as well as Wine & Watercolour evenings on Friday and Saturday evenings.

description:
Māori, Christianity & the Spirit World — Public lecture by Bradford Haami, Māori, Christianity & the Spirit World — Public lecture by Bradford Haami
In lecture theatre 2 (GBLT2) in the Law School at Victoria University / Te Herenga Waka.

Ramsey Library presents a public lecture by Bradford Haami.

What happens when vastly different ways of being meet? Dame Anne Salmond writes of ‘competing cosmologies’ and ‘ontological collisions’ — European missionaries arriving in Aotearoa in the early 19th century brought a Biblical cosmology that began such a collision. In this public lecture Bradford Haami will explore the interactions between Biblical and Māori cultural and spiritual worldviews that continue to evolve up to the present.

* How do Biblical and Māori cultural and spiritual beliefs and thought relate?
* How 19th century rangatira negotiate between traditional beliefs and the Biblical narratives?
* Where do Christian and Māori ways of knowing and seeing clash, compete or enrich each other?
* What does being Māori and Christian look like today?


Bradford Haami (Ngāti Awa) is a Māori historian, researcher and author with research interests in Māori worldviews, spirituality, Christianity and cultural preservation. He is Pou Amorangi (Māori Director) at Laidlaw College in Auckland, New Zealand, where he lectures in biculturalism and sits on the governing board of the college. Haami has written several books on Māori history, culture and spirituality, with recent works including Urban Māori: The Second Great Migration (Oratia Media 2018) and Bringing Culture into Care (Huia 2019). He was the Māori curator/expert on the acclaimed Te Taiao / Nature exhibition at Te Papa Tongarewa Museum.

--
To browse the Ramsey Library catalogue, and sign up to borrow books (free), go to https://library.chaplaincyvuw.org.nz

description:
2025 Taiwan Update Lectures, Taiwan’s Multidimensional Energy Security Challenges
Professor Chyungly Lee
A stable and reliable energy supply is essential for a nation’s economic growth and development. In selecting fuel sources, nowadays almost all countries have taken climate change into account, adopted sensible clean energy transition plans, and designed a schedule to meet the goal of Net Zero. While pursuing a 3-E (energy-economic-environmental) balanced energy supply strategy, Taiwan, lacking indigenous resources, faces unique challenges of supply disruptions from over dependence on energy imports and possible blockade, quarantine, or invasion from Beijing. Any disruption of power supply or surge of energy costs could not only threaten Taiwan’s competitive edge in the global high-tech market but also undermine Taiwan’s internal stability and the nation’s survival. In this talk, Dr. Chyungly Lee will first present fact sheets on Taiwan’s energy status, summarize Taiwan’s current energy strategy, and then discuss dilemmas and vulnerabilities that Taiwan might face in the next few years.
What does Taiwan’s two-level politics tell us?
Professor Alex Tan
This presentation examines Taiwan as a critical case study for understanding the evolving challenges to democracy in the 21st century. Arguing that Taiwan serves as a “canary in the coalmine,” the analysis highlights how the island’s early and persistent political polarization—rooted in identity politics and the legacies of authoritarian rule—prefigures trends now visible in established democracies worldwide. The research explores how deep divisions between the Kuomintang (KMT) and Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), reinforced by institutional and social factors, have led to legislative gridlock, declining trust in political institutions, and a “democratic ceiling” that constrains further democratic development. Taiwan’s precarious geopolitical position, facing constant pressure from the People’s Republic of China, intensifies the dilemma of balancing national security with the protection of civil liberties. The presentation analyzes Taiwan’s innovative responses to disinformation, foreign interference, and public health crises, illustrating both the resilience and fragility of democratic systems under external and internal stress.
Gaming Taiwan: Indigenous Epistemologies in Play
Associate Professor Chia-rong Wu
This research explores how Indigenous knowledge systems in Taiwan are being revitalized through video games. Far from mere entertainment, these games draw on tribal traditions, ancestral stories, and deep connections to the land to create meaningful digital experiences. By blending oral storytelling with interactive gameplay, Taiwanese Indigenous game developers are preserving cultural memory while challenging colonial legacies. Titles like Princess Baleng, Tayal, VuVu, and Gadvia show how games can empower communities and pass down wisdom to younger generations in innovative and engaging ways. Gamers not only play a game but also immerse themselves in digital environments shaped by Indigenous perspectives and values. This study encourages all engaged audiences, including educators and students, to consider video games as powerful tools for cultural resurgence and learning. Focusing on Indigenous Taiwan, it highlights how digital games integrate historical consciousness and interactivity to reimagine the past and future of the island.
label: Government & Politics

And if you like the finer things in life, while devouring each course you'll sip on beer & wine to your heart's desire and let the sultry sounds of live music weave through the room, adding a touch of old-school glamour to your night. Young Flame promises an evening steeped in elemental elegance.

description:
Affordable Healthcare for All: Wellington, Luxon’s cuts are making our health system worse. His choices mean it’s getting harder and more expensive to see a doctor or nurse. 
National has found hundreds of millions for tobacco companies while New Zealand’s hospitals go understaffed and nurses are left without jobs. 
It's Luxon's fault GP fees are heading towards $100. Under National, you’re paying more, waiting longer and getting less. 
Labour believes that every New Zealander should be able to access world-class healthcare, no matter where they live. 
We will make it cheaper and easier to get care close to home, and make sure hospitals are there when you need them.  
Join Labour Leader Chris Hipkins and Health Spokesperson Dr Ayesha Verrall for a public meeting on getting the healthcare you deserve.
label: Government & Politics

description:
Workshop Series: Exploring 'Search and Reflect’ with Jake Baxendale, Search and Reflect, by the legendary drummer & improviser John Stevens, is a compilation of pieces/exercises/activities/vehicles for developing the collaboration, listening, trust and communal and convivial spirit required for group musical improvisation.
Informed by his own research and performance practice in improvisation, Jake Baxendale will lead an exploration of the book, choosing a number of pieces to perform with the participants, showing how its exacting, precise investigation of musical elements provides a blueprint for friendly, open & free musical happenings.
About John Stevens: One of the founding fathers of free improvisation in Britain. In the mid-'60s, Stevens helped found Spontaneous Music Ensemble (SME), an influential group that included most of England's top experimental jazz musicians.
About Jake Baxendale: a saxophonist and composer based in Te Whanganui-a-Tara, Jake Baxendale performs regularly at venues throughout the city, and has performed extensively overseas.
https://jakebaxendale.com/
Koha Entry
A second workshop will take place on Wednesday 24th September, 7:30PM
Special thanks to CNZ for supporting Pyramid Club's programme

description:
Futuna Lecture Series 2025: Francis Kéré, The Futuna Lecture Series commenced in 2011 and has been one of the main annual events on the NZ Architectural calendar for the last 14 years. It is the Futuna Chapel Trust’s major fundraiser each year and attracts a large audience of architects, architectural designers, technicians, architecture and design students and interested members of the public. The Trust exists solely on koha/donations as well as financial support from selected sponsors and donors.
Our sponsors, Dulux NZ, APL, Plytech, Warren Trust and the Auckland, Christchurch and Wellington NZIA branches have continued their support for the Futuna Lecture Series 2025.
This year the Trust welcomes three new sponsors being Roofing Industries Limited, AGP and Big River Panels. The additional support of these new sponsors is very much appreciated and ensures that the Futuna Chapel Trust can continue to attract speakers to NZ of a similar calibre to that of the 2025 Futuna Lecture, Francis Kéré.
The Trust takes this opportunity to thank Metalcraft Roofing for their support of the Futuna Lecture Series from 2012 - 2024.
The Trust looks forward to welcoming architects, designers, graduates, students and interested members of the public to attend this event and support the Trust in its work and well as that of the Kéré Foundation.
The Trust will donate 20% of the ticket income to the Kéré Foundation to support the work of Francis Kéré in Gando, Burkina Faso.
The Futuna Trust is a charitable organisation and all funds raised from the Futuna Lecture Series go towards the ongoing care, maintenance and operation of Futuna Chapel and also to support various initiatives undertaken by the Trust. Please register using the ticket types of $10, $15, $25 or $30 GST inclusive. Booking fees are in addition to the ticket prices.
BOOKINGS ARE ESSENTIAL TO ATTEND THIS EVENT
There will be 15 Design CPD points available for NZ registered architects attending the event. Please include your NZRAB registration number when purchasing Architect tickets

description:
Celebrate the Fabric, Exquisite pieces of needlework are on display and in use every day at Wellington Cathedral of
St Paul: beautifully decorated fabrics that hang at the front of the altars, spectacular robes and
stoles worn by priests at services, and fine linens used at every service of Holy Communion.

You’ll learn much about this remarkable fabric artistry when Jo Dixey talks to the Friends of
Wellington Cathedral of St Paul and guests on Wednesday, 24 September at 10.30 am.
Jo is an internationally regarded professional embroiderer who graduated from the Royal
School of Needlework and now lives permanently in New Zealand. She teaches, exhibits and sells
her work, as well as accepting commissions from churches, fashion designers and private
individuals. She has also had contracts from the film industry, working on the Disney film Mulan
and most recently on season 1 of Lord of the Rings TV series. Jo’s collection of embroidered
3D viruses, created during the 2020 Covid lockdown, are now on display in The Museum of
New Zealand Te Papa Tongarewa.

Venue: Loaves and Fishes Hall, Wellington Cathedral of St Paul.

description:
China and the Media Landscape in the Pacific, Over the last decade, the People’s Republic of China has sought to deepen its ties with Pacific Island countries. Beijing’s efforts to cultivate influence in the region have included expanding economic, diplomatic, and security ties with Pacific Island nations, as well as expanding China’s footprint in the region’s media landscape. This talk will present the findings of recent research on China’s efforts to shape reporting, media coverage and narratives in the Pacific Islands and put Beijing’s efforts within the context of the region’s rapidly evolving information landscape.
 About the speakers:
Heidi Holz is a Senior Research Scientist at CNA. For close to two decades, her work has focused on PRC strategic communications, propaganda, and influence efforts. She is a graduate of Georgetown University’s School of Foreign Service, where she received a master’s degree in security studies and a bachelor’s degree in Chinese and East Asian history.
Genevieve Collins is a research specialist in the China Studies program at CNA, where her research focuses on the behaviour of China’s state-run media and its reactions to US military operations and activities.
 Barbara Dreaver (Discussant) has been the Pacific Reporter for TVNZ 1 News since 2002, breaking stories uncovering social and economic issues affecting Pacific people living in New Zealand and the Pacific Islands. In 2020, she created a two-year training programme through Pacific Cooperation Broadcasting Ltd to support new Pacific journalists across the Pacific region. In the 2024 New Years Honours she was awarded an ONZM for services to investigative journalism and Pacific communities.
 About CNA: CNA is a non-profit, non-governmental research and analysis organization dedicated to providing independent and objective analyses to the U.S. government and the public. This talk will build on previous CNA research on China and the Pacific Islands media landscape which you can find at www.cna.org.
label: Government & Politics

description:
A night of jazz & deep house fused with live violin, A night of jazz & deep house fused with live violin
Presenting a specially curated set - a deeply emotive journey through funk, jazz and deep house to create a rich immersive soundscape, String House Project (SHP) brings their unique blend of jazz house fusion accompanied by live violin to Wellington.

Auckland DJ Lady Fee and Wellington violinist Ana Henderson unite their talents through a shared love of hypnotic beats, soaring melodies, and emotive dancefloor experiences. Lady Fee’s meticulously mixed sets are complimented by Ana’s classically trained violin, adding a soulful, improvisational edge, shaped by influences from Balkan folk and gypsy jazz to Americana and swing.

For this one-night-only show, they’re joined by Hunter (MAURI - Live Essence Events) and Stu (Sandwiches), bringing you an unforgettable night of infectious beats, grooves and heart felt celebration.

Tickets available at Undertheradar

https://www.undertheradar.co.nz/ticket/30381/String-House-Project.utr
label: Music & Concerts

description:
Dropping Flyers Across Motukairangi, Flyer Drop Blitz - Mission Motukairangi
Kia ora e te whānau,
I’d love your help to blitz this flyer-dropping mission across the magnificent Motukairangi!
I’ve got a list of streets that need finishing off, and with your help we can get it done in no time.
Meet at my place, 11am
From there we’ll divide up and set off on your mission (should you choose to accept it
).
Every flyer in a letterbox is another step closer to connecting with our neighbours and sharing the kaupapa of this campaign.
Bring comfy shoes, a smile, and your best flyer-dropping energy!
label: Government & Politics

description:
Government Digital Transformation in Latin America - what can we learn?, We are excited to announce the latest in our series of talks on Digital Transformation, in partnership with Silverstripe.
María Inés Baque will be joining us online from Argentina to share her expert insights and experiences on the key goals, capabilities, opportunities and challenges for government digital transformation - with a range of use cases from around Latin America.
María Inés Baque is Government Transformation Advisor for Latin America, Canada, and the Caribbean (LCC) at AWS. She served as secretary of digital government and technology innovation in Argentina from 2016 to 2019. She coordinated the Digital Agenda 2030 and led the transformational efforts in the areas of digital services, digital inclusion, open government, open data and new technologies adoption.
Global awards and recognitions she has received include Innovation Lab, Tel Aviv, 20 exceptional GovTech Leaders (2020), Women Corporate Directors 2019 and The 100 Most Influential People in Digital Government, Apolitical, 2018.
She was co-chair of the G20 Digital Economy Taskforce for Gender Inclusion in 2018 that issued the Bridging the Digital Gender Divide report.
Before government, her career was in global IT and financial services enterprises. She focused on process reengineering, startups, IT management, outsourcing and business process operations.
You may attend in person at the MBIE offices (limited to 40 people - there will be some food courtesy of Silverstripe), or you may tune in online via Microsoft Teams (the link will be at the bottom of your order confirmation email). If you choose to attend in person please arrive at 11.50am so there is time for you to sign in, pick up some food, and be seated before we begin. There will be time for questions after the presentation.
label: Government & Politics

description: Eastern Porirua Meet the Candidates, Come to our big community event: Wednesday 17 September 2025, 6pm at Mungavin Hall. Meet the people who will run the city and ask questions before voting. This page is for Eastern Porirua voters. In October 2025, we will vote for 1 mayor to lead Porirua City and 5 local people to speak for our area (also known as Onepoto Ward) and 2 Greater Wellington Regional Council reps. Or, if you are on the Māori roll, you will vote for 1 mayor to lead Porirua City and 1 person in the Porirua Māori Ward instead of voting for Onepoto ward people.

description:
It's in the Ballot - CDC – Carterton District Mayoral Debate -In-studio, Contestants of 'It's in the Bag' become political candidates in 'It's in the Ballot' Meet the Candidates.
Candidates choose a numbered box which has a question that has been submitted online by voters before the show.
It’s in the Ballot” is a community-led awareness and participation initiative. We aim to increase voter interest in the general and council elections nationally.
By using broadcasting and web-based technologies to deliver in-studio; online on Facebook, YouTube and Twitch; and edited as YouTube videos we aim to enable voters to make informed voting decisions.
This means you can send the weblink of the YouTube Video of your electorate show to your friends and whanau to encourage them to watch the show before they cast their votes.
Voting papers are sent to voters on Tuesday 9th September 2025 and must be delivered into a voting dropbox by 12pm Saturday 11th October 2025
label: Government & Politics

description:
HRA Meet The Candidates, You are cordially invited to attend the Hataitai Residents Association Meet the Candidates meeting on Sunday 14th September at the:
Wellington Cadet Centre
393 Evans Bay Parade.


With the large number of Council and Mayoral candidates, we have decided to split the meeting into 2 parts.


Eastern Ward Candidates,
-We will run the Eastern Candidates from 1pm to 2pm.

5 Minute break.


Mayoral Candidates,

We will have coffee and tea after.

Amped Up, Amped Up
New Zealand’s loudest night of mean as metal mayhem is locked and loaded.
Join us here at Brewtown for AMPED UP 2025, featuring NZs heaviest double-header!

Blindspott – returning to the stage with their signature blend of raw emotion and heavy-hitting aggression.
AND

with support from Shepherds Reign - completing this un-holy trinity with their commanding, tribal-infused metal.

description:
Hīkoi ki te Pōti Kāpiti, Join Kāpiti’s Hīkoi ki te Pōti (walk to the voting booth) on Saturday 27th September. We’ll meet on the grassy area near the Waterfront Restaurant (opposite the boat ramp) in Raumati Beach for a gathering and group photo before heading off on our hīkoi to the Paraparaumu Library.
Bring your flags, placards and banners in support of Māori wards, Te Tiriti and justice and join the hīkoi.
Please spread the word. We’re hoping to get as many people as possible showing up, to demonstrate community support for Māori Wards!
All welcome - please RSVP here - https://tally.so/r/w89zaO
What to bring: Signs, flags, umbrella, raincoat, sunhat, sunscreen
We’d love to see you at the event, but if you’re unable to make it, make sure you get your votes in on time! If we all do our bit, we’ll send a really clear message - that we support Te Tiriti o Waitangi, and that we care about our Māori Wards.

description:
Mayoral and Tawa Community Board Candidates evening, You’re invited to hear from the Candidates for Mayor of Wellington and the Tawa Community Board.
Come along for your chance to ask your burning questions of your candidates.
The event will be held in the main hall at the Tawa Community Centre, which is an accessible venue with ample parking, and close to public transport links.
Doors will be open from 6:45pm.
7:00 Welcome from the Chair and safety briefing
7:05 - 7:20 Tawa Community Board candidates speak to the audience (2 minutes each in random order selected on the night)
7:20 - 8:00 Tawa Community Board Candidates answer questions from the floor
8:00 - 8:05 Quick reset to Mayoral Candidates
8:05 - 8:30 Mayoral Candidates speak to Audience (2 minutes each in random order)
8:30 - 9:00 Mayoral candidates answer questions from the floor
9:00 - 9:30 Time to mingle or ask remaining questions.
If you can’t make it, you can still submit your questions. Leave a comment with your question or email it to vibrant.tawa@gmail.com (clearly stating if the question is for Mayoral candidates, Community Board candidates, or both).
Follow this link to submit any questions you would like answered on the night
https://forms.gle/mycYjBoEWDVafq938
label: Government & Politics

description:
Fresh Produce, Fresh Produce
Presented by the New Zealand Improv Festival
Directed by Guanny Liu-Prosee
Performed by graduates of the NZIF Youth Programme

Check out the future of New Zealand improv as these young whippersnappers vie for your laughs. Fresh on the scene, the graduates of the New Zealand Improv Festival Youth Programme are here to show you what they’ve got.

For the past week, they have immersed themselves in the joy of improv, and now they’re ready to impress you with their newly honed acting chops over two nights of high-energy hilarity.

Born in 2008, now in its 16th year (don’t think too hard about the maths), NZIF is a whirlwind celebration and showcase of improvisation from around Aotearoa and the world.

The NZIF Youth Programme brings together young people from around the Te-Whanganui-A-Tara region for a week of improv training and joy. For more information please email

We are grateful for the support of Insight to Action Consulting and the Performing Arts Foundation.

As this show is improvised, we cannot guarantee the presence or absence of specific content or themes beyond what is in the description above. The show may contain mature themes and language, but not gratuitously. The show may contain voluntary audience interaction, such as giving a suggestion for a scene.

Photography: Nicolette Hurnen
label: Arts & Theatre

description:
Food Drops, Fine Weather, and Serious Falls: A 34-Day Solo Trip in Westland | WTMC Club night, Ever wondered what it takes to complete a 34-day solo tramping trip? Come hear WTMC club member Regan McGillicuddy share stories from his epic adventure in Westland, where he hiked in his own food drops and visited 38 huts across some of the most rugged and remote parts of the West Coast.
Doors open 6:30pm, talk beginning at 7:00pm.

description:
Pike River: Wellington Brass Fundraiser, We’re excited to invite you to a special advanced screening of the powerful new film Pike River. This exclusive preview is a fundraiser to support Wellington Brass Band as we prepare to represent New Zealand at the World Championships in Kerkrade, Holland.
Pike River: Wellington Brass Fundraiser
Lighthouse Cuba, 29 Wigan St, Wellington
Tuesday 21 October, 5:45pm
General admission: $28.92 each ($25.00 + $3.92 fees) – Book now on Eventfinda
This is a unique opportunity to see the film before its general release. We’re especially proud that the film’s director, Rob Sarkies, and producer, Vicky Pope, have a family connection to our band — their son plays in our Buzzing Brass Youth Band. Vicky will be giving a short introduction before the screening.
We’d love for you to join us for this special night of cinema and music community spirit. Every ticket sold directly helps our journey to the world stage.
label: Film & Media

description:
Meet the Candidates – A Business Community Conversation - Paraparaumu, Meet the Candidates – A Business Community Conversation - Paraparaumu
This September, the Kāpiti Business Chamber is partnering with the Ōtaki and Te Horo, Waikanae and Raumati Business Associations to host two “Meet the Candidates” events for our business community.

With local elections just around the corner, these sessions are your opportunity to engage directly with incoming candidates, hear their views on local business issues, and share what matters most to you.

What to expect:
A curated panel-style conversation with standing candidates
Open mic Q&A for business owners and professionals
Subsidised drinks and light nibbles
A chance to connect with others in your area

📍 Paraparaumu – Wednesday 10 September, 5.30pm, Paraparaumu Rugby Club

We’ve intentionally chosen two locations to make it easier for business owners across the district – from Waikanae and Raumati to Te Horo and Ōtaki – to attend their closest event.

These are free events, but RSVPs are essential.
label: Government & Politics

description: Meet the Greater Wellington Regional Council Candidates, There are 11 candidates wanting to be part of the GWRC. And 3 candidates for the Māori Ward. What do they want to achieve and how do regional councils and Māori wards fit into the future of our region? Come along and find the answers
label: Government & Politics

description:
Shostakovich Unpacked | NZSQ + Ghost Trio, Introducing Shostakovich: Unpacked. A four-part concert series presented by New Zealand String Quartet and friends to commemorate the 50th anniversary of Shostakovich’s death.
Across four night-time gatherings, the NZSQ will take to the stage with Orchestra Wellington, Antipodes Quartet, Ghost Trio, and pianist Jian Liu to explore the raw emotional power of one of the 20th century’s most troubled, yet defiant, musical voices.
Each concert features a specially curated selection of the chamber music of Shostakovich, paired with the unique voices of Aotearoa composers. From duets, to quartets, to a full chamber orchestra, we're getting up close to the celebrated chamber music and lasting legacy of Dimitri Shostakovich, 50 years after his death.
We invite you to join us on the journey of “Shostakovich: UNPACKED”, as together we explore and question what this powerful music meant in the time Shostakovich wrote it, but also how vitally important the composer’s artistic voice still is today.
Concert Three: Wednesday 1 October, 6:30pm, NZSQ x Ghost Trio
Artists onstage: NZSQ / Ghost Trio
Shostakovich: 4th String Quartet, Five Pieces for Two Violins and Piano, 2nd Piano Trio
Unpacked: The music of Robert Burch
Spotlight: Feel the past merge with the present, as beloved former NZSQ member Monique Lapins joins current violinist Peter Clark in Shostakovich’s delightful work for two violins and piano. Ghost Trio conclude the evening with their celebrated virtuosity and emotional intensity in the second piano trio.
Tickets: $15 - $55, or get a season pass to all four concerts for $180pp
Season pass discount will be automatically applied at checkout when you have one 'Season Pass' ticket per concert date in your cart.
In order:
Wednesday 9 July, 6:30pm & 8:30pm, NZSQ + Orchestra Wellington
Wednesday 6 August, 6:30pm, NZSQ + Antipodes Quartet
Wednesday 1 October, 6:30pm, NZSQ + Ghost Trio
Tuesday 25 November, 6:30pm, NZSQ + Jian Liu
label: Music & Concerts

description:
Meet the Candidates, hosted by Cycle Wellington and Bicycle Junction, Meet the Candidates, hosted by Cycle Wellington and Bicycle Junction
Please register,for free, at https://events.humanitix.com/meet-the-candidates-cycling-edition so we know how many people are coming.
How people get around our city and suburbs is a critical issue for Wellington.
Safe public spaces is core Council business. We believe that a network of protected bike lanes is an essential part of a safe and modern city that seeks to attract growth businesses and their staff. Wellington has made good progress but we need to keep going.
Hear about Council candidates' visions and plans for Wellington.
Please join members of Wellington’s cycling community for an informal meeting.
label: Government & Politics

description:
Nuclear Disarmament in a Nuclear Free New Zealand: Why it still matters, New Zealand is recognised as a global leader in nuclear disarmament, with its 1987 Nuclear
Free Zone, Disarmament, and Arms Control Act becoming a defining feature of the country’s
national identity. The establishment of a nuclear free zone has served as inspiration
worldwide, yet, despite this, the nuclear issue remains relevant to New Zealand. As long as
nuclear weapons exist, their environmental, humanitarian and geopolitical impacts extend far
beyond the borders of nuclear weapon states.
This panel and fireside chat seeks to situate New Zealand’s position within the global
nuclear landscape, exploring why the issue continues to matter to a nuclear free country,
highlighting the interconnected impacts of these weapons, whilst also considering New
Zealand’s role as a disarmament leader.
label: Government & Politics

description:
Prime Minister movie fundraiser, Described as a moving and poignant account of Dame Jacinda Ardern’s time as Prime Minister of New Zealand. An intimate look into the complexities and challenges of leading a country while also staying true to your values. Beforehand (all going well) we’ll share staff photos of her time as leader, never previously shared in public.
Funds go to the campaign to get our Western Ward councillor to join a full team of Labour Councillors to support the Mayor so we can get things done for working Wellingtonians and those who need our support.
label: Government & Politics

description:
Public Meeting: Affordable Healthcare for All - Wellington, Luxon’s cuts are making our health system worse. His choices are why it’s getting harder and more expensive to see a doctor or nurse. Because of Luxon’s underfunding, GP fees are heading towards $100. National has found hundreds of millions for tobacco companies while hospitals go understaffed and graduate nurses are left without jobs.
Labour will make it cheaper and easier to get care close to home, and make sure hospitals are there when you need them.
Join Labour Leader Chris Hipkins and spokesperson for health Dr Ayesha Verrall for a public meeting on getting the healthcare you deserve.
Public Meeting: Affordable Healthcare for All
