description:
Karanga taonga, karanga tangata, karanga whenua |Reversing Cultural Amnesia: Activating Māori Practice in Museums, In 1947, Māori leader, politician, and scholar Apirana Ngata spoke to his scholarly peers at the Polynesian Society, announcing his greatest desire to revive Māori culture as a living force within communities, not be relegated to dead exhibits in museums (Ramsden 1948, 85).
This lecture acknowledges the concerns of visionary leaders and champions of cultural practice and their activation within museums. Through her work as a Māori curator, writer, cultural practitioner and post-doctoral researcher, Awhina Tamarapa advocates for cultural restoration as a form of liberation in a museum context. In her research, Tamarapa is exploring strategies for the recovery and reclamation of taonga puoro (singing treasures) and karetao (animated storytellers) for new generations.
There are challenges regarding taonga held by overseas museums. Concepts such as keeping taonga warm, and mana taonga, recognises the connection and authority of descendants to their taonga, that underpin this work.
The focus on the reclamation of Indigenous practice has been bolstered by working with First Nations, Canada BC. Led by Professor Bryony Onciul, University of Exeter, UK, Tamarapa was privileged to be part of a research project “The Future of Indigenous Rights and Responsibilities: Ancestral governance, environmental stewardship, language revival, and cultural vibrancy” funded by the Arts and Humanities Research Council, UK.
_________
The Michael Volkerling Lecture series is a partnership event with the Museum and Heritage Studies programme at Te Herenga Waka | Victoria University of Wellington, National Services Te Paerangi and Te Papa Tongarewa. This annual public lecture series recognises the legacy of the late Dr Michael Volkerling who was one of the principal architects of New Zealand's cultural and creative sectors.

description:
Fundamentals of Drawing for Tweens and Teens, In this course you will learn the basics of structure and perspective so you can draw anything you like. Returning students are assigned additional challenges in order to promote continuous development of their drawing journey.

We'll be drawing on paper with pencils and pens. There's a strong emphasis on learning structure and perspective drawing, with the aim to feel more confident in drawing anything - real or imagined. We will be drawing things from real life, from photos and from our imagination.

What you will learn in the class.
- Perspective - learning the basics to help draw forms and spaces convincingly.
- Using perspective to draw organic forms.
- The structure of human faces - Constructing the face to understand it.
- The structure of human figures - Drawing the body from the skeleton out.
- The structure of animal and creature bodies - Seeing the similarities to humans.
- Shading and shadows - Understanding light as it hits objects.
- Composition - Arranging elements in your picture.
- Using different B&W mediums like pencils, pens, inks.

This course is catered to ages 10 years or older. Materials included.

Tuesdays after school, 14 October - 2 December, 3:45 - 5:15 pm.
label: Classes & Workshops

description:
Explore Monoprint Workshop, Of all the print making methods, mono printing is the most spontaneous, responsive and versatile, being the medium for everything from abstract expressionism to hyper photographic realism. Simple and direct with the minimum of equipment and media, mono printing is approachable for any age or ability level, yet the creative potential is unlimited.

Planned here is a three day workshop to introduce mono printing from simple hand printing, spontaneous transfer methods through to working with presses and multiple matrices.

For people starting in printmaking and people already with an art practice in any media. We will experiment with a whole new method of mark making, transfer and texture to build skill level and also provide a cross discipline change to invigorate your existing art practice of painting or drawing.

Also you will be introduced to a progressive evolution development technique for learning and to push yourself into new areas of creativity that can be applied to other art practices and medias.

One hour lunch - Bring a drink bottle and a packed lunch to enjoy in the historic Inverlochy house or explore the Te Aro cafes.

Basic materials are supplied.

Two day workshop: Sat 25 - Sun 26 October, 10 am - 4 pm daily.
label: Classes & Workshops

description:
5 days Figure Sculpting workshop with model, 5 days Figure Sculpting workshop with model
The immediacy of the model’s presence encourages close observation and instinctive decision-making leading to work that is expressive and real. This hands-on interaction brings a sense of movement and authenticity that’s hard to achieve otherwise.

The sculpting process typically starts by analyzing the model’s proportions and pose. A wire armature is built to support the structure and clay is gradually applied to develop the form to a one-third life size 750mm tall figure. From there the artist refines the shapes focusing on anatomical accuracy and expressive detail that give the sculpture its final character.

With nearly 30 years of experience in traditional sculpture and the film industry Javier is not just a sculptor — he’s a mentor. Trained in classical techniques he studied fine arts and took anatomy courses at medical school developing a rare combination of artistic and anatomical knowledge. He spent over five years at the world-renowned Weta Workshop contributing to major films and exhibitions and has worked across materials scales and digital technologies.

Material is included in the price.
Armature is supplied during the workshop.
You can buy our tools during the workshop if you like.
Tea

description:
Bulgarian Folk Dance Class, Bulgarian Folk Dance Class
Join Bulgarian Ensemble Horo and Discover the Joy of Bulgarian Folk Dance!
No partner? No problem! Our dances are performed in open circles, so everyone is welcome.
Come and experience the vibrant rhythms and rich traditions of Bulgarian music and dance!
Our group regularly performs at multicultural festivals and Bulgarian cultural events around Wellington.
About Our Teacher – Lilia Petrova de Castro:
Lilia began dancing Bulgarian folk at just 8 years old. With 15 years of experience performing across Bulgaria and Europe with Dance Ensemble "Svetlina" and the renowned folk ensemble "Sredetz", she brings deep knowledge and passion to every class. Lilia believes dancing is one of the best ways to energize your body and uplift your mind and she loves sharing that joy with others!

description:
Bachata Beginners level 1, Welcome to Salsa Therapy! We have been running Bachata classes for over 10 years.
Ready to move, groove, and feel the rhythm?
Join our Complete Bachata Beginners Course and discover how Latin dancing can boost your confidence, improve posture, enhance coordination and movement — and help you recharge your mindset.
No experience needed — just bring your energy and love for music!
Learn all the fundamentals over 8 fun and engaging weeks
All levels of fitness welcome
Supportive, friendly vibes
Great way to move, connect, and feel AMAZING
Early Bird Special: Only $150 – limited time offer!
Secure your spot today and start your Bachata journey with us!

description:
Balfolk Class - Newtown, Balfolk Class - Newtown
Balfolk is a folk dance and music movement from Europe that gives new life to traditional dances. A ‘Bal Folk’ is a social dance event that brings people of all ages and walks of life together through group and partner dances to have fun and connect. It's a friendly, social and energising space.

The class will run over 6 weeks. We will learn and practice different group and partner dances you would commonly find in a Bal Folk.
Dances are simple and easy to learn but also have depth so once you have learnt the basics, we can explore and play around with variations.
Balfolk is accessible to people with all skill levels. You don’t need any previous dance experience, curiosity is all you need 😊

When: Wednesdays from 6:00 to 7:30pm

Location: Newtown Community Centre

Price: $60 for the block of 6 classes
$15/class for casual attendance
Students/concession/unwaged: koha
label: Classes & Workshops

description:
Hands-on Sourdough Workshop, Sourdough for Beginners - $120 (paid via internet banking)
Come join us for a hands-on, in-person sourdough workshop at Willow Corner Collective headquarters (aka my home)! This workshop is currently the only hands-on sourdough workshop being offered in the Nelson region - I teach and demonstrate to you and then you get to mix and practice on your own dough as we go along.
Whether you're a seasoned baker or a beginner, this event is perfect for anyone looking to master the art of making sourdough bread, learning from someone who has 10+ years of experience. Perhaps you've found all the Youtube tutorials and Instagram how-to's overwhelming and are keen to learn via an in-person class. Then this is for you! I've baked hundreds of loaves in the last year alone, sold at a market, and hosted a pop-up shop. However, my passion really lies with teaching others to bake their own sourdough in their own homes, for their own families (or small businesses - one day!).You will be taught, demonstrated to, and then you get to have a go yourself; whilst learning my tips and tricks along the way. Plus we finish by sampling some delicious, fresh artisan sourdough with some favourite toppings!
You'll go home with all you need to make a good loaf of sourdough bread:
Knowledge
Student Guide, including recipes and troubleshoot guide
Bowl, liner, bowl scraper, and razor blade... all the tools you'd need to make sourdough
Dough made in class to bake the next day at home, to wow your family/friends
Confidence to continue the process yourself
Healthy, bubbling starter to continue your journey at home
Continued support and encouragement via our own private Facebook community group, for class attendees only
Note: You will have your dough to take home after the workshop that will need shaping around 6-8pm, so please ensure that will work for you that day.Also, please double check the date when booking. If for some reason you are unable to attend on the day, due to time constraints, I am unable to refund your ticket. I am happy for you to send someone in your place, though. In extenuating circumstances I may be able to hold your ticket for a future workshop; this is decided on a case-by-case basis.
*Payment to clear in bank account two days after ticket bought, after which time your ticket will be released on to someone else. Please pay immediately upon purchasing ticket.
**All workshop info you need to know ahead of time is in the confirmation email. Please ensure you read this down to the bottom.
***I recommend you already have a pair of digital scales, and a cast iron dutch oven at home to bake your loaf with as this makes the best, artisan sourdough, with great rise. Alternatively, a large, lidded casserole dish or enamel roasting pan work also. (The lids are a necessity).

"Sarah’s sour dough class is for real life! Achieve beautiful delicious bread easily in your own kitchen. Sarah teaches you how to fit sourdough into your busy life. She clearly and passionately gives the essential information, tips and tricks to make your own loaf. I loved getting to have a go at each step in the process. I love Sarah’s catchy philosophy “The goal is good bread, not perfect bread.” This took all the pressure off, for me, and I left the class empowered with all the knowledge and skills needed to give it a go at home. I appreciated the thoughtful and well prepared resources Sarah gave us. Thank you!" - Megan

"Sourdough with Sarah was a delight! From feeling overwhelmed and giving up on the idea of ever making my own loaf of sourdough, to dancing with joy as i watch a beautiful perfect sourdough loaf get nice and golden in the homewood stove!The information was packaged in bite sizes with hands on practice in between, where we all got to experience each step of the whole process, which was cleverly condensed and prepared so that despite normally having waits in between, we were able to see it all play out in a short few hours!The process was beautifully organised with attention to detail that had us fawning, came away feeling so blessed and privileged!Sarah's glowing personality made all the information feel easy and palatable, it was so fun!Such a lovely time, great environment to learn with ease." -Melody
label: Classes & Workshops

description:
Advanced Flush Setting in Two Days, Advanced Flush Setting in Two Days
This workshop is ideal for advanced students who have already learned how to set cabochon stones. Over two three-hour sessions, 20 and 27 September, 10am-1pm, you will be given an understanding of the technique of setting faceted stones using a setting burr, hammers, punches and burnishing tools. This is the first step in learning to flush set facet cut stones so they sit below the surface of the metal.

Session 1 will cover the technique, demonstrations and the basics of preparing and cutting the setting. Students will be shown how to set their stones, and may begin to do this in class, but will then go on to repeat and practice the technique in their own time.
They can do this at home, or for a small extra cost, can stay on at the studio to practice setting for the afternoon.

Session 2 will pick up on the setting techniques, reminding and refining essential steps in the process. Troubleshooting can be covered in this class, as well as learning to clean up the settings. The principles of this setting technique will be covered in a few different scenarios, as some students may wish to take this skill into different styles or directions.

The option for students to have a half-day bench hire after class will also apply to this session.

What is provided: class fees cover your practice metal (copper) and stones (CZ) and detailed handouts that are useful for you to take away to refer to when practising and honing your skills.

Correctly sized drills and setting burrs will be provided in class, but students must purchase their own burrs for practice after class and any future bench hires. These are available for purchase in the studio.

What to bring: Advanced students can bring projects to set stones into, but please note the metal must be at least 2mm thick and we do not allow brass to be used as a project or practice for beginners. The metal must be copper or sterling silver.

Students should bring either a craft magnifier or magnifying lenses/glasses. If you have your own flex shaft tool you plan to use at home for drilling and setting, please also bring this along so that your tutor can advise on the best way to use it. We have two drilling machines in the studio, and these must be shared between the students, so if you have a machine, do bring it.

Practice bench hire after class $20 per person (till 4pm) must be booked in advance.

Workshop fee $195, Early bird $175 till 24 August.

description:
Hataitai community centre Raranga, Te Motu Kairangi, with the support of Hataitai Centre & Community House, warmly invites you to:
Monthly Flax Weaving Wānanga
Experience the joy of learning, sharing, and reconnecting with the art of weaving.
Whether you’re a first-time weaver or returning to refresh your skills, all are welcome. We’ll cover basic weaving techniques and tikanga (customs) and provide a supportive, creative space to connect with Māori arts and crafts alongside others.

• An old towel
• Bring a bag, as you must take away leftover harakeke
• Returning weavers: 30–40 rau of harakeke and your weaving tools
• Some tools are available to borrow
• Shared kai (snacks) welcome but not required
• Bring a bag, as you must take away leftover harakeke
Koha appreciated, not required
If you would like to support the kaupapa, please email us at temotukairangi.huihui@gmail.com for koha details.
Come and enjoy weaving, learning, and connection in a beautiful, relaxed setting.
Contact
via facebook

Email temotukairangi.huihui@gmail.com
If you would like to koha to TMK, please email (Email temotukairangi.huihui@gmail.com) for the account details.

description:
3 Steps for Life Training, Learn CPR for your loved one.

This Shocktober Hato Hone, St John, is on a mission to provide CPR & AED awareness training to as many people as they can. 3 Steps for Life is free training designed to give you the confidence to take action if someone suffers a cardiac arrest by:

Calling 111
Starting CPR
Using an AED
Come along to this 3 Steps for Life workshop from 10am-11am, Wednesday 22 October at the City Centre Library.

This workshop is free to attend and no bookings are required.
label: Classes & Workshops

description:
Draw it Out - Re-finding Your Spark, Guided drawings to re-find your spark and what it is that's driving you.

Join us for a DRAW IT OUT drawing for wellness workshop. Practice the ‘art’ of drawing and writing for wellness. This 1.5 hour workshop takes you through guided cues (similar to meditation or journaling) to draw out where you are at, draw out how you are feeling, and draw out your own inner guidance.

We all have the resources within to guide us, this workshop creates the space to access this by using a modality called Interactive Drawing Therapy. Facilitated by Lara Phillips, this is not therapy rather drawing for wellness; a guided workshop to build one’s relationship with oneself, to strengthen self-reflection and self-care.

No drawing skills required, this is more mark making not art making. Materials supplied.
label: Classes & Workshops

description:
Kintsugi Workshop in Wellington // Toi Poneke Art, Kintsugi Workshop in Wellington // Toi Poneke Art
After several SOLD OUT workshops in Wellington here is the next one... Oct 2025

Learn the magical art of Kintsugi with Artist Ema Frost in this new Workshop. You can bring along a piece of your own pottery to restore in this beautiful style. (I'll also have a few as back up if you don't have your own piece) (All Levels)

Sunday 12th October - 10:30am - 12:30pm or 2:00 - 4:00pm

Ema has been teaching Kintsugi for 5+ years and regularly travels to Japan to study and learn new techniques. Ema's illustrations and ceramic works sit in many of our countries best galleries, and whose products and merchandise sell in the most stylish design stores and gallery shops. Her style is enchanting - quirky, feminine and colourful, and clearly influenced by her travels throughout the world, usually off the beaten track.

Have you ever wanted to try Kintsugi.... It's an ancient Japanese art form where you fix broken pottery with gold - making its imperfections its beauty. - A truly wonderful philosophy to live by. Nothing is ever really broken but new life and meaning is brought back making your piece a work of art and truly something special. You can also apply this technique on various materials like glass, wood, greenstone and shells.

Kintsugi
It's called kintsugi (金継ぎ), or kintsukuroi (金繕い), literally golden (“kin”) and repair (“tsugi”). This traditional Japanese art uses a precious metal – liquid gold, liquid silver or lacquer dusted with powdered gold – to bring together the pieces of a broken pottery item and at the same time enhance the breaks.

You will take away your wonderful finished work, plus your new skills which will enable you to further your own Kintsugi in your own time.

What you will take away:
A finished artwork piece
A understanding of Kintsugi
Knowledge and History of this beautiful art form.

description:
Pottery Wheel Throwing & Hand Building - Creative Arts Holiday Program, Explore the techniques of pottery making including creating a mug using handbuilding processes and making a small bowl using throwing techniques on a pottery wheel. Students will be shown how to centre clay and make a small bowl on the wheel and trim it. Cups and bowls will be glazed by the tutor and ready for pickup approximately 3-4 weeks later depending on drying conditions.

This workshop is limited to three students only to ensure each person has individualised attention.

Suitable for ages 12+.

Tuesday - Thursday, 30 Sept - 2 October, 10 am - 12 pm daily.

This workshop is part of Inverlochy Art School's September School Holiday Programme. For more teen & tween workshops including photography, jewellery making, animation and sewing head to the 'Tamariki and Teens' section of our website.

description:
The Open Painting Studio, Explore your own ideas and image with guidance of an experienced tutor. The tutor and the student will discuss and find a way of how best to achieve their concept through the use of materials, composition, colour, texture.

This is a dynamic class where, apart from the tutor’s guidance, the input from the students is encouraged and valued in the weekly critique of the work created. This course offers the opportunity to work your skills in drawing, composition, description of volume, mixing of colours, technique and most important, personal expression.

This course is appropriate for all levels.

Students must be at least 16 years of age to attend this course.

Students must bring their own materials ( i.e. paint oil or acrylic, paper, canvases, brushes).
label: Classes & Workshops

description:
Sweat Reflect & Connect with Carolyn Patchell, Sweat – get those endorphins going!
Reflect – review our movements!
Connect – spend time with our classmates!
Sessions:
All Day 10.15am to 4pm $55
Morning 10.15am to 1pm $30
Afternoon 1.15pm to 4pm $30
Our day will start with a 30-minute Dance Fitness session that will include warm-ups but no cool down as we’ll head straight into a Tips and Tuition session. We’ll break down movements, go over cues and choreography, and look at how to increase or decrease intensity (or manage any injuries we might be carrying). We’ll take a break together and some healthy snacks will be provided along with hot drinks. We’ll then head into another Dance Fitness session where you can put your newfound knowledge to use (or just have some fun and party like it’s Friday night)! After a stretch and cooldown, we’ll do a bit of a wrap up over lunch (bring your own) and spend some time relaxing and chatting. Hot drinks will be available, or you can pop out if you need a barista made flat white!
If you’re not staying for the full day, we’ll say farewell after lunch and the rest of us will prepare to greet those coming in for the afternoon session.
The afternoon will start with a Strong Fit session which will contain elements of our Thursday night class. We’ll then move straight into a Tips and Tuition session which will look at all elements of our Strength Based Combo class. This will include form, technique, options, and how to maximise your weekly workouts. We’ll then take a break with some healthy (and easily digested) snacks before we power into a final Strong Fit session. Following the session, we’ll have a decent stretch and take the time to review what we’ve learned, chat amongst ourselves, and say farewell before our day concludes at 4pm.
label: Classes & Workshops

description:
The Art of Mending - Micro Mill, When it comes to the clothes we love, every rip, stain, and imperfection is an invitation to exercise agency, expression, and an opportunity to show the garment how much we appreciate it.

This class is cared for by the whimsical Aisha, a multidisciplinary artist with a passion for empowering the mending process. Each month on Wednesday evenings Aisha will introduce us to a different technique for reviving our beloved textile pieces. If you're like us and have a box of clothing in need of repairs that never seems to empty... this is the club for you. With three events a month we'll inspire each other to creatively care for those pieces we love! This club is also perfect for anyone who loves learning new skills. Techniques we'll cover are lino printing, patching, darning, felting, embroidery, beading, sashiko, fabric painting and more! All materials and tools are supplied at each class - but you are welcome to bring your own. We highly encourage bringing those clothes or other textile items that need some love and repair.

There is no need to attend every class. We can catch you up on the skill at which ever class you choose to join us at. There are single class tickets or monthly sign ups available. Both of these have variable pricing options, unwaged/student, waged, and generous. Please choose whichever option feels right for you and your circumstances!

In August we are Lino Printing!
Class 02: 20th August
At this class Aisha will take us through the process of designing and cutting our own lino to print with! You're welcome to keep going with the pre cut designs as well. Lino and carving tools will be supplied.

Class 03: 27th August
This class will be open to what you want to work on! Bring in larger project items, print with the lino cuts you made in the previous week, or cut some fresh ones!

In September we are patching!
Class 01: 10th September
Aisha will take us through the process of sewing on patches. Patches that we printed in the August classes will be available for this. You're welcome to bring your own patches as well. Please bring something that needs a patch up or a little bit of decoration.

Class 02: 17th September
At this class we will learn how to appliqué, the process of using scrap fabric to make decorative patches. This is a great way to elevate a rip or stain with some visible mending.

Class 03: 24th September
At this last class of the month we'll be open for all the patching needs. Hang out and finish projects we've started or mend some extra items.

Be sure to check our website or here for updates about techniques coming up in the following months.
label: Classes & Workshops

description:
Jazz and Beyond Workshops 2025, Jazz and Beyond for students 19 and under
December 15–18, 2025
Coordinated by Chris Beernink, Dave Wilson, Daniel Hayles, and Lance Philip. Proudly supported by the Tauranga Jazz Society.
Take your playing to the next level at the Jazz and Beyond Workshops! Young musicians from across Aotearoa come together to dive into jazz and connected styles, working closely with some of the country’s leading performers and educators. In a friendly, inclusive environment, you’ll grow your skills, make new musical connections, and learn alongside other students your age from all around the motu.
Here’s what’s in store:
small group ensembles led by professional musicians
developing improvisation skills in supportive settings
an introduction to music production
listening sessions that expand your skills
inclusive jam sessions where all are welcome
ensemble performances at the end of week concert
And more!
If you're 19 or under with at least a year of experience on your instrument or in vocal training, you’re welcome to join. Choose from trumpet, trombone, saxophone, clarinet, flute, bass, piano, guitar, drums, vibraphone, or voice.
The workshops are held at the New Zealand School of Music—Te Kōkī at Te Herenga Waka—Victoria University of Wellington. Follow the Jazz and Beyond Workshops on Instagram or Facebook for the latest updates. Email jazzandbeyondworkshops@gmail.com with any questions.
Schedule
The workshops run 9:00am–4:30pm Monday through Thursday, with evening activities including concerts and our inclusive jam sessions Monday, Tuesday, and Wednesday. Students perform in a closing concert on Thursday afternoon.
Accommodation
Students arrange their own accommodation. Often students from outside Wellington stay together in groups with a parent chaperone. Options for housing near Victoria University of Wellington include backpacker hostels and hotels. If you have a group of 15 or more, University Student Housing can been booked at Cumberland House. Contact info for this option is via email at Cumberland-House@vuw.ac.nz or by phone at +64 4 463 4770.
Meals
Lunch for the four days is available for purchase at many convenient locations on campus, or students may bring their own lunch.
Equipment
Provided equipment includes drum kits, guitar and bass amps, pianos/keyboards, microphones and PAs for vocalists.
All brass and wind players should bring their own instruments.
Drummers: you are required to bring your own cymbals, sticks, and hi-hat clutch.
Guitarists and bass players: you are required to bring your own instruments as well as cables (leads).
Preparation
All students with one year of experience on an instrument or in vocal training have the skills required to participate, so no musical preparation is required. On the first day, students will play a very short audition to be placed in an appropriate ensemble. Guidelines for this short audition will be sent to all registered participants in advance of the workshops.
Cost
Early bird price: $325 - register by 19th October
Standard price $350 - after 19th October
Registration is open to all until all spots are filled.
We are dedicated to ensuring all students can participate in the workshops without financial constraints. If the cost poses a barrier, please email us at jazzandbeyondworkshops@gmail.com and we will find a solution to facilitate your participation!

description:
The Life of Henry the Fifth, A young man, once revelling in freedom and reckless camaraderie, is thrust into the role of a king, burdened with the fate of England.
Victory or ruin rests on his shoulders, yet his newfound power isolates him, leaving him lost, uncertain, and deeply unsettled.
Betrayed by friends, mistrusted by his men, and taunted by those who seek his downfall, Henry’s journey is both severe and profoundly relatable.
Shakespeare crafts a world where soldiers fight without knowing why, where the battlefield sees vagrants and children stand shoulder to shoulder, where uncertain rulers navigate a landscape devoid of guidance from the past. It is a world that, despite its historical setting, feels unnervingly close to our own.
With only ten dynamic performers, this is Henry the Fifth like never before: stripped back, sharp, and driven by the raw intensity of Shakespeare’s text.
Expect fast-paced storytelling, immersive staging, and a production that puts the audience at the heart of the battle.
Full show duration: 95 min including a 15 min intermission.
“This production epitomises what can be achieved when talent, teamwork, hard work, opportunity and passion combine.’”
NZ Herald on The Tragedy of Macbeth
label: Arts & Theatre

description:
The Māori Sidesteps, Māori made mischief

Contemporary showband The Māori Sidesteps are serving crooning and comedic goodness. With soulful harmonies, satirical skits, and superb song parodies, these fullas have won rave reviews, alongside their hit webseries and TV show – and now you can catch them live on stage at Circa Theatre!

The Sidesteps flip comedic nostalgia on its head and weave stunning harmonies with theatrical play, skewering social idioms and shining a cheeky light on what it means to be Māori in 2025.

Celebrating connection and the richness of our differences, The Māori Sidesteps bring pride in identity, the strength of mana motuhake, and the reminder that joy is the best antidote to division. From government blunders to policies ripe for the picking, these top-notch entertainers take aim at the kaupapa of the moment. Expect fearless satire, wickedly subversive humour, and a refreshing dose of truth-telling disguised as hilarity.

If you’ve ever wished someone would sing what you’ve been thinking about the current political climate, The Māori Sidesteps are here to deliver Māori made mischief through waiata that wink!

Reviews:
“Never did satire and self-deprecation go hand in hand and so cleverly and entertainingly” Alan Scott – Theatreview
“A night of whakawhanaungatanga – aroha, not (too much) hōhā.” Flat City Field Notes

Tuesday 28th October – Saturday 1st November (5 shows only)
$25 – $49
Circa One
Age Recommendation PG
Audience Care: Occasional strong language & themes
Runtime: 95mins plus interval

Performances:
Tuesday 28 October 6.30pm
Wednesday 29 October 6.30pm
Thursday 30 October 6.30pm
Friday 31 October 8.00pm
Saturday 1 November 8.00pm

Cast and crew:
Writers: The Māori Sidesteps Collective
Director: Jonathan Hendry
The Māori Sidesteps Collective Cast:
-Jamie McCaskill
-Cohen Holloway
-Jerome Leota
-Cameron Clayton

description:
ROADKILL: The Uber-cool Musical - TAHI Festival, Hey everyone- we have a little change of plans!
Unfortunately, ROADKILL: The Uber-Cool Musical won’t be happening this time around, but we’re already cooking up something even better for the future. All ticket holders will receive a full refund and we can’t wait to welcome you to our next big adventure.
Thank you for your excitement and your support.
ROADKILL The Uber-Cool Musical takes you on a wildly immersive journey through love, life and rock ’n’ roll — all from the back seat of a van. This intimate one-man musical combines humour, heart and unforgettable tunes for an experience like no other.
Strap in for the rollercoaster ride of your life as we take a regular mundane occurrence of driving in an Uber and blow wide open the private life, memories and miss happenings of our hero, and driver, Terry.

Carpool karaoke meets intense love story meets wild murder mystery.

Much more than a musical, its an experience, its a journey and an attraction!

In the space of a usual cabaret show and with the help of the passengers in the van, you will witness and be part of, childhood dreams, births, deaths and marriages, high drama, dark comedy, all sung live with a kickass, original, meatloaf-esque rock soundtrack. Surprises and magic ensues as we push the van, and Terry, to the limits of what is possible.

This will be an intimate, sensory overload, in a van. A full grand musical with all the bells and whistles.

With only 9 seats available each ride, grab your mates and have a private experience in the fast lane!
The hottest ticket in town- be sure to experience the ride of your life!

The show is in the style of a musical crossed with karaoke songs you have never heard before...

The van will be stationary and parked for this initial season.

Winner of BEST IN FRINGE and EMERGING ARTIST OF THE YEAR at the Dunedin Fringe and Winner of MOST INNOVATIVE at the NZ Fringe awards this year!

Urzila Carlson - You Don't Say | Wellington, Urzila Carlson - You Don't Say | Wellington

description:

description:
“Secret” Comedy Warmup, Every year, comedians from across the motu throw their hats in the ring for the Billy T Showcase, hoping to secure a coveted nomination.

Wellington has some fantastic acts in the mix this year and before they hit the big stage, they need a proper warm-up!

This comedy workshop gives the performers a chance to road-test their sharpest material, while the audience gets a rare behind-the-scenes look at the process.

Each act will perform their showcase set, then might turn to the crowd for specific feedback—helping them fine-tune their jokes for the big night.

The evening will be held together by previous Billy T nominee Gabby Anderson, with a stellar lineup including:

Alayne Dick
Jak Darling & Booth the Clown
Kipling DC
Lily Catastrophe
Mike Fowler
Opeti Vaka
Orin Ruaine-Prattley
& Samantha Hannah

Lineup is subject to change.

This is a FREE gig but please book a general admission ticket through this event listing to save your seat!
label: Arts & Theatre

description:
Māori Sidesteps – Māori Made Mischief, Contemporary showband The Māori Sidesteps are serving crooning and comedic goodness. With soulful harmonies, satirical skits, and superb song parodies, these fullas have won rave reviews, alongside their hit webseries and TV show – and now you can catch them live on stage at Circa Theatre!

The Sidesteps flip comedic nostalgia on its head and weave stunning harmonies with theatrical play, skewering social idioms and shining a cheeky light on what it means to be Māori in 2025.

Celebrating connection and the richness of our differences, The Māori Sidesteps bring pride in identity, the strength of mana motuhake, and the reminder that joy is the best antidote to division. From government blunders to policies ripe for the picking, these top-notch entertainers take aim at the kaupapa of the moment. Expect fearless satire, wickedly subversive humour, and a refreshing dose of truth-telling disguised as hilarity.

If you’ve ever wished someone would sing what you’ve been thinking about the current political climate, The Māori Sidesteps are here to deliver Māori made mischief through waiata that wink!

Reviews:
“Never did satire and self-deprecation go hand in hand and so cleverly and entertainingly” Alan Scott – Theatreview
“A night of whakawhanaungatanga – aroha, not (too much) hōhā.” Flat City Field Notes
label: Arts & Theatre

description:
GISH: Live at Featherston Memorial RSA, GISH: Live at Featherston Memorial RSA
Join us for GISH: Live at Featherston Memorial RSA!

Date: Sunday, 26 October 2025
Time: 6:00pm - 8:00pm
Location: Featherston Memorial RSA, Featherston, Wairarapa

Comedy icon GISH is back with a brand-new tour across Aotearoa. For over 20 years, GISH has been one of New Zealand’s most beloved comedians, famous for his outrageous parodies that mix six strings with dodgy things. Get ready for a night where no song is safe. Joining him is Canadian freestyle sensation Jesse Firebrand, a razor-sharp musical comedian known for lightning-fast improvisation comedy songs, tearing through the Australian scene, with no one in New Zealand doing what he does. Your host for the night is Anthony Wilson, an Auckland-based comic and crowd favourite who has performed across Aotearoa, Australia, and the UK, known for quick wit, polished storytelling, and pub-worthy tales. There will also be a special guest on the night.
label: Arts & Theatre

description:
Airhorn Calms Down, Hi [said in a whisper], how are you, are you ready for Airhorn?
PLEASE READ. SHOW WARNING!
This is truly going to be a different Airhorn. Last month was intense, and we love intensity, but felt the need to bring it down. The focus for this month is calm. Chill. Relaxation. This is truly going to be the most gentle Airhorn you have seen.
There will be no flashing lights or threat of epilepsy. There will not be loud noises or gross out humour. There will not be airhorns! This is not a bit. We are sincerely concerned that folks are going to come to think this is a goof and expect the usual madcap, abrasive chaos of our comedy show.
There will be no abrasion. There will be no chaos. We are wanting to do the most experimental show we can do, which in our case is a low-key, cozy, warm-hearted hour of quiet reflection and gentle comedy.This is going to be a soft show for everyone who needs a minute to just breathe. You will laugh, but not enough to hurt your side or upset your neighbor. It will be a laugh held in the liminal space between a deep breath and a long sigh.
For folks in which this amount of calm is too stressful, we will also have a Stimulation Booth (provided by Wattie's) available at any time to provide the classic Airhorn jolt they need.

description:
Royal NZ Ballet Presents The Nutcracker, Summer 2025 will be celebrated with an eagerly anticipated new production of the world’s most beloved ballet classic, The Nutcracker. Central to Christmas memories for generations of audiences, The Nutcracker is a timeless celebration of family, fantasy and growing up, where ‘home for Christmas’ is the most powerful magic of all.

A uniquely Kiwi touch transports our audiences to the nostalgia of childhood holidays at the beach in Act I, before being carried in Act II to the snowy Southern Alps, where we encounter a fairytale Kingdom of the Sweets – some of which may look quite familiar…

This new production will be created by RNZB Artistic Director Ty King-Wall, with set and costume designs by Tracy Grant Lord (A Midsummer Night’s Dream, The Firebird), lighting design by Jon Buswell (Swan Lake, The Firebird, Hansel & Gretel) and visual effects by POW Studios (Cinderella, Hansel & Gretel), all driven by the timeless magic of Tchaikovsky’s wonderful music.

Live orchestra, conducted by Hamish McKeich, will accompany performances in Wellington, Christchurch and Auckland.

Pre Performance Talk Friday 31st October 6:30-7:00pm
Post Matinee Q&A Saturday 8th November 1:30pm
Audio Described Performance Saturday 8th November 1:30pm
Warm Up Curtain Up Saturday 8th November

description:
Lord of the Cock Rings - A comedy show, Two fools. One cock ring. Zero clue.
From the warped minds of Garbage City (aka comedians Mo and Joel) comes an unhinged, experimental comedy odyssey through a realm of fantasy, filth, and foolishness.
Armed with nothing but wit, wigs, and questionable props, our heroes set out on a perilous quest to uncover the true purpose of the mysterious One Cock Ring. Along the way, they’ll face dark forces, ancient secrets, and an unexpected enemy.
Will they survive the journey?
One show to rule them all. Probably.

description:
Wellington Photographic Society - Annual Exhibition 2025, The Wellington Photographic Society’s annual exhibition is a highlight of our year, bringing together the creative work of our members and sharing it with the wider public. For us, it’s not just a chance to hang photographs on the wall – it’s an opportunity to celebrate the art of photography, showcase the talent within our community, and invite others to discover what makes photography such an inspiring and accessible pursuit.
This year’s exhibition offers a diverse collection of images captured both close to home and further afield. You’ll see photographs from all around the world – landscapes, portraits, street scenes, and wildlife – but the heart of the exhibition is firmly rooted in Wellington. Our members have drawn inspiration from the beauty and variety of our own backyard: dramatic coastlines, majestic mountains, vibrant cities, and the small, fleeting details that make life unique.
We are also proud to display images created during our group meet-ups, workshops, and learning sessions. These gatherings are at the heart of what we do as a society, offering members the chance to connect, experiment, and grow their photographic skills in a supportive and friendly environment. The exhibition is therefore more than just a showcase of individual work – it’s a reflection of the shared learning, encouragement, and passion that our community thrives on.
Visitors can expect to see a wide range of styles and techniques, from classic black-and-white to bold digital artistry. Whether you are a seasoned photographer, someone with a casual interest in the medium, or simply curious to see the world through a different lens, there will be something here to inspire you.
Opening Night: 29th September, 7pm (private event, by invitation only)
Public Viewing: 30th September onwards
Opening Hours: 10am – 6pm most days, extended to 8pm on Friday/Saturday
We warmly invite you to join us, explore the exhibition, and experience the world as seen through the eyes of our members. Who knows – you may even feel inspired to pick up a camera yourself and consider becoming part of the Wellington Photographic Society.
For more information, visit: wps.org.nz

description:
The Music Made Me Do It, Directed by Jamie Burgess

Watching Jaws with the sound off = nice movie about fishing.
How about Star Wars while wearing earmuffs?

Lord of the Rings played with the Friends theme tune on repeat?

Music can make or break a blockbuster.

Let's see what happens when we devilishly mess with the soundtrack for an hour featuring some of the world's best visiting improvisers!

Expect awkward silences, melodramatic moments, powerful pauses, and guffaws galore as the music makes everything better (we hope).

description:
Roger Hall's Easy Money, A comedy plot driven farce loosely based on Ben Johnson’s Jacobean Tale The Alchemist, set in the current day. A laugh a minute tale of greed, described by Hall as having “no moral, no message – just entertainment”

An Australian couple is based in a swanky Auckland harbourside Airbnb, armed with a loose plan to shake down as many self-satisfied cashed-up “neighbours” as possible; in the hope of a quick payday and an early retirement. All about greed and how a fool and their money are soon parted; with double crosses, dirty tricks and dodgy dealings….It’s so audacious, you can see the dollar signs flickering in the eyes of their marks.

(Revised in 2022 to update and change ethnicity)
Directed by Teresa Sullivan

description:
(Re)generation next: The Poet Laureate steps down, Aotearoa New Zealand Poet Laureate Chris Tse marks the end of his term in this exciting evening with fellow poets Ken Arkind, Cadence Chung, Gregory O’Brien, Chris Price, and Ruby Solly.
Reflections on the future
Join Chris at the National Library to mark the end of his time in the role with his reflections on the future of Aotearoa New Zealand poetry and readings from special guests.
"I left the doors to the past and the future unlocked ... "
Chris Tse’s three-year term as Aotearoa New Zealand Poet Laureate ends on Phantom Billstickers National Poetry Day, when the next Poet Laureate will be announced: https://www.nzbookawards.nz/nat.../2016-national-poetry-day/
About the speakers
Chris Tse (he/him) was born and raised in Lower Hutt, New Zealand. He studied film and English literature at Victoria University of Wellington, where he also completed an MA in Creative Writing at the International Institute of Modern Letters. In 2022, he was named the 13th New Zealand Poet Laureate. His poetry, short fiction, and non-fiction have been recorded for radio and widely published in numerous journals, magazines and anthologies. He has published several collections of poetry and his latest book Super Model Minority (2022) was longlisted for the Ockham New Zealand Book Awards 2023.
Ken Arkind is an American poet, author, performer, and educator originating from Steamboat Springs in Colorado. He holds the 2006 title of the American National Poetry Slam Champion and the 2010 title of Nuyorican Poets Cafe Grand Slam Champion. Ken now resides in Auckland and is a recent graduate from the Manukau Institute of Technology’s Creative Arts Programme.
Cadence Chung (she/they) is a poet, student, and musician from Wellington, currently studying at the New Zealand School of Music. Her poems started being published in her junior years of high school, and her debut chapbook anomalia was published by We Are Babies Press in April 2022. Her writing takes inspiration from antique stores, Tumblr text posts, and dead poets.
Gregory O’Brien is a poet, painter, author, curator, and editor. His most recent poetry publication is a collection of poems and paintings, House and contents (2022). Other recent publications include a book-length meditation on the Pacific, Always song in the water (2019) and the Ockham award winning book Don Binney: Flight Path (2023).

description:
Small Towns, Kiwi Summers, Small Towns, Kiwi Summers
Presented by Tempest Theatre Co.
Directed by Emma Maguire

Forests, beaches, unbearable ennui — it's no picnic being from one of the most rural places in Aotearoa. Sometimes the best day of your life is sitting in a horrible carpark outside the Warewhare cause there's nothing else to do.

There's a tragedy in being in a place that's so far away from everywhere else. On the longest day of summer, join my friends and yours as we dream, wonder, and hope that things aren't going to change too much come February.

An improvised dramedy about leaving home, finding your feet, and fighting your way out of the wop-wops.

As this show is improvised, we cannot guarantee the presence or absence of specific content. The show may contain strong language and mature themes, including but not limited to mental health and homophobia. The show may contain voluntary audience interaction, such as giving a suggestion for a scene.

description:
The Amber Temple at Vogelmorn Upstairs, Wellington, The Amber Temple marries mysticism with gritty, ghoulish escapades of rogues and renegades. Vignettes of characters similar to you, similar to me, similar to someone you may have been or may one day become, all on the path towards the Amber Temple.
From the bowels of the molten earth, to the jowls of the predatory opportunist, to the angel casting light from celestial constellations, you will find yourself wrapped in a web from a sliver of time, a faraway place, perhaps an unknown space, as musician and dancer weave their tall tales of trials and tribulations, mortal life and looming death, unwavering love and venomous hate, environmentalism and satirical social commentary.
An original music and interpretive dance collaboration between singer-songwriter Julian Temple and contemporary dancer Amber Stephens.
Temple, known mostly for his work in the eponymous Julian Temple Band has written all new works for the project while Stephens, a trained contemporary ballet dancer and choreographer who ran her own dance company in Vienna, has choreographed the interpretive dance for this unique performance.
“A live dancer added a visceral element to an already emotional performance. Having a responsive artist interacting and interpreting the music through movement only heightened the experience. It bridged the gap between performer and audience.”
- Ed Castelow - Dictaphone Blues
“You’ll be a converted fan of The Amber Temple before they’ve even finished their first song. There’s an obvious sense of originality, coupled with carefully crafted dance moments and some of the most intense and outstanding folk songwriting you’ve heard. There’s a feeling though that nothing is premeditated and that improvisation is the star of the show - the kind of performance that requires decades of experience. Luckily for us, Julian and Amber have this in spades. Do yourself a favour, I guarantee you’ve seen nothing like it.”
- Sam Cullen - Singer/Songwriter
“Even having an understanding of the type of show The Amber Temple would be putting on when booking them - I was blown away by the amount of drama, tension and world-building Julian & Amber are able to accomplish in such an agile performance. The Amber Temple is a totally unique and utterly engaging experience which should be seen and celebrated.”
- Chris Scott - Seaside Music
Show starts at 7 Presale tickets $20 (+BF) via undertheradar.co.nz or $25 on the door
"Vogelmorn Upstairs is not a wheelchair accessible building. There is an accessible
bathroom in the space. This is an all ages venue but those under the age of 16 must be

others' and that when you leave the gig, you do so quietly to avoid disturbing our
neighbours.”

description:
Mangatainoka Motors Hot Rod Car Day, Mangatainoka Motors Hot Rod Car Day
Attention all petrolheads! Buckle up for a rip-roaring day at our Car Days, where you can flaunt your sweet ride to fellow enthusiasts and the public alike. Plus, you'll have the chance to compete for some epic prizes that are sure to rev your engine!

Get ready to soak up the atmosphere with live music, delicious grub, and a refreshing ale. Swing by the Histui Museum for a bit of nostalgia, or hit up the Tui Shop for some merch to show off your Tui pride. Or, if you’re feeling laid-back, just kick back, relax, and let the crowd admire your ride while you swap stories with mates and family.

PRIZE CATEGORIES:

We’ve got a treasure trove of fantastic prizes up for grabs! From Most Original to the ever-coveted Star of the Show, there’s something for everyone!

- Most Original – For the ride that makes jaws drop!

- Local Star – Must be from Wairarapa or Tararua (home turf pride, baby!)

- Furthest Travelled – For those brave enough to put some serious miles on the clock!

- People’s Choice – Because the crowd knows best!

- Star of the Show – Walk away with a whopping $500 Tui voucher! (You know you want it!)

KEY TIMINGS FOR THE DAY:

- 09:00 AM - Gates open for cars (let the engines roar!)

- 10:00 AM - Gates open for the public (let the ogling commence!)

- 10:45 AM - All competing cars to be parked (no late arrivals, please!)

- 11:00 AM - Registrations close (don’t miss out!)

- 11:00 AM - 12:00 PM - Judging takes place (bring your A-game!)

- 12:30 PM - Prize giving (who will take home the glory?)

- 4:00 PM - Tui Brewery closes (but we do it all again the following month!)

PRE-REGISTER YOUR VEHICLE:

Why wait? Pre-register your vehicle or bike now for just $10 online. Just jump onto the website and on the day you can just park up, and flash your email confirmation on your dashboard. Easy peasy! Just head to https://www.tuihq.co.nz/mangatainoka-motors/

And if you forget to pre-register? No sweat! You can still sign up on the day.

All proceeds from registrations go towards the Mangatainoka Motors Reserve Restoration Project. It’s a win-win!

So, gather your crew, polish that ride, and join us for a day of laughter, camaraderie, and, of course, some seriously sweet wheels. We can’t wait to see you there!

description:
JETAA Wellington - Brewkaiwa August @ The Welsh Dragon, We will be having our August Brewkaiwa at The Welsh Dragon, a cosy and quirky pub nestled in the heart of the city. With its warm atmosphere, distinctive character, and range of drinks on offer, it’s the perfect spot to relax, chat, and connect.
Brewkaiwa is JETAA’s monthly casual meetup for anyone with any connection to Japan.
We’re a diverse group of people who have studied, worked, or lived in Japan or have been invited along by someone who has.
Come join us for a brew and stay for the kaiwa! Bring your friends!
***Japanese or alcohol consumption NOT REQUIRED!***
Brewkaiwaとは
一杯いかがですか？
JETAAがウェリントンで親睦会を開催するとどうなるのか？その結果、BREWKAIWA！
2020年に始まった、ブリューカイワは、ウェリントンの様々なバーで毎月開催されている飲み会です。大人気の国際交流グルップです！！！ 日本で働いたり、住んだり、旅行したことのある人達に人気のあるイベントです！！！お酒を飲んで、友達を出来、素敵なごちそうを食べ、おまけに異文化を知られます！
日本語が話せる外国人も良く参加しているので、日本語しか話せなくても全然大丈夫です！
是非来てください！

description:

description:
A History of Violence, Details
Directed by David Cronenberg
Starring Viggo Mortensen, Ed Harris, William Hurt, Maria Bello
--- When a pair of petty criminals attempt to rob his small-town diner, Tom Stall (Viggo Mortensen) quickly and easily kills them both. In the flush of news coverage of Tom's seemingly heroic actions, a threatening stranger named Carl Fogarty (Ed Harris) comes to town, fingering the unassuming family man as long-missing Philadelphia mobster Joey Cusack. To the horror of his wife, Edie (Maria Bello), and teenage son, Jack (Ashton Holmes), Tom finds he must confront his violent past. ---

Screening on 35mm

description:
NZIFF: Mirrors No. 3, In the wake of a traumatic incident, a young woman forms a surrogate mother-daughter relationship with her rescuer. As emotional walls come down, doubts arise: is there more to the care offered than simple kindness?

Laura and Betty seem to be poles apart. Laura, a young, city dwelling music student, lives in an apartment with her boyfriend; Betty has an adult son and lives alone in rural Germany. Their lives are thrown together after a car accident leaves Laura in the care of the older woman. Despite ostensible differences, each recognises a familiar melancholy in the other. As a tentative trust grows, the women find something unlocking within themselves, even as complicating factors emerge, in the form of Betty’s opaque family situation.

Master dramatist Christian Petzold reunites with frequent acting collaborator Paula Beer (Transit, Undine, Afire) and regular DOP Hans Fromm, turning his pen and camera to a smaller scale domestic drama. Mirrors No. 3 (named for a Ravel piano piece played within) makes visual and thematic echoes back to Petzold’s previous work: from extended bike rides down rural lanes (Barbara), to the centrality of a piano (Phoenix), as well as the thread of mysterious tension that underlies them all. The film revels in the messy, stimulating complexities of human relationships, exploring the way that sometimes even questionable motivations can affect positive outcomes. — Jacob Powell

description:
Return to Babylon Documentary Film Screening, The Assyrian Church of the East Youth Association (ACEYA) (Wellington Branch) is excited to present a special screening of 'Return to Babylon'—the only one of its kind in Aotearoa New Zealand.
The documentary film takes you on an Assyrian family’s journey as they visit the Assyrian Homeland after years of living in France.
This is a story of reconnecting with one’s roots, identity, and people.
Following the screening, we will have a pre-recorded Q&A session which includes the film's director, Sébastien Daycard-Heid, and Sémiramis Ide and Agnes Ide Banipal—two of the film's protagonists.
 Synopsis:
Sémiramis is French, an Eastern Christian, and Assyro-Chaldean. In the Val-d'Oise region, this community, originally from Turkey and Iraq, has lived since the 1980s in a rhythm marked by weddings, church services, and family meals.
Shaped by the exile of their parents and the persecution their community faced under the Turkish dictatorship and Daesh, Sémiramis nurtures her roots in Assyrian civilization, originating from Mesopotamia. But the puzzle of her history no longer fits together as it once did.
Gradually, the elders are disappearing, taking with them an identity and culture that is 6,000 years old. How can this fracture be repaired, and this heritage preserved? Should they consider staying or returning to their ancestral homeland, now that peace has returned? Can one go back after decades of conflict? Can they rebuild and start anew to live in peace with themselves and others?
"Return to Babylon" is a road movie from Sarcelles to Erbil, following Sémiramis and her family on a journey that leads them to question their future in France and the fate of their community in the Middle East.
A film by Marie Dault, Sémiramis Ide, and Sébastien Daycard-Heid
Directed by Sébastien Daycard-Heid
Screen time: 52-minutes; French and Assyrian with subtitles
Link to the English-subtitled trailer: https://www.instagram.com/p/DDzsYJzt_B9/
The screening event will be held at the Cockburn Street Chapel, 1 Cockburn Street, Kilbirnie, Wellington from 5-7pm.

Entrance is free, but please register to confirm your attendance.

We welcome koha (donations) which will go towards supporting the ACEYA Wellington Branch's youth-focused activities and events.

description:
NZIFF: Young Mothers, The Dardenne brothers return with a deeply affecting drama exploring the lives of five teen mothers. Hopes and fears steer the young women towards bettering their lives for themselves and their children.

Young Mothers examines the lives of underprivileged teenagers as they come to terms with motherhood for the first time. Living together temporarily in a group home, they are taught how to care for their babies, while grappling with very different personal circumstances. The Dardenne brothers treat the characters with delicate respect while humanising the tumultuous reality that often comes with teenage motherhood.

Jessica, raised in an orphanage, cannot imagine abandoning her child and desperately seeks closure from her birth mother. Julie considers giving up her daughter for adoption, yet her own troubled mother wishes to raise the child to atone for her past mistakes. Brought up by an alcoholic mother, Perla dreams of a stable family, but her delinquent boyfriend wants nothing to do with her or their child. While Ariane has the privilege of a loving partner, both are recovering drug addicts which presents its own challenges.

This is a story of hope told through characters looking for a future free from their past. — Madison Marshall

description:
NZIFF: Dreams (Sex Love), A teenage girl recounts her crush for her teacher through the pages of a memoir. The winner of the Golden Bear 2025 is a lucid and tender chronicle of the unforgettable experience of first love.

Originally intended as the second chapter in his trilogy and released in Norway as such, Dag Johan Haugerud’s Dreams ended up premiering internationally as the last. But it secured a fitting crown to the trilogy, by winning the Best Film at the 2025 Berlinale, thus inducting Haugerud among world class auteurs.

Dreams emanates from two of Haugerud’s passions: literature, as he first gained prominence in his homeland as writer, and the cinema of French master Éric Rohmer, distinguished by sentimental skirmishes brimful of finely written dialogues.

The film’s protagonist and narrator is Johanne, a 17-year-old student who falls for her new French teacher Johanna. Johanne manages to get close to her crush, who nonchalantly ignores how her student’s devotion is veering into affection. Yet, this chronicle of first love is told in a voice over reflecting the memoir that Johanne wrote on her experience – meaning that things may or may not have happened as she says. The memoir is also read by the girl’s mother and grandmother who muse on the girl’s literary talent and provide a layer of irony and melancholy to an unfathomably lucid and tender chronicle of the universal and unforgettable experience of first love. — Paolo Bertolin
label: Film & Media

description:
Meet the Characters: Kiwi's Big Hararei, These school holidays Zealandia Te Māra a Tāne will become the playground of a host of incredible critters from the upcoming Circa Theatre children's show Kiwi's Big Hararei!

Brought to you by award-winning company Horse With No Name, this free "Meet the Characters" event features an amazing array of manu including kiwi, tūī, kārearea and tītīpounamu.

The cast of Kiwi's Big Hararei will wow tamariki with a sneak peek of their show, featuring original waiata by New Zealand singer songwriter Benny Tipene. They will also kōrero about the unique adaptations of these manu, and how we can all be kaitiaki of them.

Bring your tamariki along to engage with these colourful creatures, with stunning costume design by GRIDLEY by Victoria. Musical performance, native biodiversity and interactive theatre combine on the Heritage Lawn for an afternoon of spring fun in the sun! The team of talented children’s entertainers from Horse With No Name are so excited to share a snippet of their show Kiwi's Big Hararei with you.

Kiwi's Big Hararei will be playing at Circa Theatre over the school holidays. For more information about the show, visit www.circa.co.nz

General admission fees to the sanctuary apply, free entry for members. Should the weather turn, this event will be held the foyer of the Visitor Centre on the ground floor. Overflow carparking is available at Birdwood Street during the busy school holiday period.

description:
The Pantoloons: Cinderella, Glass slippers, royal balls, and a Fairy Godmother who’s still on her learner’s licence, what could possibly go wrong?

Prince Percy is hopelessly charming (emphasis on hopeless), the Queen is busy approving new royal wave techniques (it’s very hard work being a Queen!), the step-sisters are causing chaos in couture, and Buttons has big dreams!

Will true friendship win over fairy-tale romance? Will Buttons dreams come true? And who is behind the kingdom’s mysterious gossip vlog? Packed with music, mischief, and magical mayhem, this is Cinderella with a twist, a tune, and a whole lot of sparkle! Step into a spellbinding world of wonder where dreams shimmer, magic floats on the breeze, and anything is possible… but only until the clock strikes twelve!

REVIEWS FOR RED RIDING HOOD

“You guys were amazing, thank you so much. Me and the kids had an amazing time. We can’t wait for the next holidays t come see you again.”

“My kids had a blast! My little man was in hysterics at Mr Moa.”

“Love everything that you do and each time gets better and better.”



SEATING LAYOUT: LARGE TIERED SEATING BLOCK. For accessibility seating information and wheelchair space bookings please email events@cdc.govt.nz or call 06 379 4081 during office hours.

description:
A Walk With Katherine Mansfield - Guided Walk, In this walk of up to 75 minutes we will enjoy the gardens through the words of Katherine Mansfield. Throughout her short writing career she expressed her love of plants and the natural world. Our walk, accompanied by the words of Katherine in her 1907 charming vignette ‘In the Botanical Gardens’, will be essentially on main paths, including some uphill to the Succulent Garden, to reflect on some of her favourite plants.

Meet at the Founders’ Entrance, Glenmore Street.
Cost: $5 (cash only, please). or free for Friends.

This is part of the regular walks run by the Friends of the Wellington Botanic Garden, they run twice monthly throughout the year with a different topic every time.
Join the Friends for only $30 a year and all the walks will be free, as well as other great benefits.

description:
Women Loving Women Speed Dating, Celebrate love and connection at our Speed Dating event for women who love women!

This is a unique opportunity to meet amazing women, forge new friendships, and discover potential romantic connections in a warm, inclusive, and supportive atmosphere.
We have the use of a private function space upstairs.

When you arrive you will get a name label and your complimentary first drink, and will have time to settle in and mingle a little. You will be Speed Dating with around 10 people over the course of the evening. You will have 7 minutes to chat to each person.
You then decide if you want to meet your Speed Dates again and tick interested on your form if you do. Only if the feeling is mutual will we email you each other’s contact details.

There will be an intermission where platters of food will be served, and you can buy yourself another drink if you like.

Our event is designed to respect all boundaries and foster open, honest communication. Not everyone you meet will be your type, but we expect you to be polite. You only have to chat to them for seven minutes!

description:
Pride In Place: Creating a Community Walk Tour, Join the team from Walk Tours NZ for a free and inspiring presentation on how to create and run your own non-profit community walk tour.

Over the past seven years, Walk Tours NZ has delivered more than 100 community tours around central Wellington, focusing on the city’s rich LGBTQIA+ Rainbow heritage.

This event goes behind the scenes of creating a walk tour and is perfect for anyone passionate about bringing place-based history to light – whether it’s Rainbow histories or a topic of your own choosing.

Hosts Roger Smith and Gareth Watkins will guide you through the key ingredients of a successful non-profit walk tour – including identifying interesting stops, crafting compelling narratives, and being an engaging host – even if you’ve never done it before!

Bring your curiosity, enthusiasm and ideas, and discover why walk tours offer a unique form of living history – and how the experience can build community and connect people. No previous walk tour experience is necessary, and all are welcome.

The Queen Elizabeth II Pukeahu Education Centre (formerly the Home of Compassion Crèche) in Pukeahu Park has limited space, so registration is essential.
Please sign-up here: https://walktours.nz/book

This free community event is part of the Aotearoa Festival of Architecture 2025, organised by Walk Tours NZ in collaboration with the New Zealand Institute of Architects (Wellington Branch).

description:
Makara Churches and Historic Cottage Tour, Makara Churches and Historic Cottage Tour
The Makara Churches St Matthias and St Patricks date back to the 1800's. Monk Cottage built in 1867 is used as a local musuem for the area.

The churches and cottage will be open over one weekend from 10am till 3pm for people to visit. They are all within walking distance of each other.

Local people will be on site to talk to visitors. The cottage has information about early settlement of the area. St Patricks church has beautiful stained glass windows dedicated to early settlers. St Matthias has a graveyard where the early settlers are buried.


Cost: Koha
Event information here: https://wellingtonheritagefestival.co.nz/event/makara-churches-and-historic-cottage-tour/


Health & Safety:
No particular health and safety issues apart from possibly someone tripping on an entry step. None of the buildings have difficult entryways, only 2 or 3 steps to get inside.

The road outside is quite busy at weekends so care must be taken getting in and out of cars if parked outside the grounds. There is plenty of parking inside the venue area off the road.

description:
September Full Moon Drumming, Please remember this is a ZERO WASTE and *NO ALCOHOL* community gathering.
Kia ora!
Full Moon Drumming Wellington is a registered public event with the Wellington City Council. We are a group of humans from all walks of life who gather under the full moon each month to connect through drumming and dance around the fire. This gathering is participatory, that means if you made it to the circle you are part of the circle. As in Africa, there is no audience! Everyone is invited to participate as part of the ‘chorus’ (singing/clapping), dancing, or drumming.
The event is weather permitting, we check the forecast a few days prior and aim to make a decision the day before the event, although this is not possible and sometimes we make the decision on the day. All updates are posted on the event page.
This gathering is entirely run by volunteers, if you'd like to contribute in any way please get in touch.
There are a few things that we need help with:
- FIREWOOD: Please bring dry firewood as a koha, no wood no fire! Please NOTE we DO NOT burn pallets (due to nails) or treated timber. Driftwood from nearby south coast beaches is often abundant, feel free to post or reach out if you have a vehicle and are keen to help gather firewood on the day of the event.
- BEAUTIFYING THE CIRCLE SPACE: Anyone has fairy lights, oil burners, or is keen to make some signs?
NOTE: We hold a fire permit for this event. For safety reasons we don't allow participants to feed the fire, and while is generally okay to roast some marshmallows early in the evening we don't allow the use the fire for cooking or heating food.
This is an **ALCOHOL FREE EVENT**, please help us uphold this kaupapa and remind those who are unaware and might be new to the event. As hosts we are responsible for your safety and we take that responsibility seriously, especially given that the event is authorised through both fire and event permits. Large, public, all ages gatherings require administration and logistics so please respect this and the guidelines provided.
Princess Bay is within Taputeranga Marine Reserve (https://octopus.org.nz/taputeranga-marine-reserve), we are welcomed to gather each month in this special place so let’s all make sure there is NO RUBBISH LEFT BEHIND and that we take care of the space. Dogs are NOT ALLOWED at the gathering - there are Korora (Blue Pinguins) nesting under the rocks nearby and we've had issues with dogs in the past.
Children are welcome at the fire, though, especially after dark, please make sure that all children have adult supervision, that the supervisors are aware of the children they are looking after, and that the children are aware of who is looking after them.
Feel free to bring:
- Your friends.
- Drums or any percussive instrument.
- Warm clothing; jackets and wool blankets are good.
- Something to seat on (otherwise sand is often wet)
- Drinking water.
- Food, tea to share.
- Your lovely selves.
- Fire spinning kit and fuel.
FIRE SPINNERS: Please take all precautionary safety measures and make sure to set up fire-spinning downwind from the fire circle.
PARKING: There's a parking lot a few hundred meters from the fire circle where there's also public toilets. Please also be aware of our neighbors driveway opposite the stairway and do not park directly in front of it.
CARPOOLING: If you don't have a way to get to Princess Bay, or if you have spare seats in your car, feel free to post it on the event page. The less cars driving the better.
Feel free to share the event page and send an event invite to whomever you feel would be interested, not everyone sees the notifications and advertising

description:
Voices from the Moana: Amplifying Pacific stories of healing and resilience, Talanoa Tai Learning is a new collection of learning experiences. They're designed to help you build your cultural responsiveness and improve your ability to engage meaningfully with Pacific communities. Talanoa is a Paciﬁc style of deep dialogue, with a focus on how we connect to each other and strengthen relationships, while still being able to share honest and eﬀective insights. Tai refers to ocean waters, which represent your opportunity to rise through the ebb and ﬂow of this learning journey. If you want to strengthen your capability in this space, to create transformational change, and to enhance your relationships with people from diﬀerent communities - this workshop is your chance to grow.
What will I gain from Voices from the Moana?
In Voices from the Moana, you will explore and share rich narratives of healing and resilience from different Pacific nations and perspectives. The Pacific ocean is a diverse place and we have our own unique stories of healing through traditional practices, beliefs and methods. This Talanoa Tai learning experience invites reflection on your own understanding of different healing modalities from the Pacific and the impact it has on your worldview. It will equip you to advocate for social justice through Pacific voices. You'll gain practical tolls and insights that you can apply directly to your work.
This is a 3 hour in-person learning experience.
Who is this workshop for?
These learning experiences are for both Paciﬁc professionals and those from other communities. You don’t need to have prior knowledge or experience in this area - we’ll meet you where you are and provide a welcoming, supportive environment for you to learn.
Cultural responsiveness is for everyone. Whether you’re in social work, education, government, community sectors or beyond, these learning experiences have been designed to help everyone build their skills. If you think this professional development might be right for you, it is!
Cost
When work is busy and budgets are tight, cultural responsiveness can often take a backseat. But this is an aﬀordable investment that will help you address the challenges that so many of us share, like how to build engagement and trust, and avoid relationship missteps. It’s not a buzzword; it’s a vital skill if you want to better meet the needs of the people you serve. Price: $170 (inc GST) per person, including morning tea.
 Facilitator
Our team’s extensive research and experience feed into these sessions, with a focus on interactive activities and practical, real-life examples. Our team has decades of experience across a range of ﬁelds, in particular social development, education, and research. We have worked with organisations and businesses across the Paciﬁc, and our engagement with diﬀerent Paciﬁc languages, cultures, and communities means we oﬀer robust, informed perspectives. Fa’aeafale’upolu (Polu) Samuelu is the facilitator of this Talanoa Tai Learning experience.

description:
Fareham Journey Free Cohousing Information & Tour, Fareham Journey is building a sustainable cohousing community in Pae Tū Mōkai, Featherston and they are looking for people who share their kaupapa to create this with us. The Fareham property has extensive grounds which includes a historic home, and established organic gardens, an orchard, and fields. It even has an arts community on site.

We run these free cohousing information and tour events on the third Sunday of every month, from noon until 2pm at Fareham, 80 Underhill Road, Pae Tū Mōkai, Featherston in the South Wairarapa.

Learn about the Fareham Journey and our vision to create a sustainable and supportive community and how you can get involved. We invite you to bring a plate of vegetarian food to join us for a shared meal in the historic homestead, Fareham House, followed by the tour.

Ensure you RSVP to attend at https://farehamjourney.nz/rsvp/

description:
Plimmerton Rotary Garden Tour 2025, Join us for a Springtime treat- a tour of ten gardens around the Pauatahanui Harbour.

The gardens are varied, from bijou suburban hideaways to a lifestyle block, and from an 1860s cottage garden to a modern design gem. They are testaments to the care and creativity of their owners.

Included is the iconic Heritage Rose Garden beside St Alban’s church in Pauatahanui, which features legacy and modern rose varieties around the burial ground.

Gardeners will be inspired by the experience - it will be an unforgettable day out.

Times - Gardens are open from 9.30 am to 4.30 pm on both days, except for the Pauatahanui Rose Garden/Burial Ground, which will be closed on Sunday morning until 1 pm.

Garden competition – A prize voted for by entrants for the “Best Garden” for Consultancy Services has been offered by Distinctive Home and Landscapes Limited to the value of $600. Other spot prizes will be drawn at the end of each day for entrants.

Ticket holders:


Note that when ticketing, select the Zone to start at: Camborne, Paremata/Aotea, Whitby, or Pauatahanui.

Preplan your garden tour from the map provided when tickets are issued, and have the plan available on the day.

Note that every effort is made to ensure gardens are as safe as practicable. All gardens are entered at visitors’ risk.

must obtain the garden owner's consent if you wish to take cuttings.

Note that the event will occur wet or fine, pets are not allowed, and no ticket refunds will be available.


This is a Plimmerton Rotary fundraiser for community benefit, and net proceeds will be shared by:


Gillies McIndoe Foundation, founded by Dr Swee Tan, benefits research work in developing accessible life-changing treatment options for brain cancer, vascular birthmarks and keloid scars through the use of affordable repurposed medications. https://www.gmri.org.nz/

“HAROLD” - North Wellington Life Education Trust - visits primary schools with an intriguing mobile classroom, furthering the Education of unique Life Skills for primary school children in the Porirua Johnsonville regions. northwellington@lifeed.org.nz


A special thanks to Titahi Bay Horticultural Society for their early support.

description:
Wairarapa Bookshop Hop 2025, The best booksellers in Wairarapa have come together to give you the ultimate book-lovers day out in celebration of New Zealand Bookshop Day.

This year, you can collect stamps from 13 new and used Wairarapa Bookshops and enjoy a range of other bookish events all day long.

One of the (many) great things about Wairarapa is we have 13 fantastic bookshops all within an easy 30 minute drive of one another, so it's entirely possible for you to hop around all 13 bookshops in a single day.

Celebrate NZ Bookshop Day with a Wairarapa wide Bookshop Hop. It's your chance to win lots of prizes and stock up your bookshelf.

STEP 1:
Pick up an official passport from any of the participating bookshops - available from all participating stores from Friday October 10th.

STEP 2:
Collect a stamp from each store you visit and make a purchase. Each stamp is an entry into the prize draws for $1,000 in bookshop vouchers.

STEP 3:
Leave your stamped entry with the last bookshop you visit.

This event happens rain or shine!

Register for free to stay up to date and for an extra chance to win a prize: bookshopday.nz/
