Hutt City Night Market

📍 Location: Dowse Square, Laings Road, Lower Hutt
📅 Date: Thursday, 18 September 2025
🕓 Time: 4:00 PM – 8:00 PM

Come down to Dowse Square every Thursday from 4–8PM, rain or shine, and enjoy a handpicked line up of local food trucks serving a delicious range of cuisines. It’s the perfect way to unwind after work, catch up with friends and whānau, and support small local businesses.

Expect:
🍔 Tasty street food from around the world
🎶 Laid-back vibes and community spirit
🛍️ A weekly night out to look forward to

📢 We’ll be announcing weekly vendor line ups and tasty updates on our Wellington Street Eats Hub Facebook page — so be sure to like and follow us to stay in the loop!

This is just the beginning — we’ll be at Dowse Square for the first 4 weeks, before moving to our long-term home on Daly Street by the Riverbank Carpark with even more food trucks!

Bring your appetite, tell your mates, and we’ll see you there!

#HuttCityNightMarket #LowerHuttEats #StreetFoodVibes #SupportLocal #NightMarketNZ

description:
Not Your Nana's Craft Market - R18 Art and Craft Market, *Strictly R18*
Are you ready for a unique and thrilling experience? Look no further! We invite you to the most captivating event of the year - the Creepy-Cute, Witchy, Kinky, Sexy, LGBTQIA+ Friendly Alternative Art and Craft Market!

What to Expect
Get ready to immerse yourself in a world where art and craft meet the dark and mysterious. This market is not for the faint of heart! Here's what you can expect:
1. Creepy-Cute Delights: Explore a wide range of art and craft creations that blend the creepy and cute aesthetics. From adorable monsters to spooky dolls, you'll find something to tickle your fancy.
2. Witchy Wonders: Dive into the world of witchcraft and magic. Discover spellbinding artwork, mystical jewelry, and enchanting potions. Embrace your inner witch or warlock!
3. Kinky Curiosities: For those who enjoy a touch of kink, we have a selection of unique and provocative art and crafts, and kink wear. Explore the boundaries of sensuality and embrace your desires in a safe and inclusive environment.
4. Sexy Sensations: Indulge in the world of sensuality and erotic art. Discover captivating paintings, sculptures, and photography that celebrate the beauty of the human form. Embrace your sexuality with pride!
5. LGBTQIA+ Friendly: This market is a safe space for all members of the LGBTQIA+ community. Celebrate diversity and inclusivity as you explore the wide range of art and craft offerings.
6. Alternative Art and Craft: Step outside the mainstream and explore the alternative side of creativity. From gothic to steampunk, from punk to cyberpunk, you'll find a variety of unique and unconventional art and craft pieces.
Join Us!

Don't miss out on this extraordinary event! Mark your calendars and invite your friends. Get ready to be amazed, inspired, and maybe even a little bit spooked. See you at the Creepy-Cute, Witchy, Kinky, Sexy, LGBTQIA+ Friendly Alternative Art and Craft Market!
It definitely will NOT be your nana's market! See less

The Artisan Craft Market is a premium handmade event that takes place across various locations in the broader Wellington region. This high-quality market is designed to foster a welcoming and friendly atmosphere.

Our vision at Artisan Craft Market is to make the market accessible to those who appreciate shopping locally. We aim to provide a platform that supports local artisans, allowing them to showcase their meticulously crafted, high-quality products. By bringing the market directly to the people, we hope to celebrate and promote the unique talents of our community’s skilled artisans.

- Permaculture orchard tours & explore our first polyculture maze

description:
XTrail Spring - Battle at Boulder Hill, XTrail Spring - Battle at Boulder Hill
Boulder Hill offers up a classic slice of Wellington trail running - rugged, scenic, and deeply rewarding. Set in the Belmont Regional Park, the three courses take you through a mix of lush native bush, open ridgelines, and rolling farmland with epic views across the Wellington harbour, Hutt Valley, and out to the coast. The short course is a compact loop with punchy climbs and flowing descents, while the long course gives you the full Boulder Hill experience — a steady climb from the valley floor to the summit, followed by sweeping downhills and one final sting in the tail before you loop back to base. A true taste of the terrain that makes this region so special.

https://barefootxtrail.co.nz/

The Festival gate is open from 3pm on the Friday, with events running over Friday evening, all day Saturday through to Sunday evening. You can come for the weekend, for a day, half day or an evening. Children (0 - 12) can attend free.

description:
Martinborough Music Festival 2025, Bringing the world to Martinborough for chamber music in the heart of South Wairarapa.

Join us for four exciting concerts over three days, featuring stunning New Zealand and international artists including Natalia Lomeiko (violin), Yuri Zhislin (violin/viola), Matthias Balzat and Ashley Brown (cello), Jian Liu (piano), Wilma Smith and Donald Armstrong (violin), Simon Brew (saxophone) and Caroline Henbest (viola).

These artists will bring to life extraordinary works including Zoltán Kodály's Duo for Violin and Cello, Op. 7; JS Bach's Goldberg Variations for string trio; Shostakovich's Piano Quintet in G minor, Op. 57 and Mozart's String Quintet No. 5 in D major, K.593.

The Sunday afternoon concert will also include the world premiere of Shifting Worlds, a piano quintet by renowned New Zealand composer Louise Webster, who has special ties with South Wairarapa.

Visit martinboroughmusicfestival.co.nz for more information about artists, programmes and links to ticket sales.

description:
Ultimate Tribute Fest 2: Dimebag and Ozzy Memorial Show, Ultimate Tribute Fest 2: Dimebag and Ozzy Memorial Show
Ultimate Tribute Fest 2: A Memorial for Metal Legends
Rail Records, Wildkiwi Distillery, Women's Refuge, and Rockstock present a monumental night of heavy metal in honor of two of the genre's most important and beloved figures: the legendary guitarist "Dimebag" Darrell Abbott of Pantera, and the recently departed Godfather of Metal, Ozzy Osbourne.

Join us on Saturday, December 6th, 2025, at Wildkiwi in Upper Hutt for a memorial show that will shake the foundations. This date holds a special importance to us metal heads, falling just three days after what would have been Ozzy's 77th birthday (December 3rd) and just two days before the anniversary of Dimebag's tragic passing (December 8th, 2004), giving us all a chance to raise a glass and celebrate both legends in the loudest way possible.

This is a night to pay tribute to the artists who defined a generation of heavy music. From Dimebag's revolutionary groove and unmistakable harmonic squeals to Ozzy's haunting vocals and iconic stage presence, their impact is eternal. We invite the metal community to come together for an unforgettable evening of remembrance, unity, and blistering riffs.

The Lineup
Prepare for a full-throttle sonic assault from four of New Zealand's premier tribute acts, performing the anthems that have become the soundtrack to our lives:

•Hell's Wrath delivering the ferocious power of Pantera

•Zombie Stomp (ft. Danny Rascal) channeling the madness of Ozzy Osbourne

•Angel Dust performing the eclectic genius of Faith No More

•Demon Fetal Harvest unleashing the thrash mastery of Megadeth

(More bands to be announced!)

Event Details
•Date: Saturday, December 6, 2025

•Venue: Wildkiwi, Unit 13/27 Blenheim Street, Maidstone, Upper Hutt

•Time: Doors open at 6:00 PM

•Age Restriction: This is a strictly R18 event. ID will be required.

•Charity: We will be accepting donations at the event and at point of sale on behalf of Women's Refuge. Your support is greatly appreciated.

Ticket Information
Secure your spot to witness this massive tribute event. Tickets are on sale now!

•$20 Early Bird (+GST/BF) - Limited quantity available! Grab them before they're gone.

•$30 General Admission (+GST/BF)

•$40 Door Sales/Lates (If not sold out prior)

VIP Table Experience - Only 6 Available!
For the ultimate night out, gather your crew and secure a VIP table.

Price: $240 per table (includes 6 tickets - works out to $40 per person)

Perks:

•Guaranteed reserved seating for your group of 6.

•Early venue access from 4:00 PM to settle in and have a meal.

•10% discount on delicious bar food from the Wildkiwi kitchen.

•First dibs on the merch table.

•Check out soundcheck and meet the bands (where possible).

Limited Edition Merchandise

•Commemorate this special night with a limited edition T-shirt. There are only 20 of these shirts being made, so this is a true collector's item. Available as a ticket add-on. Don't miss out!

This show is a tribute, a memorial, and a celebration. Get your tickets now and be part of a historic night for New Zealand's metal scene.

description:
Conservation Kōrero: Underwater Forests of Wellington, Towering seaweed forests and colourful sponge gardens lie just beneath the surface of Wellington’s coastline. Like forests on land, these underwater habitats support a remarkable diversity of life, including treasured kaimoana species. Yet they face growing pressure from human activity and environmental change.
Dr Nicole Miller will take us on a visual journey through Wellington’s Blue Belt, exploring current conservation successes and challenges. Drawing on years of diving, photography and local restoration work, Nicole will highlight the beauty and fragility of these ecosystems and why it’s more important than ever to bring changes to the surface.
This event will be held in the Pāteke Room in the Visitor Centre with light refreshments provided. Doors open at 6:00pm, parking is available at both our Visitor Centre and overflow parking area on Birdwood Street.
Nicole’s seaweed artworks will be on display at Zealandia Te Māra a Tāne from 1 August to 30 September, with all profits supporting Explore Your Coast: www.exploreyourcoast.co.nz/docu.
label: Conservation & Environment

description:
Future Architecture of the Network (FAN) Conference 2026, Kia ora!
Electricity and electrification are seen as the significant enablers for decarbonisation of our nation. The Future Architecture of the Network (FAN) | Te Whatunga Hiko programme aspires to meet the challenges the electrical power system will face as we journey towards sustainable decarbonisation.
Our vision is to provide an infrastructure paradigm through a hybrid AC/DC transmission and distribution system that meets the needs of tomorrow’s efficient, low-carbon, reliable and resilient electrical power system.
Funded as part of the New Zealand Government’s Strategic Science Investment Fund (SSIF) on Advanced Energy Technology Platform (AETP), the research team is investigating what the future electrical power system might look like.
Hear about the team’s latest achievements as we approach the final phase of the programme.
Attendance is in person at Victoria University Wellington.
Ngā mihi nui,
Prof. Neville Watson,
Science Leader
The detailed programme will be circulated closer to the event.
 More information on the research can be found at https://www.fan.ac.nz/
If you have any questions, please contact futurearchitecturenetwork@canterbury.ac.nz

This timely event brings together perspectives on international cooperation, policy innovation, and the urgent challenges of our climate future. Whether you're passionate about sustainability, international relations, or meaningful dialogue, this event offers value, inspiration, and connection.

description:
The Power of Community - Dr Amanda Cahill, "What does it take for communities to lead the renewable energy transition - not just be consulted?"
If one person is positioned well to respond to that question, it is Dr Amanda Cahill.
Goodlife Collective, Sustainability Trust and WEAll Aotearoa are proud to be co-hosting Dr Amanda Cahill, founder of The Next Economy
Don't miss this opportunity to hear Amanda's insights from her work in Australia, which demonstrate how acting on climate change can help catalyse fairer, more regenerative wellbeing economies.
Amanda has worked at the intersection of government, local councils, big companies and communities for 30 years, to support communities to transition to a thriving future.
Amanda is the Founder of The Next Economy, where she supports regional communities across Australia to manage the impacts of decarbonisation and climate change in a way that builds more equitable and regenerative economies. Most of this work has been in coal and industrial regions, where she has brought together government, industry, workers and community groups to co-design transition strategies despite deep-seated tensions. Her work draws on 30 years’ experience working with changemakers across the world to address economic and health inequalities, environmental degradation, women’s rights and climate justice.
Event Programme:
5:15pm - doors open, drinks & nibbles
5:45pm - Welcome & Introduction
6:00-6:30pm - Talk from Dr Amanda Cahill
6:40 - Dialogues & Q&A
7:00(ish!): Networking

About Sustainability Trust: Sustainability Trust are your local experts in sustainability, healthy homes, ethical electricity and supporting our local communities.
About WEAll Aotearoa: WEAll Aotearoa is a non-partisan and independent ‘think and do’ tank working to redesign Aotearoa New Zealand’s economy around the wellbeing of our people and te taiao. WEAll use an evidence-informed approach and focus upstream to develop practical, long-term solutions for the public good.

About Goodlife Collective: Goodlife Collective designs and delivers events and experiences to build connection between people, nature and valuable ideas, in service of unlocking our collective potential.
About Dr Amanda Cahill
Amanda is the Founder of The Next Economy, where she supports regional communities across Australia to manage the impacts of decarbonisation and climate change in a way that builds more equitable and regenerative economies. Most of this work has been in coal and industrial regions, where she has brought together government, industry, workers and community groups to co-design transition strategies despite deep-seated tensions. Her work draws on 30 years’ experience working with changemakers across the world to address economic and health inequalities, environmental degradation, women’s rights and climate justice.
Amanda is a Churchill Fellow and has a PhD from ANU in human geography. She is also a Research Fellow at the University of Melbourne, an Industry Fellow at the University of Sydney and a co-editor of the recently published book: Regional Energy Transitions in Australia: From impossible to possible.
About The Next Economy
Next Economy works with government, industry, investment and community to create the conditions for a rapid, responsible and fair transition to a climate-safe, regenerative and socially just Australian economy.

description:
Ruamahanga Farm learning day, At this Toru Trail, we look forward to a day of planting, learning and creativity at Ruamāhanga Farm. Just outside Martinborough, Ruamahanga Farm Foundation are bringing the local community together to help restore wetlands and provide greater access to the awa. The restoration is a foundation for Te Reo o te Wai, an arts and conservation programme for local primary schools.


Our hosts Jane Riddiford and Rod Sugden will share the story of the land and the conversion of a traditional stock and crop farm into a regenerative, community oriented venture. They will involve us in some of the experiential ways they are helping children and young people connect to hidden places along the Ruamāhanga. The day will include planting trees and grasses along a new wetland walk combined with nature based story telling, art and creative writing. We will have a shared lunch by the awa or under canvas if it is wet.

description:
Forest & Bird: Every Last Bird – Birds of Te Araroa Trail, Every Last Bird – Birds of Te Araroa Trail

Book your place now to reserve a chair.

Between November 2023 and March 2024, Te Papa natural history curator Dr Colin Miskelly walked the length of Aotearoa New Zealand on Te Araroa Trail – counting every bird seen or heard along the way. His talk will cover some of the logistics of walking the trail, as well as a summary of the birds encountered. This included looking at what difference (if any) predator trapping had on the abundance of native birds. For a taste of what the talk will cover, see Te Araroa Trail | Te Papa’s Blog.

Colin Miskelly on Mt Crawford, Tararua Ranges:

description:
Climate Fresk Workshop in Wellington, Do you want to be part of the solution to tackle climate change but don’t have the time to become a climate scientist? Join us for a 3-hour interactive workshop to explore the causes and consequences of climate disturbances.
Based on the IPCC report and played by over 2 million people worldwide, this collaborative workshop allows you to understand the key issues of climate change to empower you to take action.
How it works:
The workshop is based on a 42-card game. Each card represents an element, a cause or a consequence of climate change.
In teams, guided by your facilitator, you are encouraged to find the cause-effect relationship between the different components of climate change. Collective intelligence will get you from one deck of card to the next!
This step-by-step reconstruction provides keys to understand the complexity and develop an overview of climate change.
Agenda:
Introduction, 15 mins
Fresk Card Game, 1 1/2 hours
Debrief and Actions, 1 hour 15 mins
Climate Fresk is an excellent opportunity to understand the key elements of climate change and what you can do to be part of the solution. No previous climate knowledge is needed.

Tea, coffee and snacks will be served during the short break. Workshop run by Climate Training Co. Ltd. Donations welcome!
label: Conservation & Environment

description:

description:
Designing Tomorrow: The SDG Blueprint for Built Environment Futures, Designing Tomorrow: The SDG Blueprint for Built Environment Futures
📅 Wednesday, 1 October 2025
🕔 5:00–7:30 PM (Networking from 5:00 PM | Panels 5:30–7:30 PM)
📍 Te Aro Campus, Faculty of Architecture and Design Innovation, Victoria University of Wellington (139 Vivian Street)
The built environment is at the heart of Aotearoa’s response to the United Nations Sustainable Development Goals SDGs). The way we plan, design, and construct our cities influences how we live — and how we tackle challenges such as climate change (SDG 13), sustainable cities and communities (SDG 11), affordable housing and equity (SDG 10),
responsible consumption and production (SDG 12), and partnerships for action (SDG 17).
This event is part of SDG Action Month 2025, a global campaign that highlights how communities, institutions, and industries are accelerating progress toward the 2030 Agenda.
For Aotearoa, the conversation is urgent: how can planning, design, and construction shape a sustainable, equitable, and climate-resilient future?
The evening will open with a keynote address that sets the stage with global perspectives on sustainability and the role of the built environment in achieving the SDGs.
Two panels will then explore critical themes:
• Planning + Place + People — equity, housing futures, cultural identity, indigenous leadership, and policy alignment.
• Materials + Methods + Innovation—construction technology, green standards, digital tools, and carbon-conscious practice.
Alongside the discussions, attendees can view a Student Showcase from the School of Architecture and the School of Design Innovation, and contribute to a Blueprint Wall by writing their own pledges on SDG Commitment Cards, ensuring the event concludes with collective action as well as ideas.
📌 Free to attend | Open to all | RSVP required

description:
Launching in-store: Capital Trees by Susette Goldsmith, Join us in celebrating the recent launch of Capital Trees: The Arboreal Legacy of Te Upoko-O-te-Ika the Wellington Region by Susette Goldsmith, author/editor of Tree Sense: Ways of Thinking About Trees.
"The significance and meaning of trees engagingly explored through the way they have shaped our capital.
From the fossil forest of Tītahi Bay and the ageing oak on Plimmer Steps, to the karaka grove on Wellington’s waterfront and a threatened stand of lowland beech in the Hutt Valley, Capital Trees journeys across the region to trace the living legacies of the city’s rich tree heritage and the many people who have shaped, protected and challenged it.
These legacies include arguments around heritage tree listing, the native versus exotics debate, biodiversity, attitudes towards heritage authenticity, trees as monuments and more, explored through facts, anecdotes and field notes.
Illustrated with contemporary photography and specimen illustrations of the species and individual trees covered, this book is a must for all who live in the Wellington region."
All welcome! See you at the signing table.

description:
Te Hononga hikoi: Taupō Swamp, Te Hononga hikoi: Taupō Swamp
Te Hononga hīkoi enable our members to connect with others in the Wellington Catchments Collective. It's pretty inspiring seeing the activities happening in other catchment groups.

The next Te Hononga hikoi will be at Taupo Swamp in Porirua on the morning of Sunday 21 September at 10am – 11.30pm approx.

Come for a spring stroll and bring friends and family. Bring water and own snacks or fuel up at nearby cafes in Plimmerton.

We will meet in Ulric Street by the pedestrian bridge entrance to the dog park (plenty of parking)

Friends of Taupo Swamp & Catchment Inc was formed in 2018 by a group of Porirua residents. Restoration activities have been focused on the part of the wetlands that is owned by Porirua City Council.

Back in 2018 there was a lot of blackberry on the site. Now, some of the 2019-20 locally sourced plantings by volunteers are 5 metres high. By the end of the current planting season FOTSC will have put in 18K plants. An adjacent planting programme around the Plimmerton Domain coordinated by the local Rotary Club and the Porirua City Council has resulted in 22k trees and plants.

Please register your interest/intention to attend by flicking a short email to . In the event of bad weather we will advise cancellation by 8am and rescheduling for a week later.

description:
Club Tropicana, This August, Beach Babylon becomes Club Tropicana, a retro, romantic escape inspired by 1960s tropical honeymoons, classic tiki bars and vintage beach glamour. Picture golden sunsets, flamingos, thatched umbrellas and the carefree buzz of a sun-soaked getaway, right in the heart of Wellington. No passport required.

The menu is vibrant and full of escapist flair. Start with coconut prawns and banana blossom kokoda, then dive into mains like mango glazed  pork rib rack or the tropical tofu paneer curry. Save room for dessert: pineapple upside-down pudding or a coconut rum fondue to bring the tropical fantasy to a sweet finale. Behind the bar, the tiki and kava-spiked cocktails flow freely, from Blue Hawaiian’s to retro rum punches, all dressed to impress with flamingo stirrers, umbrellas and tropical garnishes.

A golden-age soundtrack sets the mood, featuring the smooth calypso of Harry Belafonte, beachy vibes from The Beach Boys, and sun-drenched classics by Astrud Gilberto.

Club Tropicana is a winter getaway, fun and fabulously over the top.

description:
Michelin Star to Martinborough, Join celebrated Chef and Union Square owner Adam Newell for a once-in-a-lifetime culinary experience. Take a journey through four decades of his exceptional career, including his Michelin-starred tenure at the renowned Fulham Road Restaurant in London. This exclusive event will offer an intimate exploration of Chef Newell's evolution as a chef and restaurateur, showcasing iconic dishes from four pivotal periods in his career.

Set in the elegant Napoleon dining room inside the historic Martinborough Hotel, each course represents a defining moment in Chef Newell’s career. Paired with fine wines selected by in-house Sommelier Carl Fraser, this evening is designed to be a feast for both the palate and the mind.

Course 1: 1980s – Claridge’s Hotel, London
A taste of the refined sophistication from one of London’s most prestigious hotels.
Course 2: 1990s – Le Gavroche, London
A nod to the classic French techniques that helped shape Chef Newell's early career.
Course 3: 2000s – Zibibbo, Wellington
A celebration of New Zealand’s finest ingredients and a significant step in his culinary journey.
Course 4: 2010s – Union Square Bistro, Martinborough
Reflecting his achievements at Union Square, the course that represents his current culinary vision.

This evening offers guests a unique chance to experience the evolution of one chef's journey through extraordinary dishes paired with wines that elevate each moment.

description:
Government Digital Transformation in Latin America - what can we learn?, We are excited to announce the latest in our series of talks on Digital Transformation, in partnership with Silverstripe.
María Inés Baque will be joining us online from Argentina to share her expert insights and experiences on the key goals, capabilities, opportunities and challenges for government digital transformation - with a range of use cases from around Latin America.
María Inés Baque is Government Transformation Advisor for Latin America, Canada, and the Caribbean (LCC) at AWS. She served as secretary of digital government and technology innovation in Argentina from 2016 to 2019. She coordinated the Digital Agenda 2030 and led the transformational efforts in the areas of digital services, digital inclusion, open government, open data and new technologies adoption.
Global awards and recognitions she has received include Innovation Lab, Tel Aviv, 20 exceptional GovTech Leaders (2020), Women Corporate Directors 2019 and The 100 Most Influential People in Digital Government, Apolitical, 2018.
She was co-chair of the G20 Digital Economy Taskforce for Gender Inclusion in 2018 that issued the Bridging the Digital Gender Divide report.
Before government, her career was in global IT and financial services enterprises. She focused on process reengineering, startups, IT management, outsourcing and business process operations.
You may attend in person at the MBIE offices (limited to 40 people - there will be some food courtesy of Silverstripe), or you may tune in online via Microsoft Teams (the link will be at the bottom of your order confirmation email). If you choose to attend in person please arrive at 11.50am so there is time for you to sign in, pick up some food, and be seated before we begin. There will be time for questions after the presentation.

description:
2025 Taiwan Update Lectures, Taiwan’s Multidimensional Energy Security Challenges
Professor Chyungly Lee
A stable and reliable energy supply is essential for a nation’s economic growth and development. In selecting fuel sources, nowadays almost all countries have taken climate change into account, adopted sensible clean energy transition plans, and designed a schedule to meet the goal of Net Zero. While pursuing a 3-E (energy-economic-environmental) balanced energy supply strategy, Taiwan, lacking indigenous resources, faces unique challenges of supply disruptions from over dependence on energy imports and possible blockade, quarantine, or invasion from Beijing. Any disruption of power supply or surge of energy costs could not only threaten Taiwan’s competitive edge in the global high-tech market but also undermine Taiwan’s internal stability and the nation’s survival. In this talk, Dr. Chyungly Lee will first present fact sheets on Taiwan’s energy status, summarize Taiwan’s current energy strategy, and then discuss dilemmas and vulnerabilities that Taiwan might face in the next few years.
What does Taiwan’s two-level politics tell us?
Professor Alex Tan
This presentation examines Taiwan as a critical case study for understanding the evolving challenges to democracy in the 21st century. Arguing that Taiwan serves as a “canary in the coalmine,” the analysis highlights how the island’s early and persistent political polarization—rooted in identity politics and the legacies of authoritarian rule—prefigures trends now visible in established democracies worldwide. The research explores how deep divisions between the Kuomintang (KMT) and Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), reinforced by institutional and social factors, have led to legislative gridlock, declining trust in political institutions, and a “democratic ceiling” that constrains further democratic development. Taiwan’s precarious geopolitical position, facing constant pressure from the People’s Republic of China, intensifies the dilemma of balancing national security with the protection of civil liberties. The presentation analyzes Taiwan’s innovative responses to disinformation, foreign interference, and public health crises, illustrating both the resilience and fragility of democratic systems under external and internal stress.
Gaming Taiwan: Indigenous Epistemologies in Play
Associate Professor Chia-rong Wu
This research explores how Indigenous knowledge systems in Taiwan are being revitalized through video games. Far from mere entertainment, these games draw on tribal traditions, ancestral stories, and deep connections to the land to create meaningful digital experiences. By blending oral storytelling with interactive gameplay, Taiwanese Indigenous game developers are preserving cultural memory while challenging colonial legacies. Titles like Princess Baleng, Tayal, VuVu, and Gadvia show how games can empower communities and pass down wisdom to younger generations in innovative and engaging ways. Gamers not only play a game but also immerse themselves in digital environments shaped by Indigenous perspectives and values. This study encourages all engaged audiences, including educators and students, to consider video games as powerful tools for cultural resurgence and learning. Focusing on Indigenous Taiwan, it highlights how digital games integrate historical consciousness and interactivity to reimagine the past and future of the island.

description:
The Challenges of Peacebuilding, In this conversation, Dr David Harland will reflect on his experience working as a mediator and negotiator in conflict zones and his role as Director of the Geneva-based Centre for Humanitarian Dialogue. The Centre was awarded the Carnegie Wateler Peace Prize in 2022 “for its track record of finding the means, including mediation, to bring parties together and end conflicts”. Its work has included involvement in Aceh and Mindanao, assisting with the disbanding of the Basque separatist group ETA, and the Black Sea Grain Initiative. David will share insights on the challenges of peacebuilding in an era of growing competition and contestation.
Dr David Harland is a former New Zealand diplomat and Executive Director of the Centre for Humanitarian Dialogue (HD), a Geneva-based foundation that specialises in the mediation of armed conflict. He previously worked for the United Nations, including in Bosnia, Kosovo, Haiti and Timor Leste, and he wrote the UN Secretary-General’s landmark report on the fall of Srebrenica. David serves on the UN Secretary-General’s high-level advisory board on mediation. He has degrees from Harvard University, Tufts University, Beijing University and Te Herenga Waka—Victoria University of Wellington.
The event will be followed by light refreshments.

description:
Putin’s Russia and Southeast Asia: The Kremlin’s Pivot to Asia and the Impact of the Russia-Ukraine War, Dr Ian Storey will discuss his new book on Russia’s relations with Southeast Asia. The first major study of Russia and Southeast Asia since the end of the Cold War, it traces the dramatic shifts in Moscow’s relations with the region since President Vladimir Putin took power in 2000. Dr Storey assesses the legacy of the Soviet Union, charts the evolution of Putin’s foreign policy and identifies the drivers behind the Kremlin’s ‘Turn to the East’ or Asia pivot. His book also examines Russia’s dialogue partnership with the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) and the development of Moscow’s political, economic and military ties with each of the 11 regional states over the past 25 years. A large part of the book is devoted to Southeast Asia’s responses to Russia’s full-scale invasion of Ukraine in February 2022. At the end of the talk Dr Storey will also provide an update of Russia-Southeast Asia relations in 2025 and how the region views the on-going Russia-Ukraine War.
Dr Ian Storey is a Senior Fellow at the ISEAS-Yusof Ishak Institute, Singapore. He specializes in regional security issues, focusing on Southeast Asia’s relations with the major powers and maritime security, especially the South China Sea dispute. Since joining ISEAS in 2007 he has been the editor of the ISEAS academic journal Contemporary Southeast Asia. Prior to ISEAS, Ian held academic positions at the Asia-Pacific Center for Security Studies, Hawaii and at Deakin University, Australia. Ian received his PhD from the City University of Hong Kong, his Master’s degree from the International University of Japan and his BA (Hons) from the University of Hull, England. He is the author of Putin’s Russia and Southeast Asia: The Kremlin’s Pivot to Asia and the Impact of the Russia-Ukraine War (2025) and Southeast Asia and the Rise of China: The Search for Security (2011)

description:
Taiwan’s Economic Statecraft and the future of Liberal International Order, Taiwan’s Economic Statecraft and the future of Liberal International Order
Associate Professor Christina Lai will speak on Taiwan's trade practices against the backdrop of Cross-Strait tensions

About this Event

Abstract
Over the last decade, China has punished countries that undermine its territorial claims and foreign policy goals with measures such as restricting trade, encouraging popular boycotts, and cutting off tourism. These coercive measures have caused significant economic damage to U.S. partners such as Japan, the Philippines, Taiwan, and Australia. This talk focuses on Taiwan’s response to China’s economic sanctions, highlighting the agency of medium-sized countries in the shadow of a great power.
The second part of this presentation will propose a common understanding of the liberal international order in which state and non-state actors follow rules, norms, and legal procedures in conducting international affairs. This rule-based practice is an essential part of the Asian regional order. If Taiwan were integrated into the multilateral institutions in Asia, the chance of conflict would be greatly reduced. The future of Taiwan also depends on the resilience of the liberal international order and other middle-power states in the Asia Pacific.


Bio
Christina Lai is an Associate Research Fellow in the Institute of Political Science at Academia Sinica, Taiwan. Dr. Lai received her Ph.D. in Government from Georgetown University. In 2015-2016, she was a post-doctoral fellow in China and the World Program at Princeton University. She is interested in U.S.-China-Taiwan Relations, Chinese Foreign Policy, East Asian politics, and Qualitative Research Methods. Her works have appeared in the Politics, International Politics, Political Science, PS: Political Science & Politics, Journal of Contemporary China, Pacific Review, and Asian Security.



Agenda


🕑: 04:30 PM - 05:30 PM
Welcome reception with refreshments and light catering

🕑: 05:30 PM - 06:30 PM
Keynote address: Taiwan’s Economic Statecraft and the future of Liberal Intern
Host: Christina Lai

description:
Wellington Mayoral Debate 2025, There is no denying that public sentiment in Wellington has taken a beating. Dwindling economic stats, a struggling CBD and major infrastructure challenges have left the Wellington community feeling unhappy and unheard – and nobody has felt this more than the businesses in that community.
Every electoral cycle has debates, and all of them have politics. But this is the debate to attend if you are in business in Wellington, because unlike the others this debate is focused directly on what matters most to you.
What’s in-store
In partnership with The Post, BNZ & Victoria University of Wellington - Te Herenga Waka, the Wellington Chamber of Commerce is delivering the premier local government event for Wellington business: the 2025 Wellington Mayoral Debate.
Hear candidates Andrew Little, Ray Chung, Diane Calvert, Karl Tiefenbacher and Alex Baker talk about their vision for economic growth, their policy plans to stimulate business and their views on how council can work better with the private sector, all moderated by The Post’s own Andrea Vance.
Following the debate there will be the chance for open questions from the audience, providing you with the chance to hold candidates to account on the issues that matter most to you.
Light refreshments will be provided after the debate, where you’ll be able to network with candidates and business leaders.
Agenda:
5.30pm - Debate
6.30pm - Audience Q&A
7.00pm - Networking with drinks & nibbles
7.30pm - Event ends
Thank you to our media partner The Post , our venue partner, Victoria University of Wellington - Te Herenga Waka, and our supporting partner BNZ for their support.

description:
Antipodes, Antipodes is a quintet of musicians from Sydney and Te Whanganui-a-Tara/Wellington that playfully moves between the arty/cerebral and the folksy/earthy elements of jazz and improvised music. Sometimes delicate and considered, sometimes brawny and muscular, the intent that brings their performances together is a commitment to the song: each composition is a glistening artefact, brought to dynamic life by the ensemble.

Originally formed in Berlin and drawing influences from New York to Stockholm, Antipodes has, over 10 years of touring and recording, forged their own identity: a unique triptych of North American, Northern European, and South Pacific sounds that captivates audiences, offering them a shared journey into their dreamlike and evocative co-creations.

Featuring:

Jake Baxendale (saxophone)
Callum Allardice (guitar)
Luke Sweeting (piano)
Tom Botting (bass)
Tim Geldens (drums)

Part of the Wellington Jazz Festival 2025

Join us for an hands-on workshop where you’ll learn the basics of Product & UX Design, get experience with practical tools, and see how design thinking can transform everyday services and products.
👥 Who’s it for?
Startups, small business owners, and professionals curious about UX.
Students keen to break into the design world (free tickets available).
Anyone who’s struggled with bad digital or service experiences and wants to know how to fix them.
📚 What you’ll get:
A crash course in UX & product design.
Fun group activities to redesign common real-world experiences.
A peek behind the scenes at how design improves outcomes.
Networking with other professionals and students.
🎯 Why come?
You’ll leave with fresh skills, practical frameworks, and maybe even an idea for your next project. Businesses will walk away with insights into their customer challenges, and students will get a taste of real-world UX.
✨ Limited spots — grab your ticket today!

description:
Self Promotion for Business Owners, First impressions count! 
Present yourself as an approachable, confident and competent business owner to attract new clients.
Overview:
Highly interactive in-person workshop, ensuring you action and refine your learnings immediately amidst a safe supportive learning environment.
Our goal is to make a natural strong first impression and spark further conversation with potential clients. We will cover crafting a compelling narrative, identifying a target audience, and practicing impactful delivery.
Key learnings:
Understand basic sales skills and the psychology around self-promotion
Manage your nerves
Refine your message
Become savvy in articulating your USP (unique selling proposition)
Learn what to say when and how using powerful words and body language
Receive on the spot expert coaching and feedback
Work on your voice modulation, posture, and gestures to ooze professionalism
 Previous Workshop Attendee:
"Big thanks to Angelika Barnes for her course on "Self Promotion'. I would highly recommend her. We learnt so much and had a great time doing so! The workshop helped me immensely in developing a clear, concise & compelling way of presenting and promoting myself in future business environments. Angelika is a great presenter."
Luke Swart, Nelson
Presenter Bio:
With a background in sales and communication as trainer for the Banking Academy in Cologne, Germany and roles in both operational and people management, Angelika has maintained her focus on empowering people through highly engaging experiential workshops and 1:1 coaching sessions.
Angelika empowers people to express themselves with confidence and is looking forward to sharing gems that help others succeed.
To register - visit https://www.abcangelikabarnescoaching.com/funded
You could be eligible for up to75% funding through the Regional Business Partner Network (RBPN) Growth Advisors, e.g. Rose Ryan call 03 577 9575 or email rose@mcoc.org.nz o

TENZ Conference 2025, TENZ Conference 2025
TENZ invites you to our 2025 Conference - Inspiring Ākonga Empowering Kaiako, to be held at Wellington East Girls' College, 131 Austin Street, Mount Victoria, Wellington 6011.

The conference is designed for teachers and researchers at all levels of technology education and will provide opportunities to connect with, and learn from, other members of the community as well as get up to date with new products, tools and opportunities that support students’ learning in technology.

Register here: https://tenz.org.nz/2025-conference/

With over 50 sessions spanning the full spectrum of technology education - from food, textiles, DVC, and STEAM to digital, vocational, and emerging tech - there’s something for every kaiako, at every level. Dive into workshops on AI, AR, and rockets; explore neuro inclusion, culturally sustaining practice, and curriculum integration; get practical with tools like Minecraft, WorldPainter, and Brisk; or collaborate on pathways, assessment, and cross-curricular design thinking. Whether you're refining your NCEA practice, reigniting creativity, or discovering new ways to inspire ākonga, these sessions are designed to spark ideas, deepen confidence, and empower you to lead change in your classroom and community. This is your chance to connect, create, and be part of shaping the future of technology education in Aotearoa.

description:
Leadership and Management Part 3, Leaders today are expected to be the driving force of their teams. They are constantly under pressure to lead effectively in a business environment that is characterised by constant change. Our leadership and management courses offer participants the opportunity to develop the necessary skills to embrace this challenge and lead their teams through these times with confidence and pride.

Our Leadership & Management - Part 3 workshop is a practical skills training course designed for people already in a leadership/management position, or those about to take up a new role, who want to explore the latest thinking and models for effective management and leadership and build on the techniques acquired in our Part 1 and 2 workshops.

In today’s world, emotional Intelligence is a critical and powerful component of effective leadership. This 2-day course will equip leaders with the skills to become more ‘people smart’ by developing ways to lead with emotional intelligence. Participants will also learn how to inspire their people with a shared vision and align teams to company goals, along with the tools to lead and manage change, ways to become a more influential and persuasive leader and the tools to raise awareness and manage unconscious bias in the workplace.

To book: email - info@biztrainers.co.nz or call 04 974 8790

We believe our region’s tech future will be stronger when everyone has a seat at the table, and we’re committed to making space for all perspectives to be heard.
Event details
📅 Date: Thursday 18 September 2025
🕘 Time: 10:00 am - 12:00 pm
📍 Location: Te Au Pūngao, cnr Arthur & Seymour Streets
Free to attend, registration is essential for catering purposes.
Join us for morning tea at Te Au Pūngao to connect with others working in technology, innovation, and startups, and to help set the direction for Marlborough’s tech future.
We’ll be talking about:
Making coworking more accessible for sole contractors, early-stage founders, and startups

description:
Win More As a Tradie in 2026!, Win More As a Tradie in 2026!
Get ready to level up your tradie game and learn how to win more jobs, clients, and money in 2026!

About this Event

Win More As a Tradie in 2026!
Come join us at the Stokes Valley Rugby Football Club for an exciting event tailored just for tradies like you! Learn valuable tips and tricks to boost your business and increase your success in 2026. Network with fellow tradies and industry experts to gain insights and grow your professional circle. Don't miss out on this opportunity to take your trade to the next level!



Key Topics & Talking Points
Quote Smarter, Win More
How to make your quotes stand out from the competition with simple, professional templates.
Using free/low-cost quoting tools to speed up response time (and why speed wins jobs).
Adding small touches (images, guarantees, payment links) that boost acceptance rates.

Lead Tracking Made Easy
Simple ways to track every enquiry so none fall through the cracks.
Using a basic CRM or spreadsheet to stay on top of follow-ups.
How to automate reminders so you never forget to reply.

Booking Without the Back-and-Forth
How to let customers book jobs or quotes online, even outside work hours.
Tools to sync bookings with your calendar automatically.
Why offering easy booking options can double your conversion rates.

Boosting Your Online Presence
Making Google Reviews work for you — and how to get them without pestering.
Setting up a simple “digital business card” (or Quickr app) for instant credibility.
Quick wins on Facebook & Instagram that take 10 minutes a week.

Following Up Like a Pro
The 3-day rule for follow-ups — and why it secures more jobs.
Automating polite reminders for quotes and overdue invoices.
Staying front-of-mind without being pushy.

Why It’s Impactful for 2026

Customers expect fast, simple communication — these tools make it effortless.
You can compete with bigger companies without hiring extra staff.
Every strategy here is low-cost or free, and takes less than 1 hour to set up.

This event is free, with an Open Bar & Nibbles provided by the Stokes Valley Rugby Club.

Registration for the event is recommended so we can determine numbers.

description:
The Inevitabilism Panel, We're told AI is Progress, progress that cannot be stopped, that it will change the way we work and live, from business to education and the commons. But who says? Whose progress and whose AI is it anyway? Is societal progress really bound to technological innovation, or are there other ways of reading - and even shaping - positive social change?
Technological Determinism is described as the belief system that social progress is driven by technological innovation, which in turn follows an "inevitable" course." This panel will take a good hard look at this 'inevitabilism' - its forces and politics - with a view to our shared future in Aotearoa and the Pacific.
Join us for a rigorous evening of discussion with a view to how we might gain more understanding - and more say - as to the reach and influence new technologies have over our autonomy, dignity, communities and cultures.

With over 15 years’ experience in senior leadership roles within the tertiary education sector, Jerry brings a wealth of expertise in strategic thinking, stakeholder engagement, and turning vision into action, as evidenced by some of the exciting things happening in the area which Jerry will share with us. 
 
Join us for an evening of insight and inspiration and hear one of the region’s most dedicated leaders talk about: 
Te Utanganui - designed to be New Zealand's third major distribution hub, complementing the Golden Triangle (Auckland-Hamilton-Tauranga) and the Christchurch-Rolleston node. Te Utanganui is a transformative multi-modal logistics and distribution hub located in Palmerston North, it serves as a vital link in the national freight network currently going through transformational changes connecting road, rail, air, and sea transport systems. 
Manawatū Regional Food Strategy, our Land Diversification initiative and the complementary capability between regions
Regional NZ - the need to work together, shared populations, future growth plans
Electra Business After Five
Thursday 21st August 2025  
5.30-7pm $10+bf
Te Takeretanga o Kura-hau-pō, Levin

description:
Export Ready: Strategies and Lessons for International Growth, Whether you're exploring new markets, refining your export strategy, or preparing to scale globally, this practical workshop will equip you with the tools, insights, and confidence to take your business international
What’s in store
Join export expert Pete Torrington for an interactive, 2.5-hour workshop designed specifically for local producers and manufacturers. Drawing on over 30 years of global experience, Pete will guide you through the essential steps to becoming export ready.
You’ll learn how to:
Assess your export potential and avoid common pitfalls
Choose the right international markets for your product
Build effective distribution and retail strategies
Navigate food safety, packaging, and compliance requirements
Price and promote your product for global shelves
Whether you're just starting your export journey or want to sharpen your approach, this workshop offers real-world advice and actionable strategies to help you succeed.
Who should attend
Food and beverage producers
Consumer goods manufacturers
Agribusinesses and primary sector entrepreneurs
Anyone considering export as a growth strategy
About the Facilitator
Pete Torrington is the founder of Ask Pete Advisory and brings over 30 years of international commercial experience in food and consumer goods, including senior roles at Colgate-Palmolive across Europe, Asia, and Australasia. He now works with New Zealand manufacturers and producers to help them grow in overseas markets.
More information: www.askpete.co.nz
Agenda

ExportNZ / Business Central/ Manawatū Chamber Member: $59 +gst

Every one of us serves customers, whether we realise it or not.  Together we will look at all types of customers and how we can serve them better and improve ourselves in the process.  
State what customer service means in relation to all your customers.
Recognise how your attitude affects customer service.
Identify your customers’ needs.
Create a great first impression

Build good will through in-person customer service.

The WaiHost Outstanding Customer Experience workshop is the only customer service training course on the market that is based on 8 years of research & data looking into what Kiwi consumers expect from companies they do business with.

description:
Celebrate the Fabric, Exquisite pieces of needlework are on display and in use every day at Wellington Cathedral of
St Paul: beautifully decorated fabrics that hang at the front of the altars, spectacular robes and
stoles worn by priests at services, and fine linens used at every service of Holy Communion.

You’ll learn much about this remarkable fabric artistry when Jo Dixey talks to the Friends of
Wellington Cathedral of St Paul and guests on Wednesday, 24 September at 10.30 am.
Jo is an internationally regarded professional embroiderer who graduated from the Royal
School of Needlework and now lives permanently in New Zealand. She teaches, exhibits and sells
her work, as well as accepting commissions from churches, fashion designers and private
individuals. She has also had contracts from the film industry, working on the Disney film Mulan
and most recently on season 1 of Lord of the Rings TV series. Jo’s collection of embroidered
3D viruses, created during the 2020 Covid lockdown, are now on display in The Museum of
New Zealand Te Papa Tongarewa.

Venue: Loaves and Fishes Hall, Wellington Cathedral of St Paul.

label: Religion & Spirituality

description:
EYA Presents: The Bible and the Sacraments Bible Study, What are the Sacraments? Where do they come from? What do they mean? And why are they so central to our Catholic Faith?
In The Bible and the Sacraments, you’ll discover the deeply biblical roots of the Seven Sacraments and how they are more than mere Church rituals, but streams of life flowing from the living Body of Christ.
Throughout this study, you’ll discover how God has always dealt with His people through “sacraments,” and how the sacraments of the Old Testament find their ultimate fulfillment in the Seven Sacraments instituted by Christ and celebrated in the Catholic Church to this day.
Eucharistia Young Adults (EYA) introduces our second Bible study for 2025! This eleven-lesson Bible study by St Paul Center will delve into the beauty of the sacraments of the Catholic Church.
Please bring your Bible, journal, pen - and of course, your lovely self! Bring your friends, co-workers, family members, the more the merrier!
__________________
Every Wednesday | 16 July 2025 - 08 October 2025
St Mary's of the Angels Parish Hall
Everyone is most welcome!

description:
Sound Journey - WELLINGTON, Sound Journey - WELLINGTON
This powerful experience is like a soundtrack that is crafted to go with your life.

Something between an ancient ceremony and a movie soundtrack.

Please bring a yoga mat, pillow and blanket. Be prepared to drop into a deep space.
Door sales will be available if there is space. Advanced booking is recommended.

Sika's Sound Journeys are truly unique. They are sonic explorations that feature didgeridoos, drums, flutes, voice and orchestral elements.�A collection of foraged sounds from objects he has recorded in nature, add even more textures. Many of his sounds are completely unrecognisable and abstract. Immersed in this cocoon of abstract sound, we can find ourselves in the most surprising places in our mind. In this timeless realm, beyond the normal limitations of rational reality, anything is possible.

An epic adventure deep inside yourself.

Journey to worlds within worlds on incredible sound waves.

Sika creates a safe space to relax deeply and connect with our inner guidance. This Sound Journey begins and ends with a short guided visualisation.

There will be two journeys with an interval. Most people choose to lie down, so once again, please bring a yoga mat, pillow and blanket to get really comfortable.

A journal is also recommended.

description:
Wes Huff | Truth Matters Tour | Wellington, Wes Huff | Truth Matters Tour | Wellington
We're excited to invite you to an evening of insight and inspiration as we welcome Wes Huff for a special Thinking Matters event. Wes is a gifted communicator and seasoned apologist known for helping Christians confidently navigate questions of faith, reason, and truth in today's skeptical culture.

In this thought-provoking session, Wes will unpack key ideas that will challenge your thinking, deepen your understanding of the Christian worldview, and equip you to engage meaningfully with the world around you. Whether you're solid in your faith or wrestling with big questions, this night promises to be impactful and encouraging.

Don’t miss this unique opportunity to hear from Wes Huff and be part of a community passionate about truth.
One night only – reserve your spot now!

description:
Aussie medium, Simon Hay at the Palmy Conference and Function Centre, Aussie medium, Simon Hay at the Palmy Conference and Function Centre
An Evening of Live Mediumship and Healing with Aussie Medium, Simon Hay

Simon is a psychic medium, medical intuitive and healer. He travels throughout Australia and New Zealand doing private sessions and events. His down-to-earth style of mediumship is accurate, surprising, and entertaining.
At these events, Simon shares messages and accurate information from spirit, but he's passionate about educating about energy healing and mediumship so he also answers audience questions about his career. If you’re curious about communicating to spirit and energy healing, you’ll love this event.
Enjoy…
• A demonstration of psychic mediumship readings in the Elwood Room
• Q and A — ask questions about spirit and energy healing
Arrive to be seated by 7:15 pm.
$55/ticket
Re ticket purchasers, we have a no refund policy. Be certain about attending before purchasing.
Not all attendees will receive readings (attendance doesn’t guarantee you’ll get a reading)
This is an adults only (16 years +) event. Parents, be aware that I often talk about topics suitable only for adults.
To be polite and respectful, turn off your phone during the event, and do not video or record any part of the event.
Prior to attending this event, visit Simon Hay's website, read all the information there and the disclaimer in its entirety. Thank you.

description:
The Greatest Story - A Group of Wise Teachers Returning, Public Talk & Workshop

Throughout history, especially at times of crisis, great spiritual teachers have emerged to show humanity the next step forward.

According to British artist, author and esotericist Benjamin Creme, a group of such spiritual teachers is now living in the modern world. Maitreya, the World Teacher, and his group The Masters of Wisdom are here - not as religious teachers - to inspire all people to create a civilisation based on sharing, justice and peace; and for humanity to act to do the work to share and save our world.

Humanity at spiritual crossroads

Humanity is at crossroads. One path into the future leads to increasing social and economic division, environmental destruction, war and planetary peril. The other path leads to increasing social harmony, economic and environmental balance, and a golden era of peace.


Maitreya’s priorities

To help humanity in its task of global transformation, Maitreya has formulated certain priorities. They cover the essential needs of all people, every woman, man and child: an adequate supply of food; housing for all; healthcare and education as basic universal rights. Other top priorities include the restoration of the environment and the establishment of peace.

The key to achieving these goals requires a major shift of present mind-set and thinking, structures and systems – and more equitable sharing of the world’s food and resources. To realise humanity is one global family and the planet is a living being. According to Maitreya: “Without sharing, there can be no justice; without justice, there can be no peace; without peace, there can be no future.”

~ followed by short Transmission Meditation session ~

Share International New Zealand. Contact (021) 261 2749
Access - entrance from Raumati Road/ walk - drive past Te Raukura ki Kāpiti / Kāpiti Performing Arts Centre

description:
New beginnings, New hope. Faith Responses in a Changing World, Join us for an inspiring interfaith panel discussion featuring speakers from the Muslim, Jewish, and Christian traditions. As the world continues to face rapid change, how do our faiths help us respond with hope, compassion, and renewal?
This is the second Wellington event in the Abrahamic Interfaith Dialogue series, proudly presented by the Pearl of the Islands Foundation in collaboration with the Wellington Abrahamic Council.
Light refreshments will be provided
Come along to listen, reflect, and be part of a meaningful conversation. All are welcome.
